text:
I visited the Basilique-Cath√©drale de Saint-Denis ladt year and really enjoyed it. The building has an amazing past. What stands today mostly comes from the 12th‚Äì13th centuries, when the choir completed in 1144 became the first structure to use all the key elements of Gothic architecture. But the site goes back much further. It began as a shrine built over the tomb of Saint Denis, the first bishop of Paris, and over time it became a major royal abbey and the burial place of many French kings and queens. After centuries of changes and damage, it was finally restored and recognised again as a cathedral.
Inside, the first thing you notice is the light. The tall stained-glass windows fill the space with colour, and the high arches make everything feel open. The royal necropolis is the highlight for many visitors. It holds more than seventy tombs of French kings and queens, including famous ones such as Dagobert I, Henri II and Catherine de‚Äô Medici, Louis XII and Anne of Brittany, and memorials for Louis XVI and Marie-Antoinette. The stone sculptures are detailed and give you a clear sense of how people looked and dressed in different centuries.
The main altar stands above the area traditionally linked to the tomb of Saint Denis. Around the altar you see the oldest part of the church, the crypt, where the early history of the basilica began. The choir behind the altar is one of the first examples of true Gothic architecture, and walking around it you notice how the columns and windows were designed to bring in as much light as possible.
There is also plenty to look at as you move through the chapels, including the carved choir stalls, the rose window, and quiet corners with older stonework. I enjoyed taking my time in the ambulatory, where the stained glass changes colour as you walk.
Entry is normally ‚Ç¨17 from Tuesday to Sunday and ‚Ç¨11 on Mondays. Many visitors can enter for free, including under-18s, people aged 18‚Äì25 from the EU or who live in the EU, and disabled visitors with their carers. Audio guides and short free tours are also available.
It‚Äôs a peaceful place filled with history and beautiful details, and I left feeling like I had discovered a side of France that many travellers miss.

Impressive church and since the 7th century the burial site for nearly every French monarch (43 kings, 32 queens, and other royalty).

It is also the birthplace of Gothic Architecture as in the 12th century (c. 1135‚Äì1144), Abbot Suger directed a major renovation in which he incorporated key architectural innovations like the pointed arch, ribbed vaults, and extensive stained-glass windows to flood the interior with light. This design became the blueprint for cathedrals across Europe.

During the French Revolution (1793), the basilica was secularized and its royal tombs were desecrated, with the remains of the monarchs exhumed and dumped into common graves.

Among them King Louis XIV, King Louis XVI and his wife Marie Antoinette.
Louis XVI and Marie Antoinette were beheaded by guillotine during the French Revolution in 1793 at the Place de la R√©volution (now Place de la Concorde) in Paris. Their bodies were then dumped in quicklime in the Cimeti√®re de la Madeleine

In 1815, after the Restoration of the monarchy, the remains were exhumed but only fragments in poor condition remained which are now in two sober graves. There is a splendid sculpture of them both in the church

The remains of Louis XIV and other kings, queens and other royalty were recovered from the mass graves of the revolution, identified in so far possible and placed in two ossuaries in the basilica's crypt. For Louis XIV there is a cenotaph

Entry is ‚Ç¨ 17,- but that is well worth it as you get a lot of French history and at the end there is an interesting small artisan village with trades related to the church restoration and a large video presentation.

Extremely beautiful windows in a different style than many other churches. Most of the windows have recently been renovated so the light in the church was amazing. Only part of the church demands an entrance fee. So it is worthwhile even if you do not want to pay the fee to see the front of the church.
Comprehensively wonderful. French history. Beautiful architecture.  Very much worth a visit even if you are only remotely interested

A very odd woman started singing some religious songs when we were in one of the tiny crypt. You know, those fanatics who stand in the corner in their trance with closed eyes. I met these people before in old Mexican pyramid but Not sure what kind of energy this lady was looking in such place. it looked stupid and scares kids and other visitors. However it made me feel like I am still mentally not bad.  The basilica itself is very interesting place especially if you familiar with French history and royal dynasties.
Magnificent chateau once belonging to a bellicose count. External decoration is superb, though there isn't a huge amount to see inside. Much recommended for an hour's stop, all the same.

Stunning facade with a few rooms.
Pity the lady on reception could not have provided a welcome smile or indeed any welcome.
Amazing place, architecture superb, not too busy with tourists. An enjoyable rainy afternoon spent
A wonderful discovery of this castle steeped in history, but which unfortunately suffered from numerous lootings. A magnificent fa√ßade.
A lovely castle to visit, adorned with magnificent sculptures! Plenty of reading material retracing the life of "Galiot" de Genouillac and his passion for architecture. Self-guided tour.

An impressive cathedral showcasing a seamless blend of late Romanesque and early Gothic architecture.
The style is remarkably uniform, with a beautifully restored and captivating main portal.
A true ‚Äòmust-see‚Äô in this tranquil city, which also features Roman remnants like a theater, city gates, and ancient walls.
Beautifully restored cathedral church. Some brilliant new stained glass. No visitors Sundays unless attending services.
Brilliantly restored and lit. One can see the carvings on the portal and on the capitals as never before. It looks absolutely lovely.

Impressive late Romanesque, early Gothic cathedral, very homogeneous in style. The main portal is well restored and very interesting. A "must see" in a quiet city, which also offers Roman remains: theater, city-gates, walls,...
Beautiful cathedral, worth the visit in a charming town

Fantastic history lesson. How often can you walk around the tops of ramparts and castle walls!  And the tapestry. Unbelievable. I can‚Äôt recommend the audio guide enough. The explanations were detailed and thorough.

Excellent! A superb chateau with 800+ years of history, hosting the vast and impressive tapestry of the apocalypse. There is a huge moat with ornate gardens in one part, excellent views of the river and city, superb ramparts and a multilingual audio guide that gives you the details as you walk around. There are internal herb and flower gardens and even a small vineyard within the chateau!

Big discovery - I didn‚Äôt know this castle. If you want to see how people leaves 600 years ago this is the place to be. The visit is around 2 hours long and I recommend you see entire place. Nice Apocalypse stamp , nice story , I was impressed by what people can do 600-700 years ago.

Lots of things to see:  gardens, ramparts, exhibits, the Tapestry of the Apocalypse and a surprisingly nice restaurant.  We just got ice cream and ate in the shade, but plenty to do.  I recommend the audio guide for the Tapestry of the Apocalypse.
We used the audio guide while visiting which was well worth it for the tapestry. Which is absolutely amazing. The rest of the fortress is worth the visit. The gardens are especially impressive

Fantastic fortress built by Vauban from 1693, one of the 12 major Vauban sites listed in 2008 as a UNESCO World Heritage Site. Behind his pink marble walls, we can see the barracks where the soldiers of Louis XIV lived, the scalable on the pic where they watched, the powder maker, the arsenal where they kept weapons and powder.

It is also also an unusual village where 170 inhabitants live, like everyone else, but in an extraordinary setting of southern sun, dazzling snow, silence and stones steeped in history. From the rampart, observe the strategic node of valleys : the Mountains of Queyras with a thousand hikes, the ski resorts of Vars and Risoul, the glaciers of the 4,000m of the Ecrins massif !

Looks amazing but never got in as I ran out of time sussing the place out.

What you need to know.

There are two parking areas. 1 at the bottom of a hill with a steep climb to the village (round trip 1.25 hrs) the other is at the top with about 10 mins flat walk to the entry point.

Neither are well signed from the road. Refer to Google maps for better guidance before setting off.
Beautiful backdrop for an amazing international Jazz concert with the European Jazz Companions! What √† day ü•∞ I'll be back soon to visit the rest of the fortifications !
Tall walls with nice views. Some constructions are covered by the beautiful geometric and continuous shapes of soil. The walls also seems to be projected by  genuine engineers.
A beautiful historic town with stunning scenery, lots to see and do. The fortifications, ramparts, church, main street, and cheese making were impressive, and fascinating.

Stepping into the grounds of Ch√¢teau de Vincennes felt like entering a page of French history ‚Äî grand towers, ancient stone walls, and the sound of hooves echoing through the courtyard. Watching the parade of military horsemen was truly a sight to behold ‚Äî a perfect blend of tradition, discipline, and grace. It‚Äôs moments like these that remind you how beautifully France preserves its royal and military heritage.

This is a wonderful place to explore.  It's easily accessible by bus or metro and it boarders a large park that includes the zoo. You can easily spend a whole day in the area, especially with kids.  My 12 year old grandson loved the castle. It was nearly empty when we visited and it felt like real exploring, passages, towers, and "secret rooms", his imagination took us on quite an adventure.

Great place with monumental architecture and long history. Entrance for people with disabilities was completely free. The area was equipped with accessible ramps for people with disabilities, but the entrance for some areas of the castle is still unavailable for wheelchair/walker users. Also, you can buy souvenirs on the spot.
The castle is truly impressive. I visited at night, with the full moon shining over its walls ‚Äî it looked immense and majestic, like something out of a legend.

I was visiting the Chateau Vincennes during the week and in the morning, right at the opening hours. And it was a good decision because it was not crowded and we visit all the places quietly. Very special place. If you come to Paris and you have time, it's a good decision to visit this chateau.

Nice climb, gets you in shape ! (And a possible break about halfway in)

The view at the top is more than worth it though ! Absolutely stunning sights of bordeaux, and great signs and historical explanations.

Friendly staff.

I'd recommend to anyone, from anywhere, and especially people from Bordeaux such as me who have never actually gone up !
We had a great weather. It costs few euro, lots of stairs, but worth the climb. Great view over the city.

Reaching the top of Tour is no easy feat, but the panoramic views of the city are breathtaking. The narrow stairs and passages add to the challenge, but it's well worth the effort. A must-visit for anyone looking to experience in center of Bordeaux.

Great view, not too many people.
Little to no information on the top, there is a handout in different languages available at the bottom of the stairs.
Staff was friendly, ticket was booked online (for a certain time frame).
We came because it was included in the bordeaux pass and would recommend it if you want to have a view over the city
Wonderful church with a huge tower. Nice to look at!

The H√¥tel de Sully is a historic stop in the Marais that is as understated as it is charming. Built in the 17th century, this mansion offers a glimpse into Louis XIII architecture, with its intricately designed facade, quiet courtyard, and manicured garden. While it may not captivate for long, it provides a brief escape from the bustling streets of Paris.

The highlight of visiting is the hidden passageway that connects Rue Saint-Antoine to the iconic Place des Vosges. Walking through the courtyard and emerging into the historic square adds a sense of discovery to your exploration of the Marais. The garden is peaceful, but not particularly remarkable, and while the architecture is beautiful, it doesn‚Äôt demand more than a few moments of attention.

The H√¥tel de Sully also houses the Centre des Monuments Nationaux, which can be of interest for those curious about French heritage, though it‚Äôs a small feature that may not appeal to everyone.

While the H√¥tel de Sully is a pleasant addition to a Marais itinerary, it‚Äôs not a must-see. It‚Äôs best appreciated as a quick detour on your way to Place des Vosges or as a quiet stop amid a busy day of exploring the neighborhood.

A calm and historically rich spot worth visiting if you‚Äôre already nearby, but not a destination that stands out in Paris‚Äôs sea of extraordinary landmarks.

It's a secret gem!
From the outside looks like any ordinary building but once you go through the doors you feel like you entered another era and imagine the horse carriages and all the elite dressed up in the 1800s
The House museum of Victor Hugo is also inside this complex of buildings including a magnificent garden
Entrance was free

P√âNIBLEMENT LONG ET ENNUYEUX !

AWFUL handling of European Heritage Days. The worst. A 90 minute wait (people were sitting in the ground in the live, became the live didn‚Äôt move), and then a long boring talk in an ugly room, followed by more boring talk in the bedroom. It was painful for everyone.

In the future they should set up the rooms so the public can walk through, instead of subjecting people to so much pain and suffering.  I hated it so much.
Love place to sit in the grounds of this Passion monuments location and it's free. No guided tours when we were there but staff were very helpful  regarding  membership card delivery.

The finest example of early 17th-century Parisian architecture, with a stunning courtyard and orangerie. The bookshop specializes in art and garden titles - their vintage postcard collection is worth browsing. The hidden formal garden (open first Sundays) features espaliered pear trees trained in historic patterns.
If you didn't speak French, you won't get much from this.  There are leaflets experiencing the exhibits but very few of those are available in English.

We bought the tickets for both Glanum and the H√¥tel de Sade museum (billets jumeaux) but we weren‚Äôt all that impressed with the museum itself. It‚Äôs really more about the excavations of the site of Glanum, with fewer artefacts than might be expected. The museum is in St R√©my de Provence, a bit of a walk on a very hot day.

Wonderful little museum that you should not miss if you visit Glanum excavation site. Small but very informative historic presentation. The site also evokes a sense of the continuity through the centuries.

The museum does not have much to offer and can easily be skipped. It does not at all stand up against the ruins on the outskirts of the city. The museum struggles to even fill anything of importance in it's four small rooms.
A small museum dedicated to the excavations in Glanum. Interesting but small and you would struggle to spend an hour there.

Arrive 1205...told closes at 1215...info says 1230. I had 25 mins to look at something that lasts 5 at most. Dont waste yr time coming here just look at the photos in the reviews. And definitely not worth paying for just come if have national monument pass (which I didn't get to use)
It is a little bit disappointing that what you actually see in the pics is all you can see.  But though an interesting piese of history.
Worth a visit but quite small. A real feeling of history.
Nice place for a short visit

The fresco is magnificent, but the chapel is tiny, and you pay 5 euros just to admire the fresco, which is certainly period! The priory isn't open to visitors. So, I find the price a bit exorbitant! A shame for the culture!
Go visit the Ch√¢teau de Berz√©-le-Chatel instead, which offers much more for 8 euros!

A bit off the beaten-track, the Chateau de Bouges is not amongst the first that you would think of while summing up the impressive list of Loire-chateaux.
It's however a very interesting visit (guided visits only, so you should check the website for the hours) and around the Chateau is a huge park, well-maintained with plenty of beautiful trees and flowers.
The Chateau de Bouges has known many different owners (even Talleyrand, but he did not leave a lasting memory). Most prominent owner was the founder of the famous BHV Paris warehouse.
The castle tour takes around one hour and you can easily spend two more hours in the garden. Note that there is no restaurant.
Very nice and interesting castle. Guided tour with written info in English.
Nice little castle in a gigantic garden/parc. You can spend the entire day just in the garden..
Really lovely place,  both the chateau and the village.  Well worth a visit
Incredible chateau, nice guide, huge grounds and great souvenir, it definitely deserves 5 stars

I really enjoyed visiting Place de la Bastille. The Colonne de Juillet in the center is beautiful and full of history‚Äîit was built to remember the July Revolution of 1830. It‚Äôs amazing to stand where the Bastille prison once stood. A special and meaningful place in Paris. A must-visit for anyone who loves history and atmosphere

For Paris, this place is basically just a spire in an open area.  It was the location of a famous prison, but it was destroyed, so it's essentially just an large open area, and the spire.  It's a little cool and it is near to a lot of other things so if you have the time, I would say why not.

Place de la Bastille is one of Paris's most historic and symbolic squares, marking the site of the Bastille prison, whose storming on July 14, 1789, sparked the French Revolution. Today, the square is a bustling hub, featuring the towering July Column (Colonne de Juillet), which commemorates the revolutionaries of 1830. Surrounding the square are lively caf√©s, shops, and cultural venues, including the modern Op√©ra Bastille. Place de la Bastille is also a starting point for exploring nearby attractions like the Marais district and Port de l‚ÄôArsenal. Its historical significance and vibrant atmosphere make it a must-visit destination for those seeking a deeper connection to Paris's revolutionary past.

Visited just days prior to Bastille Day when much activity was ongoing.  The whole Bastille area on the edge of la Marais is worth exploring.  The column is at the hub and round a bout for the street leading up to the Bastille.  Ornate column with gold figure atop is worth the quick look.

Recently spent a week in Paris and enjoyed seeing the July Column (Colonne de Juillet) at Place de la Bastille again. This is a 47 metre tall column monument that was erected in the centre of the plaza between 1835-40.

Previously the location of the infamous Bastille Prison which was destroyed during the early days of the French Revolution. What you find here is a bronze column, topped by a gilded figure - the Genius of Liberty'. The base of the column includes decorative bas-reliefs which are not easy to see from afar.

Unfortunately, the monument is surrounded by a busy roundabout, making it less convenient to view up close. However, you can have a good look from the street intersections that lead to the square.

In the end, an impressive monument but not easy to view from up close. Have a look-see when passing through Place de la Bastille in the La Marais.

A fascinating place full of history. The visit is not very long but truly interesting, especially the section about the French Revolution and Marie-Antoinette‚Äôs cell. The architecture is impressive and the atmosphere takes you back in time. Definitely worth adding to your itinerary.

Its a small place so not a lot of people come here. You can see Marie Antoinette‚Äôs cell - where she was forced to stay for 76 days before her death. They have a lot of history of the French Revolution. Good place to hang out for an hour or two for history buffs. They also have the interactive ipads that show you how the place looked like back in the day.

A must come place if you are curious/ love the history of French, especially French Revolution, and Queen Maria Antoinette.
They give every visitor a pad that you can scan and discovery the space how it was through the times with explaination. Very interesting.

Suggest to buy to combo ticket of this and the Saint-Chapell so you can save the time of the queue.

A little place filled with history. I recommend to get an audio guide, 3euros on top of the entrance fee to get the most out of the visit.

We visited rather near visiting closing time but were welcomed with smiles and a friendly attitude by everyone, from the security staff to the ticket seller.

You can admire roman architecture as well as learn about the French revolution and conditions of imprisonment here. In the old refectory, there used to be something different on display as seen in other older reviews. Bow you can find an impressive model of Notre Dame de Paris explaining a little how it's built and how it was reconstructed.

Thank you for this visit üòä

Incredible experience. I‚Äôll never see Paris the same way as before. The interactive tour is simply mesmerizing. It‚Äôs as if we went through the French Revolution again, walking the same roads leads to Concorde where they used to chop off the heads‚Ä¶ highly recommended for a vivid understanding of the French revolution in Paris.

It is such a beautiful church. The artworks are magnificent.

I love how they have Adoration of the Blessed Sacrament from Tuesday to Saturday; before the daily mass.

We came in December for the Chroma display which was absolutely beautiful. Well worth a visit. Returned to visit the following day and enjoyed a calm, quiet walk around the inside of this magnificent cathedral

If you're anywhere near Amiens, don't miss this cathedral ‚Äî it's absolutely worth the detour. Notre-Dame d‚ÄôAmiens is even bigger than the one in Paris, and way less crowded. The detail on the facade is insane, and inside it feels massive and peaceful at the same time. In the summer, I‚Äôd recommend going late afternoon so you can catch the light show in the evening ‚Äî it's honestly magical how they bring the front of the cathedral to life with color. Tip: take your time walking around the outside too ‚Äî there are lots of little carvings and details you might miss!

I have a thing for Cathedrals, and this one was exceptional. Bigger than the one in Paris it‚Äôs filled with stunning details. Free light show on the facade every evening in the summer. We visited on a Friday afternoon and it was very quiet. We were driving past Amiens and I‚Äôm very glad we stopped!

I was stunned at first sight and drawn into the mysticism and ritual. Then suddenly the Sun came out and the nave was bathed in mystic light and I was stunned anew. It was a night-and -day experience and it was still only noon. The experiences you have here are of the things you hold dear for your life.

Azay le Rideau is a beautiful, compact, ch√¢teau, within a few minutes walk of the village. We had no problem parking in the Chateau car park, but it was the end of September.
We had a lovely meal in the restaurant at a reasonable price.
The visit route takes you to the top floor first, then brings you down. We were advised, by a guide, to unhook the rope on the second floor and not proceed to the top as the stairs are much more uneven and my sister walks with a stick. I continued to the top, but she, wisely, followed the advice. I have to endorse what the guide told us; for anyone not too steady on their feet, do stop at the first floor.
The rooms are furnished; particularly the ground floor which makes the chateau very homely. It is not a grand or pompous place, you can imagine a family living there!
The chateau is surrounded by lovely parkland, which we didn't explore as my sister had walked as far as the day permitted and we still needed to return to the car park. Unfortunately, we hadn't realised that there was BLUE BADGE PARKING right outside the entrance where you pay to go in.
So beautiful. Should come here to visit. It‚Äôs large, the light is very good to take pictures. I feel like you can take pictures everywhere in this ch√¢teau it still turns out to be beautiful

This is a masterpiece among the castles of France. The castle is very beautiful, there is a picturesque park around the castle. Near the entrance there is a cafe where you can have a snack and delicious ice cream. Don't forget to look into the secret garden in front of the entrance to the castle grounds. In the parking lot you can find a place on the grass in the shade of the trees.
Wow. Stunning ch√¢teau with moat. Great for photography and much more stunning than Villandry but the gardens are no match to them
Well worth a visit in the Loire. We happened to visit just as they were setting up Christmas decorations

Very very good visit. Absolutely stunning interior and they even had games out in the courtyard. Great visit for groups of all ages. Definitely worth a trip to see.

Set in a beautiful area as well. The gardens are free and the house is paid.

Guide books available in multiple languages

Friendly and informative staff. As chateaus go this one is more a mansion than a castle. Very much still being refurbished. So beyond the rooms and views not much to see. Certainly worth dropping by if you are already in town.

We visited the day of the Journ√©e de Patrimoine. There were lots of people dressed in period costumes all made by the group. Many tables showing their skills and demonstrations of games, dance and reading for the children. An excellent morning.

Wonderful building. Some amazing rooms. Many empty but this can help accentuate the architecture. Like a lot of French historical places, very reasonable price to visit. Quite a bit of information in English on the rooms, although it is quite dry information about the furniture etc rather than the story of the place. Visit was just under one hour.
Versailles was closed and fully booked so we came here instead. Love it! It's well preserved and not too many tourists. Recommended to buy tickets online through 3rd party, it's cheaper.

Awesome quick trip from Arles - honestly, way neater than we anticipated. 7 euros per person, well worth it. The views of the region from the top of the tower, the history, the tranquil feeling, the sculptures in the cloister, the echo in the church. Go check it out!! Open on Sundays.

Visited today with my daughter who was under 18, so she got free entry!

The staff are wonderful and very friendly. I'm not french and they explained everything perfectly!  Even have the tour leaflet in English, also alot of the exhibits have some English at the bottom.

We went almost there hours walking around and had an amazing time!!

Very clean and well maintained, lots to see

Highly recommend for everyone to visit

Very impressing medieval caste with powerful towers and massive walls. It‚Äôs a engaging journey into history. There are many corridors, halls and ancient buildings which may well impress. I think it‚Äôs well maintained.

Wonderful place to visit. Since being taken over by a foundation the site has seen improvements and more renovated buildings. It is Magical and spiritual as well as a great starting point to discover the history of Provence, with its monks in this once island. The chapel is a dream and the top of the tower gives you a view you won't believe.
Very peaceful, beautiful views.

I really enjoyed my visit. It‚Äôs in a very special place in amongst the lovely wooded hills of the Var. I didn‚Äôt mind paying the entrance fee because how much would it cost to maintain these sort of buildings and repair them! It was lovely to walk around and soak in the atmosphere. There‚Äôs also a lovely cafe just outside at run by a lovely mother and his son And there was good spots for us to park our bicycles.
One of the most amazing places i've visited, really shows how monks used to live back in the day. Abbey and surrounding nature makes you feel like you're back to medieval times

Beautiful abandoned monastery set among trees a few miles outside Carc√®s. The monks may have gone, but their church and monastic buildings remain and it's fascinating to look at how they, and the Lay Brothers, lived their simple lives. (Not too simple though. Look at the size of that tithe barn). The acoustics in the the Romanesque church are wonderful. Outside, even the grasshoppers keep reverentially quiet. If feeding the flesh is as important to you as feeding the spirit, then there's a very pleasant little coffee shop in the car park a few hundred yards away. Tickets are 9‚Ç¨ and can be bought in advance on the website.

Entering through the gateway to Thoronet is like stepping out of time. The museum‚Äôs quiet halls open into a world where the Cistercians‚Äô austere simplicity still breathes through the stones.

Further out into the courtyard around the church, one encounters silence , an architecture that does not shout, but whispers of proportion, light, and shadow. Here, each step becomes a meditation on how humanity shapes spaces for the sacred.

In the olive production, where soil and labor are joined, one is reminded of the rhythm of monastic life: prayer and work, ora et labora. The roots of the olive trees reach deep, as if searching for what lies hidden in the frost the quiet force that carries both fruit and history.

And finally, the magnificent jar. A simple vessel, yet also a symbol: humanity‚Äôs attempt to give form to what would otherwise slip away. Here, clay becomes a mirror of our own existence, fragile, yet filled with meaning.

Thoronet is not merely a visit; it is a reminder that simplicity can be the most enduring. Perhaps something we ought to reflect on more today.
To me there was almost no the spirit- they made it like museum and take 9 euro for the entrance. Disapointed.

An extremely interesting historical place with thumbs of famous French. It worths to go down to the thumbs, to learn about those politicians, philosophers, authors, scientists, but I liked the large space and pieces of history on the ground floor. Beautiful, amazing, original.

One of the beautiful French Mausoleum in the heart of Paris 5th arrondisment. The inside is wonderful and the must visit is the crypt which has the panth√©onis√©d remainings of famous French persons such as Victor Hugo, Marue-Pierre Curie. L√©on Foucault's experiment of diurnal motion is still visible.

Beautiful building. Not crowded. The crypt is amazing with notable historical figures (Victor Hugo) to current historical figures.  The ambience was definitely church-like and quiet, respectful. Definitely worth a visit. Thd Pantheon is included in The Paris Pass, which I highly recommend purchasing if visiting Paris and it's plethora of museums.

Just beautiful! The murals on the walls are exceptional, the space awe inspiring, and the tombs a sobering reminder of some of the great people that helped form the French identity.

It truly was a special experience, informative, and a nice pause from the hustle and bustle of the city.

Sizable place. Beautiful building. I liked how there were multiple themes going on with the art. (Christianity, Genevieve, etc) The crypt is interesting because there are many famous/important historical figures in there. But all the crypts are the same/redone. The rooftop was closed.on my day.

When in Poissy a visit to Villa Savoye is an absolute must. The villa is a magnificent example of the simplistic and yet very functional design by Le Corbusier.  The villa is worth visiting not only ftom outside but especially from inside. Visotors have access to most of the rooms, including the terrace.

Made it to Villa Savoye on a hot day and it was all worth it! The lines and spaces in this house are unwavering and it is a visual masterpiece. It was also interesting to notice the architectural problems of the house. Overall it is an informative field trip.

Though I studied architecture & architectural history many years ago I certainly couldn‚Äôt forget Villa Savoye.  If you have any interest in architecture or modern art it is worth a detour which we took on the way to the Loire Valley.  Unlike many buildings‚ÄîVilla Savoye looks better in person than in photographs. JUT DO IT and stop here!!

This iconic modernist villa, on the outskirts of Paris, designed by the architect Le Corbusier, and built in 1931  is representative of the origins of modern architecture and is one of the most easily recognizable and renowned examples of the International style. Oh and it‚Äôs beautiful too.

Villa Savoye is a masterpiece of modern architecture. Designed by Le Corbusier, it perfectly embodies his vision of functional beauty and minimalism. The clean lines, open floor plan, and integration with nature are truly inspiring. It's a must-visit for architecture lovers. The staff was welcoming, and the information provided about the villa's history was insightful. Highly recommend!
An authentic castle, a beautiful exposition inside, and the staff is more than helpful

A good example of how a medieval castle would have looked and functioned. The attractive building has many interesting features such as the towers, the clockface, the courtyard and the roof timbers, which can be viewed for a very reasonable entrance price.

It is in good condition and the brickwork is very clean. You can learn about its varied history and how it housed some of the Parisian art treasures during the 2nd world war.

We got there at 12:30pm and they were closed to visitors. It looked good from the distance. I was able to take some far away photos before they realized they didn't close the red gate. I, also, took photos of the church next door.
Such an interesting chateau and quite unlike the better known ones. Wonderful oak beams and superb art works
Very nice visit to a Castle that is not usually commonly visited. Recommended.

Thank you to the wonderful lady who let me take my two small dogs in to enjoy the guitar music today at the chateau. It was a lovely afternoon, a beautiful place, with equally beautiful people looking after it.

Lovely setting, stunning building. 2 floors to explore, quite a small place (for a ch√¢teau?!) Everyone loves a caf√© though üòâ but I understand there isn't enough demand during quiet season. Maybe a coffee machine?
Visited with guide, which was really nice and full of knowledge and lively - everyone was listening
Beautiful renovated chateau with very capable guide

We loved this Ch√¢teau, such great work has been done to restore this beautiful building.
The only improvement I could suggest would be a small cafe.. but this could be said for many Ch√¢teaux.

We finally made it to our most awaited visit! Although, we must admit, we weren‚Äôt thrilled about the bright sunshine. But hey, there‚Äôs a restaurant right there if you‚Äôre in the mood for a quick beer. Overall, the place is pretty good, and the route is amazing. It‚Äôs just 20 minutes from the Marseille Vieux Port, making it a great spot to visit during the summer. The view from the fort terrace is simply breathtaking. You can see the big Frioul Island on one side and the city of Marseille on the other. It‚Äôs always a treat to watch the big cruise ships and small boats passing by. The fort is well-maintained and preserved, and there‚Äôs not much to see inside, but it‚Äôs definitely worth a visit at least once.

Okay, so the Ch√¢teau d'If is this really famous old castle right off the coast of Marseille. The main thing you gotta know is that it's famous because of the book, The Count of Monte Cristo, which used it as the ultimate prison.

King Francis I built it way back in the 16
th
century to protect the coast, but it ended up being this crazy, inescapable state prison‚Äîbasically France's version of Alcatraz.

You take a quick boat ride from the Old Port to get there, and the minute you see it on the island, it looks super isolated. The view of Marseille from the top is awesome, but the best part is walking around the cells. They even have the fictional one for Edmond Dant√®s, which is cool. You learn that if you were rich, you got a nice cell (called a "pistole" cell) with a window and fireplace. But if you were poor, you were stuck in a dark, gross dungeon. It's a total must-see if you love that book or just want to explore a spooky piece of history.

Gorgeous views, a must of you're in Marseille. You take a boat from the Old Port and it takes you to the island. We spent there around 2 hours and grabbed a boat back to the Old Port. The boat ticket to the island was 18eur

If you are visiting Marseille, take some time to visit this historical site. Easy 20 ferry ride from the port and then we spent about an hour walking through the old prison dungeons and enjoying the outdoors with great views.
There is even a cafe to grab a drink before you head back to main land.
Amazing ferry ride out to the Ch√¢teau. Amazing place to visit! Loved the dome at top where the voice echos when you talk. We also loved the old graffiti from the prisoners.

Absolutely incredible castle. A must see, especially as someone who is a huge fan of BBC Merlin. Even if you don‚Äôt know the show the rich history and beautiful interiors are worth a look. Free for under 25s! Great gift shop! Beautiful views!

An underrated castle that I‚Äôve thoroughly enjoyed visiting every time. The surrounding landscape beautifully evokes the atmosphere of the medieval era. The castle itself is stunning, with its grand towers and detailed architecture that instantly spark your imagination.

My second top on the list (Hohenzollern is the first). Definitely must see it. There are not a lot of internal stuff in castle itself - but the building is maintained and well kept - and the tour allows to visit 99% of the castle itself. Exterior is beautiful, interior is maximally interesting for anyone who enjoys historical buildings.

Wow. Just wow. Everyone should visit this place once in your life (at least on your bucket list). Just breath taking, even at night. Has a sort of medevial aura, both on the interior and exterior. Loved every minute of it.

I‚Äôve visited a lot of castles through out Europe. But this was one my daughter wanted to see due to the Merlin show being shot here. And just wow. Truly stunning. The restoration is incredible. It‚Äôs well worth a trip if you‚Äôre heading out or into Calais. The village is also sooo pretty. I recommend driving on the steep road next to the castle and parking up the top where there is a bit of a hidden car park!

Incredible example of 1930s modernist architecture by Mallet-Stevens. The geometric lines, innovative use of materials, and beautifully restored interiors make this a must-visit. A hidden gem that showcases the best of Art Deco design - well worth the trip from Lille center!

This is a fantastic building to visit if you are interested in architecture.  There were very few other visitors on the day we visited, so it was enjoyable to wander around the house and gardens.
The walk to the property from the nearest tram station is lovely and took us about 15 minutes to walk.
There isn't anywhere to grab a coffee or a snack nearby so don't arrive peckish!

A stunning art deco movement building, set in beautiful grounds. This building was left to rack and ruin in the 90's, suffering vandalism and water damage. The government bought it and spent 22m euro's restoring it, and replacing the original lost furniture and fittings with identical copies. A remarkable achievement.

Wow, this place was practically derelict in 2000 but 23M euros has restored it to how it used to be. That extra money has made sure you won't know what is new and what is reclaimed. Certainly the best art nouveau house I've seen ever and I've seen Frank Lloyd Wright's work in Chicago
Awesome house and gardens well with the visit off you like Art Deco and architecture and history or just anything interesting. Pictures can't do it justice.

A splendid monument with an impressive and well-executed concept. The renovation work was top-notch, breathing new life into the space while preserving its character.

The main hall‚Äôs d√©cor was truly stunning‚Äîthoughtfully designed and visually captivating.

The caf√© offered a pleasant atmosphere, and the food met expectations‚Äîsimple and just right.

My only minor critique is that the bookshop felt a bit too small for the overall scale and ambition of the place, though that‚Äôs just a personal observation.

I have been here more than a year ago and sometimes I am still thinking about this museum. Amazingly made. With the temporary exhibition and the main exhibition I did spent around 5 hours in here, without even finishing all, just because it was so good and I enjoyed every room to the fullest.
Big recommendation for everyone who enjoys languages. Take your time :)

This museum came into existence fairly recently (2023). However the ch√¢teau that hosts this museum exists from the 16th century; started by Fran√ßois 1er and designed by some of the same architects that designed the Louvre and some parts of Versailles.
If you're passionate about all aspects of the french language including but not limited to art, history, geography, phonetics, vocabulary, slang, this museum is definitely the place for that kind of immersion. Their website says 2 hours is the average required time but I'd say plan for at least 4 hours if you're the researcher, overthinker type that likes to dive deeper into silly things such as why this painting(cf photo) is titled LHOOQ. Plenty of fun activities to do too.

We took a group of about 15-16 students of ours to an excursion here. Also I just realized how ironic it is that I write this review in English but I guess it's more important that more french learners understand why they should visit; if I wrote it in french, it won't likely reach the beginners.

It's possible to couple this with other nearby Ch√¢teaux (Pierrefonds for example) and a picnic in the nature.

Absolutely proud and delighted! üåêüá´üá∑ I had an amazing experience at the Cit√© Internationale de la Langue Fran√ßaise.

The reception was commendable, we were perfectly guided, and a guide in English was suggested. üëè

The place is adorned with new and high-quality elements, and the restoration of the Ch√¢teau de Villers-Cotter√™ts is truly admirable. üè∞‚ú®

The interactive activities provided a comprehensive understanding of the history of the French language. It's fascinating to witness how French resonates globally. üó£Ô∏èüåç

With a visit time of 1.5 hours, it's a perfect stop during your visit to Villers-Cotter√™ts. However, I wish there was more focus on French outside of France; this part felt a bit rushed for my taste. Still, a definite must-see!

Excellent new museum/exhibition with all displays in French/English/German. Children and those of all other ages well catered for. Lifts are present so easily accessible. Free car parking nearby. Small cafe on site but remember no re-entry yo exhibition/museum if you want a coffee or snack during your visit. Buildings have been magnificently restored.
Great beach for walk8ng / kite surfing and sun bathing ..waves quite big when swimming / few rocks to left more sandy to the right

Fascinating house and garden. Very calm feeling being there. Not a lot to see but fascinating to see how Clemenceau lived. He claimed he was France's first Bhudhist.
Be sure to download the app which I only noticed on the way out. It brings each room to life with actors.
It was a treat for me especially to chance on this place as on my cycle tour I am reading Paris 1919 about the Versailles Treaty
Not very crowded, accesibile   but a bit rocky.

Loved everything about our trip to la maison de Clemenceau. Wonderful to visit a French historic site so well preserved and well maintained that it really gave you a flavour of what it would have been like to live there and why Clemenceau chose this particular spot. On a beautiful summer's day, free parking - fantastic!
Friendly staff but quite a small garden. Don't come expecting Giverney.  Pamphlet is in English but not the descriptive boards in the house.
Admission price was reasonable, a few interesting rooms and a beautiful view of the French alps.
Pretty cool monastery. The views are spectacular, and the actual monastery is, meh. If you've never been, it's worth a trip, but if you're short on time, I would skip it.
nice place, you can walk almost everywhere, enjoy the garden, etc
Very nice, great views, not so big , worth a visit

Haven‚Äôt been since 2017 but was telling someone about this place.  Getting here on the train is such an experience it‚Äôs amazing - the walking around this beautiful town is not for those who don‚Äôt like hills

The Chapelle Expiatoire was one of our favorite sights in Paris. This small chapel was built by Louis XVIII to commemorate the place where Louis XVI and Marie Antoinette were unceremoniously buried, after their executions. A small altar in the lower section shows the exact spot the King‚Äôs body was recovered.

It's an interesting and solemn site of where many royalists died. Its also interesting how it writes and frames things focusing on the supposed tragedy with the events also being the basis of modern french identity.

Price is low and it's worth a look to complete a look into the revolutions; a fine hidden gem if you can withstand some monarchist leaning notes and visitors.

Can‚Äôt express how much I love this place. It‚Äôs totally beyond expectations! Petite indeed but tranquil and offering a sense of serenity. And I actually like the story of Marie-Th√©r√®se Charlotte. Bringing a book or a sandwich and sitting in the surrounding park on a sunny afternoon is highly recommended. Oh, the staff are just kind and polite. I really did have a wonderful visit!
Beautiful space! Seven euros to get in. Note: they close for lunch.

I read some of the comments on Google Maps that criticised the money paid for the little there seemingly is to see. Well, some of the reviewers weren't clearly paying attention. This is a place for contemplation and a place full of significance for a period of the history of France and Europe when enlightened monarchs saw their authority questioned and died at the guillotine. The importance of the place is further added by the fact that only in the early 20th century did the authorities finally put aside the idea of having it demolished. The architecture, the symbolism, are both beautiful.

Although I don't know much about architectural styles, I know about this palace that it fascinated me.  The beauty of the facade of the inner courtyard simply takes your breath away.  I went to visit it on a Thursday morning, I don't like it when it's crowded, I love to admire these beauties in peace.  The price was ‚Ç¨8.  Although there is not much furniture in the palace rooms, it makes up for it with architectural details that are amazing.  I couldn't wait to open the next door and be amazed by the beauty that surrounds me.

This is quiet unique and huge. It was a private home. But the owner was even richer than the king. And exact that's it how it looks - posh.
But the selfguided tour, I recommand the audioguide for 3‚Ç¨, is it worth. The rooms are mostly clean, but some are really nice painted or have wooden ceilings. You have to climb a bit stairs, but take your time. I spend 2 hours, but 1 hour is absolutely makeable to see all rooms. If you want deeper info to some points the guide has a green button, I didn't used it, but its surly your chouceüôÇ.

Exquisite palace, big and lavish. Unfortunately only sad thing is that you can see architecture and building materials but all the rooms are very empty, some places have a few furniture items, some only pictures of objects, so the space seems too unoccupied, other than that it is a marvel!

The rooms aren't decorated with furniture and art. However, for us, we felt it would have distracted us from the real gems of the palace. Which is the architecture and carvings. You need to look closely to spot some of the carvings.
Definitely worth a visit, really well conserved and interesting. I've enjoyed It a lot!

Well worth the 4 euros to visit the cloisters.  Do take the information leaflet and read it as you go round.  There is some amazing architecture on show however it is rather bare in the upper rooms.  Be aware it is not accessible by wheelchair or pushchair as you have to ascend a narrow spiral staircase.
Interesting but short visit.
Simply Amazing!
Top

Aberta de quarta a domingo das 14:00 √†s 17hs. EU$ 5.00 pp. Antigo claustro aberto a visita√ß√£o, fica dentro das depend√™ncias da Cath√©dral St-Gatien. Na Idade M√©dia e no Renascimento, La Psalette era uma escola de m√∫sica vocal anexa a uma igreja, onde os jovens recebiam um alto n√≠vel de educa√ß√£o musical e religiosa. Desde o in√≠cio da Idade M√©dia (s√©culos V a X), o claustro foi o local de trabalho dos c√¥negos da Catedral de Saint-Gatien. No final do per√≠odo medieval, o cap√≠tulo, tamb√©m chamado de assembleia de c√¥negos, experimentou grande atividade cultural gra√ßas √† sua oficina de c√≥pia de manuscritos, o scriptorium, e √† sua biblioteca, que era ent√£o uma das mais ricas da Fran√ßa. Tr√™s galerias ainda existem hoje. Na esquina das galerias norte e leste, uma magn√≠fica escada em espiral d√° acesso ao andar superior. Ela se abre para o exterior atrav√©s de grandes janelas. No interior, um n√∫cleo conduz o olhar at√© o topo do parafuso, que termina em um teto artesoado.

We came to the castle very spontaneously.
Tourist guide was so kind and nice, she tried to speak with us in English and made very interesting excursion in the castle
It‚Äôs very old and beautiful castle with interesting history. Beautiful paintings on the walls. Recommend to come when sun is not goes down because it‚Äôs different to see details inside. But make excursion very mysterious.
In the end of castle they have small shop with souvenirs

Great location. The chateau looks very good. There are no real gardens and the interior is sometimes lacking furniture. However for the price they ask, it was worth it. The guide is very knowledgeable and the paintings on the walls are great. The gardens cannot change as there is no place for them anymore, but I think the furniture can still improve but overall this was a very well done chateau.

We traveled a long way specifically to see this Chateau. We checked the website which said it closes at 5.30 at this time of year and last entry is at 4.30pm. We arrived just after 4 (using toll roads to get there early) and found the Chateau closed. When I finally located someone they said that the last visit was at 4 and we could not enter. It may have been quiet but they should stick to the advertised opening times. Very disappointing and a waste of half a day and petrol! If you plan on going ring ahead.

I saw the sign of the Ch√¢teau on the road and was like ye I am gonna visit that. I am glad I did so. Since I was there at the opening, I was in the first tour, and because I was the only one then, the young lady did the tour in english  and it was just great. (I am really thankful that you did so)
Beautiful castle with a friendly French guide. Guided visits only.

Another amazing Chateau that although it is largely unfurnished it still manages to showcase the historic homes and vast wealth of nobility. It's no longer in private hands it is owned and maintained by the nation

Having read the article in a French magazine I felt I must visit. 3 hours is too long it's probably 2 hours to immerse yourself in the building and its contents as the southern wing is under refurbishment and so the rooms are closed. The cost makes it a MUST visit yet I was disappointed in the contents.

I reviewed this castle 10 months ago, and gave it 4 stars for the reasons listed below. However, it comes to mind more often than any other place I went to in the Loire Valley and I think of it when I visit house or castles in other countries because it really is one of the most impressive places I've been to. For that reason, I've upped it to 5 stars.

I loved the castle rooms without the furniture because you can appreciate the space, walls, floor and ceilings so much more. Many other castles have furniture. We basically had the place to ourselves which made it special too (I don't think it gets that busy during the week in September). However, I would agree with comments from others:
1) Where is the information about the rooms? There are leaflets available but they focus on the art in the rooms rather than going into more detail about the original space.
2) you've got to like contemporary art, but actually it didn't detract from the visit for me.
3) where is the information about the owners? There is some, but I think it could be better.
In spite of that, definitely go. It's really worth it. They have picnic tables inside too.
A surreal place; so creatively executed and a unique twist on a traditional Chateau visit. Come with an open mind and a willing imagination. Worth the visit.
Beautiful Chateau and grounds and showing contemporary art exhibitions.
Cool Abbey with a nice history. Surprised at how influencial it was over the years. Audio tour worth getting though it's a little clunky.
Beautiful Abbey. The 3D displays and movies show how splendid this Abbey has been. Audiotour recommended

Used to be the center of Christendom. Mostly ruins, but still lots there to see. Amazing digital recreations of the Abbey. Never really understood that until the 1400's this was the largest cathedral in Christendom - much bigger than St. Peters of that day. A combination of religious politics and the reformation in France changed all that. Much of the Abbaye was destroyed during the reformation. The digital exhibit expertly guides you through the transformation of the Abbaye over time.

We visited with group. I overheard our group head talked to receptionist and found that we can come for free (I think there is certain condition people who can come for free).
So please check before you buy a ticket.

The monastery is huge. Located in old town.
For renting audio, it costs ‚Ç¨3
If you have single jack for earphone, bring it! It‚Äôs easier to hear the audio and you don‚Äôt need to hold the audio like you are in the middle of calling someone :))

Unfortunately in many area there is no information at all.

Going there was not super planned for us on our holidays. But it absolutely was worth it! The place is spectacular. Super big with nice explanations and visuals on how it looked once it was build. We were really in the atmosphere of medieval period !
The tour was fascinating, thanks to our guide... Absolutely do the 3:30 p.m. tour (longer) but which will take you to places that are inaccessible... I highly recommend it
A piece of history, a tip, take the guided tour, it's so rich that we stayed there for hours.
Visited on August 17, 2025. Magnificent cloister with a beautiful treasure room. Not to be missed!
Magical and relaxing! This cloister, inspired by Romanesque architecture, is a haven of peace in the heart of Puy-en-Velay ‚ù§Ô∏è

A lovely cloister, with traces of different eras.

It's a shame there aren't a few flowers in the center of the cloister.
And it's too hot in the treasure room, so we don't really want to stay and look at the works on display (there's little light, for preservation purposes, of course, but sometimes it's really more than just light).

Fantastic visit where we've been under the spell upon arriving in this well-preserved village, with its small Sainte-Anne church and its red-tiled roof and then, just a stone's throw away, the large gates of the property ... At the end of the courtyard behind the round flowerbed and its large tree, the house: we visit successively on the ground floor, the dining room where the table is always set and where Chopin, Liszt, Balzac, Flaubert, M√©rim√©e, Delacroix, Alexandre Dumas fils sat... By the staircase and the corridors decorated by Maurice Sand, we go upstairs: the cabinet of curiosities, Chopin's room that George had transformed into storage after their break-up, the blue room with walls and hangings with Louis XVI medallions, where George Sand lived her last moments. Finally, Maurice's small theater where people enjoyed playing and singing on winter evenings.  A true treasure trove for all fans of the author and of Fr√©d√©ric Chopin, who composed a large part of his work here. Don't forget to pay your respects at the author's grave...

I went here in 2022, but never left a review on it. However, here it is now as I've remembered.

5 stars because of the beautiful scenery, history, and overall peaceful vibe of the place. There are just a few things to keep in mind if you are a foreigner. (Well, much like me.)

FOR THOSE PLANNING TO GO:
1. They don't really speak English
2. Getting here is a bit difficult, as the language barrier kinda gets worse and worse, but it's definitely doable.
3. If you join a tour guide around the house, she (at least in our case) will not speak English.
4. You CAN get your own copy of George Sand's published works!
(SIDENOTE: To get to Nohant in the first place, you will be dropped off in the middle of a field, with a small sign. Nohant does NOT have a big entrance to the town)

OVERALL: Should you go?
If you are a fan of Chopin and George Sand's lives together, yes. However, it is also best that you look up Sand's children, Solange And Maurice. Just knowing their backgrounds will be useful, and will make your expereince better.

If you aren't a fan of Chopin and Sand,  you might find it boring. (The blue room in the pictures below is Sand's room, where she died.)

I was fortunate to be taken here by my local guide and enlightened regarding the life and legacy of George Sand. I visited this beautiful site and grounds in 2024 and thoroughly recommend it. The tours are in French, and as my abilities in French are elementary at best, there is an English brochure they will lend you to carry along on the tour that gives the background of each room on the tour. Truly a fascinating monument worth a visit if you find yourself in Central France. Merci!

Stunning location stunning house. Downside is you get a tour of the house in French which is absolutely epic... hard if you don't speak Frenchand you be  then be standing around for an hour and a half.  I don't understand why they not let you just walk around or at least have an English guided tour.  The marionette exhibition upstairs bookshop is free. Closed between 12 and 2   restaurant opposite little church has an amazing tart tartin but is very expensive. If you go on a Thursday the little cafe in the house grounds has a nice affordable menu.

Beautiful tour, but there should be some assistance in terms of written guide in English or other languages so that someone who doesn't understand french can follow and enjoy the tour as much as anyone else.

‚Ä¢	A Gothic masterpiece: Built between 1242 and 1248 by King Louis IX (Saint Louis) to house precious Christian relics ‚Äî including the Crown of Thorns ‚Äî Sainte-Chapelle is one of the finest examples of Rayonnant Gothic architecture.
‚Ä¢	Unforgettable stained glass: The upper chapel features 15 towering stained-glass windows, each over 15 meters tall, illustrating more than 1,100 biblical scenes. When sunlight filters through, the entire space glows in a kaleidoscope of reds, blues, and purples ‚Äî an experience visitors often describe as ‚Äúspiritual‚Äù or ‚Äúotherworldly.‚Äù
‚Ä¢	Compact yet awe-inspiring: Unlike sprawling cathedrals, Sainte-Chapelle is intimate. You don‚Äôt just see it ‚Äî you feel it envelop you in color and light.
‚Ä¢	Central location: Located on the √éle de la Cit√©, next to the Palais de Justice and a few steps from Notre-Dame, it‚Äôs easy to combine with other major Paris attractions.
‚Ä¢	Historical significance: As the private royal chapel of the French kings, it represents both religious devotion and the peak of medieval artistry.

‚∏ª

‚ö†Ô∏è Things to keep in mind
‚Ä¢	Crowds and queues: Sainte-Chapelle is small and extremely popular ‚Äî lines form early, and the chapel can feel packed, especially mid-day.
‚Ä¢	Security checks: Entry is through the Palais de Justice complex, so airport-style security applies. Arrive early to avoid delays.
‚Ä¢	Limited visit time: The experience, while stunning, is short ‚Äî most visitors spend about 30‚Äì45 minutes inside.
‚Ä¢	Lighting conditions vary: The stained glass looks best on sunny days (late morning to mid-afternoon). On cloudy days, colors appear softer and less vivid but still atmospheric.
‚Ä¢	Lower chapel first: The entrance leads you through the modest lower chapel before you ascend to the breathtaking upper chapel ‚Äî don‚Äôt rush; the contrast enhances the reveal.

A Breathtaking Masterpiece of Light and Color!

Sainte-Chapelle is one of the most stunning sites in Paris ‚Äî truly a hidden jewel of Gothic architecture. The moment you step inside, you‚Äôre surrounded by a dazzling display of stained glass that fills the chapel with radiant light and color. Each panel tells a story from the Bible, creating a sense of awe and serenity unlike anywhere else.

The upper chapel is especially mesmerizing, with its towering windows and intricate details that make you feel as if you‚Äôre standing inside a jewel box. Don‚Äôt let the long line discourage you ‚Äî it‚Äôs absolutely worth the wait.

Even after visiting the grand cathedrals of Europe, Sainte-Chapelle stands out as one of the most unforgettable experiences. A must-see in Paris ‚Äî peaceful, spiritual, and breathtakingly beautiful!

Visiting Sainte-Chapelle was honestly one of the highlights of my trip to Paris. It‚Äôs tucked away on the √éle de la Cit√©, inside the Palais de Justice complex, so from the outside it doesn‚Äôt look like much. But the moment you walk upstairs into the main chapel, it‚Äôs breathtaking ‚Äî the entire space glows with color.
The chapel was built in the 13th century by King Louis IX, who wanted a special place to keep religious relics, including what was believed to be the Crown of Thorns. Knowing that history makes the place feel even more meaningful.
There are two levels inside. The lower chapel is peaceful, with painted arches and golden stars on the ceiling, but it‚Äôs the upper chapel that truly amazed me. The walls are almost entirely made of stained glass, and when the sunlight shines through, the whole room is filled with red, blue, and violet light. It‚Äôs one of those moments where you just stand still and stare ‚Äî photos don‚Äôt do it justice.
I went in the late morning on a sunny day, and the light was perfect. It can get a bit crowded, but the atmosphere is still very calm, almost spiritual. The visit doesn‚Äôt take long ‚Äî maybe 30 to 45 minutes ‚Äî but it stays with you.
If you‚Äôre already visiting Notre-Dame or the Conciergerie, it‚Äôs just a short walk away and definitely worth it. Sainte-Chapelle isn‚Äôt big, but it‚Äôs unforgettable.

I would say it is the most beautiful church I have seen. Starting with a small and less light at the below church which is in vivid blue color, walkinh through a little staircase to go up. Then suddenly we are in a brilliant space, over scale of human height ceiling, and the most magnific is all the mosaic glass which tells the stories of the bibel.

Small notes:
- You still need to be in the queue even booking the ticket before, 30-45mins.
- Sercurity check as air port
- the shop gift inside will make you spend money a lot :))) as they have many nice stuffs
- Enjoy all the small craving details also

I just got back from visiting the Sainte-Chapelle, and I'm still trying to process how breathtaking it was. Honestly, pictures and videos don't do this place justice‚Äîit's an experience you have to see for yourself.

The first part is the Lower Chapel, which is beautiful with its vaulted ceilings and deep blues, but it's really the Upper Chapel that steals the show. As soon as you walk up the narrow stairs, you are enveloped by light. The walls are almost completely replaced by 15 enormous stained-glass windows towering 50 feet high.

It feels less like a building and more like walking inside a giant jewel box. If the sun is shining, the whole room turns into a kaleidoscope of color‚Äîyou can see centuries of biblical stories painted in vibrant light. It‚Äôs an incredibly moving and serene spot, and easily the single most stunning architectural sight I‚Äôve ever seen in Paris. Do yourself a favor and make sure you go on a bright, sunny day if possible!

Very beautiful Cathedral located at the centre of the city. I visited morning around 11 am and they have the vibration music playing continuously. It feels so good to sit and pray. Even if we don‚Äôt pray it‚Äôs a very calm place to meditate. The church is very beautiful.

Extremely beautiful church! Huge and with nice information inside! They have a shop as well as some brochures for more information. It is a must for people interested in French history and Gothic architecture. You cannot miss the Marc Chagall's piece of art!

A true masterpiece of Gothic architecture, the Cath√©drale de Reims captivates visitors with its soaring spires, intricate stone carvings, and breathtaking fa√ßade. Inside, sunlight streams through stained-glass windows of multiple colors and designs, casting vibrant patterns that tell stories from history and scripture. Every corner reveals centuries of craftsmanship, from the delicate arches to the detailed sculptures. Whether you are drawn to architecture, art, or history, the cathedral offers an unforgettable experience where light, color, and stone come together in perfect harmony.

Historical & Legendary Cathedral
This is one of the oldest Cathedrals in the world. It witnessed the crowning of Kings in the Middle Ages and was always an amazing beacon of faith for the Catholic Church.
It is currently ongoing a bit of renovation but still looks fabulous.
If you come to Reims you will see the Cathedral it is the absolute one and only building you need to see visit.
We were also very impressed by the inside the ceilings are so high that they give you this feeling of Grandness-
ABSOLUTE must see !

Notre Dame was the most stunning cathedral that I've ever had the pleasure of seeing. It was beautiful inside and fill with relics and beautiful artworks. It was an awesome experience. If you ever have the chance to see go there do so.
Beautiful and not busy, lots of interesting facts about when it was built, the prison and the school. Very interesting! And cheap to go
A great place to visit. Imposing, beautiful and interesting

We visited the castle on a rainy day. The building is impressive and the story behind the castle and its original owner is interesting. Well worth a visit on a rainy day when there is not much else to do or wine to taste.

A hidden gem worth finding. Tapestries hang in almost every room. They are magnificent & have been well cared for. The walk through the castle is highlighted by English & French descriptions. Children will also enjoy the fairy tale themes.
Well worth visiting and the good news is everything was in French, English and Spanish, so you could read and enjoy the rich history
Cloister next to Bayonne Cathedral. Beautiful and harmonious architecture. Peaceful and quiet. Free entrance.
A very relaxing place.

The cloister of Bayonne Cathedral offers a true haven of peace in the heart of the old town, just steps away from the local bustle. Built between the 13th and 14th centuries on the site of an earlier Romanesque cloister, it boasts beautiful Rayonnant Gothic architecture. Access is free and open daily, with opening hours varying by season, making it perfect for a tranquil visit.

Free and quick tour of the cathedral cloister ‚õ™. Beautiful architecture, peaceful and pleasant to discover while passing through Bayonne. A little extra would have been to have a nice, well-mown lawn to make the place even more charming üåø

The cloister itself is very pretty, offering very photogenic views of the cathedral, and for that alone, it's worth the detour.

However, the idea of transforming it into a tourist market, with stalls selling knives, cutting boards, etc., is deplorable in my opinion, even if I'm not religious at all.

As a result, it's packed with people who don't even look at the place...

I was unable to enter  the house as it was not ‚Äòdog friendly‚Äô, so my time was spent walking around the grounds. Certainly worth the visit to only do this.
Grounds in pristine condition and obviously well maintained.
Excellent footpaths and clearly signposted.
I myself have mobility problems, but would recommend the grounds for disabled access/wheelchairs.

Beautifully well preserved and furnished ch√¢teau, with knowledgeable and friendly guide. Going back for sure for the special guided visit of the grounds! I highly recommend. Ch√¢teau guided tour 8‚Ç¨, but you can visit the beautiful grounds for free, and have a picnic there in the warm seasons.

A visit to Ch√¢teau de La Motte-Tilly is like being a guest of some very pleasant, if unfamiliar people. Here you will be told about the life of the house, the objects that have come out of use, the people who lived here or are depicted in the portraits, and the old print books (as if just to keep you occupied while dinner is being served).

This is the atmosphere that the last owner, marquise de Maill√©, wished to preserve at the castle. In the early 1970s, she transferred the estate and the park of over 1,000 hectares to the French State as she had no direct heirs left.

This was a perfect solution to preserve the interiors and furnishings that the marquise and her father had spent dozens of years on (re)creating and not let history repeat itself at the end of the 18th century when, following the death of the manor's founder, the last Minister of Finance under Louis XV, and the ensuing Revolution, the castle fell into disrepair for more than a century.

Now this mid-18th-century "hunting lodge" together with the park makes a very pleasant impression, so I think Colin Firth and Milo≈° Forman spent a wonderful time here in the late 1980s working on the film "Valmont".

Beautiful castle and grounds. The tour of the castle itself was very informative and personal. We really loved strolling around the grounds. Also, it is not at all busy and very peaceful. I will go back.

A beautiful small ch√¢teau just outside Paris. The buildings and grounds are kept well. Entrance to the grounds is free and it only costs ‚Ç¨8 to see inside the ch√¢teau.
We saw orchids and cowslips amongst the many small flowers that cover the cut grass.

Lovely abbey, worth a visit.
The guided tour was only in French though. Not a big issue, but would've been good to know upfront. We left the tour and enjoyed walking around the abbey
A beautiful village and very peaceful. Well worth a visit. Lovely food at the restaurant there.

Visited the abbey several times in the past years. It is a beautiful place. Last time (in 2018) we got a tour in the abbey church by one of the monks. It was very interesting. The museum shop has moved in another building. The monks sell self-manufactured tableware, religious books and food. The buildings are in good shape. The bell tower Saint-Nicolas is impressive. It's definitely worth it to participate in a guided tour. Have to speak French though.

A calm, serene place with an extensive abbey and a magniificent tower.  It is in a beautiful setting enclosed by a lovely stone wall with a twin-towered entrance. Parts are still in use and part is being restored.  Well worth visiting both the abbey and the village
Le Bec Hellouin. Free parking for Motorhomes. Abbey very beautiful as is scenery around. A lively place to visit

The location and buildings are beautiful. There's a cafe with inside and outside seating. The art is not to my taste but is displayed in various sized rooms and there are also rooms explaining how the abbey has been used over time. A lovely place to visit. No wheelchair access to upper floors, where the bulk of the art is.
An interesting example of how an abandoned abbaye was renovated to house an art collection.  Beautiful gardens too and place to relax.  It lacks just a small cafe for refreshments in the garden.
Beautiful abbey, so peaceful and magnificent in its simplicity! Lovely rose garden and a visit to the fish pond to see the swans is a must!

Fascinating old building.  Very simply renovated, with the twist of modern art.  Read the info on what to look at inside on the website, significance of the images on the ceiling.  Very beautiful. Worth driving too.
Magical place, beautiful church and garden. It's also a modern art museum. There are free guided tours three times a day with an emphasis on the paintings. The entrance costs 6  euros.
Great visit today, our guide gave us an English translation.  He certainly was passionate and informative.  Nice renovation going on during our visit, well worth the admission costs.  Thanks so much.

Really beautiful castle! The tour was entirely in French with no papers to read so we missed basically anything about the castle while there, but the rooms were stunning to look at. The castle grounds were very overgrown and not taken care of so just be aware if you‚Äôre expecting a leisurely walk afterwards. The playground opposite the castle was a highlight for our kids for a picnic lunch
Beautiful interiors, very nice garden.
Nice palace. But working hours not suitable for tourists. Just few dalys per week and only for big groups... O
The guided tour is in French or in English (unless some of the visitors are French).

Thoroughly enjoyed our hour long audio tour through the apartments and salons of this renovated piece of history. The audio tour had snippets of what happened on the rooms rather than describing each piece of furniture. If you aren‚Äôt able to go to one of the larger chateaus outside Paris, or just want easier access to a bit of historical grandeur, this is a nice choice. It was a pleasant change from the busier museums. I thought the price was too high though for this smaller place. I was disappointed the special exhibit of the Sheik‚Äôs art was not available, but the price was the same. I loved the terrace overlooking the place de Concorde.

This has to be one of the most underrated attractions in Paris. Very beautiful, significantly less crowded, and free audioguide provided. People travel all the way to Versailles to see something like this, when in Paris, you can easily see it too at Hotel de la Marine.

Reservation recommended. The audio guide experience at H√¥tel de la Marine is fantastic! Each visitor receives their own headset, with many language options available. As you enter each room, the audio automatically plays the corresponding story and introduction. The narratives are vivid and engaging, with immersive background sounds that make the history and daily life truly come alive. Highly recommend this experience ‚Äî it really adds depth and atmosphere to the visit!

Excellent use of an audio guide for visitors. They obviously put a lot of effort into that system. Note that they have time slots so you might have to come back later. Don't miss the outdoor walkway looking onto Place de la Concorde. They have some chairs and it was nice to sit and watch for a while.

Interesting concept, the headset given to visitors is kinda cool. This is a historic building on Place de la Concorde. Originally built in the 18th century as royal furniture storage, it later became the headquarters of the French Navy for over 200 years.

Today, it‚Äôs a beautifully restored museum where you can explore elegant salons, hidden chambers, and get a glimpse of French history and craftsmanship. Plus, it offers some great views of Paris from its balconies. :)

Can't go inside the big building, but there are small entrance everywhere around where you can go in the little rooms. It's nice to see. Nice n cool in the basements so even on a hot day It's a nice place to see and visit.
Very well preserved fortification from the 15th century. Great way to learn about the past and the war between France and Spain. 10/10

Very interesting visit for those who enjoy history and old architecture. The fort is very well preserved and the staff was kind. The bonus was the gazing sheep ‚Äî an environmentally friendly lawn mowers who made great sounds with their bells as they were walking by.
The place looks impressive, but there is no English explanation and you need to walk around with a French speaking guide.

A huge fortress, powerful walls, and an incredible number of different routes inside. The guide speaks a mixture of French and Spanish, but surprisingly, you understand everything. The services of a guide are included in the ticket price and it is definitely worth joining the tour, since you can only get to the upper floor with a guide. I recommend it!
Very well preserved and beautiful garden.
Very charming Little castle!

Small castle but very nicely furnished, gives a good idea of how it used to be. The pigeon tower is the biggest in the area and a nice asset on site to visit.
Also the garden is well maintained and offers a nice short walk. Worth visiting when in the neighborhood.
A small but a good place to come to plus and some good views from around the garden area and in the place itself, a good place to come to and see when in the local area.
Amazing ch√¢teau with a rich history and amazingly well preserved portraits and furnishing. Well worth visiting.

The tour itself is bad, but the interior is fine. The price is around 8 euros, I think, and it's worth it because it also includes climbing the cathedral tower. The tour is only offered in French, and they give you a poorly translated brochure. Some paragraphs don't even match up with the one before or after, so I took the tour and explained that I didn't understand the language but was interested in seeing the crypt. They agreed. The guide knew I wouldn't pay attention and would just be taking pictures. So if you're going to take the tour, tell the guide about that, because they make some really awful faces! The crypt is beautiful; only remnants of its former splendor remain. It's incredible how great treasures were lost in France due to its wars, and this was no exception. Here in the crypt, we can see the first crypt of Romanesque origin, where the relics of Saint-Etienne were displayed in their heyday. We can also see the remains of a Renaissance burial, the recumbent effigy of the Duke of Berry, as well as the tombs of numerous archbishops and some fragments of the famous screen dating from the 13th century, which separated the choir and the nave. I insist, it's worth going inside and seeing it, but the tour itself and its explanation are not worthwhile.
