There is not much to see and can only be visited with a very boring French guide. The guide only spoke a few words of English when selling the tickets. You can also make do with a brochure containing a few poorly translated sentences that make no sense. The French guide recites entire texts while the brochure only says: "twelve large window openings provide light" (I had noticed that too!!).

Save yourself the trouble! Look at my photos and videos, light a candle in the church and buy a cup of coffee or even a glass of wine for the entrance fee.
A very interesting tour of the crypt of Bourges Cathedral. Full of details about the construction of the building, its evolution over time, and all with a lot of humor.

The crypt tour is interesting, well worth it.

Beautiful view from the tower. On the way up, the guide takes several breaks, which is appreciated given the 396 steps.
On the other hand, no explanations are given, whether about the cathedral, the tower itself, the city, or the skyline. For ‚Ç¨7, it's expensive. Especially since the guided tour of the crypt costs ‚Ç¨8, which, thanks to the information provided, is much more understandable.
Big disappointment, it's not a crypt but rather a lower chamber... it's expensive for what little there is to see.

Great site and much larger than expected. You can get a real understanding of Roman life from the ruins and printed leaflet (in English). Worth spending an hour or so on site visiting. You might be able to park outside the Saint Paul de Maisole hospital for free (as the car parking opposite is expensive).

Incredible place to come spend a couple of hours learning about the 3 civilizations that lived in the area 2000 years ago. Small paid parking lot or you can take a long walk from town. Starts off near the parking lot before you go into the paid area with the arch that you can see starts the road into the old town. Get tickets at the reception center/gifts shop and opens up to an awesome area of ruins. Take the trail to the left first and it will loop back. We got the handheld speaker to help explain a bit more and it was definitely worth the 3‚Ç¨ for our small group. However, there‚Äôs a lot of good info posted around the ruins in French, English, and Spanish if you don‚Äôt want to pay for the speaker. Make sure to hit the viewpoint at the end of the route that comes back down to the trail back to the start. Good for the kids, especially the ones with an interest in Roman history. There is also a little cafe inside the area and picnic area out front.

A good set of Roman ruins with a nice visitors' center.
Not as spectacular as others you can find, but still very interesting. A nice add on to a visit to St. Remy.

Loved our visit to Glanum. Visitor center is well maintained & staffed with knowledgeable people. We got the audio guide which explains everything you‚Äôll see with clarity. Fascinating place, well worth the stop for a couple of hours.

Easy access and plenty of nearby parking, there is a short walk to the ticket office and gift shop. There is a restaurant ready to take your order and provide an amazing picnic. Don't forget to bring your blanket this place is very relaxing with exceptional breezes and plenty of sun.
Visits possible only if you call ahead

A magnificent castle, not for its furnishings as it's empty, but certainly not for its Italian-inspired paintings, including the murals and those on the ceilings of the staircases and landings.

The timber frame is also worth seeing.

It's a shame that some people have "amused" themselves by "carving" their initials or drawings on the walls.
The roof has been recently restored, and the paintings are now safe.
Beautiful castle with magnificent frescoes. A person explained the entire history of the castle to us. Entrance is inexpensive.

Beautiful castle restored by the state and therefore part of the national heritage. The guided tour was of great value, the guide was knowledgeable, exceptional in explaining all its paintings and of course the building, a must see!!

We had an excellent time with the guide, who has worked here for 18 years. The magnificent castle boasts numerous unique and remarkably well-preserved murals and ceilings. The "grotesque" style of painting is fascinating in its detail. A must-see! Telephone in advance, otherwise, no visit. Closed on Mondays.

The fort and the abbey are separate tickets, which is lame, and the abbey is closed on certain days, so we didn't get to visit both which was a little disappointing. The fort does offer nice views at least, and there are many historical things to see. To get here is a lot of uphill walking, and many of the stairwells in the fort are very steep and narrow, so be careful with your footing.

Built in the early 14th century by order of King John II the Good of France, this military fortress was strategically constructed to guard the border between the French Kingdom and the Papal territory of Avignon. Enclosed within its massive stone walls are the remains of the Abbaye Saint-Andr√©, a medieval garden, residential quarters, and watchtowers. It‚Äôs a hidden gem that blends military history, peaceful nature, and panoramic views. From the northern watchtower, visitors can see the Pont d‚ÄôAvignon, the Rocher des Doms, the skyline of Avignon, and the silhouetted peaks of the Alps to the east.
Note: The abbey ruins can be accessed with a separate admission.
‚Äª Included in the Avignon City Pass.
It always feels nice to visit a forteresse and feel the vibes of the times. There was a nice view one sid Avignon otherside Villeneuve d,Avignon
One  the best castles, great grounds and displays and the cries over Avignon, well worth a visit

The abbey is beautiful and it's a peaceful walk around the grounds. Incredible to see ruins from 1000 years ago. The fort side is incredible as well, exhibits and walking along the wall is an experience that is hard to beat. Incredibly peaceful place, kind workers, only complaint is it's a bit expensive. 8.50 per person

A very warm welcome from the tour manager.
Guided tours available.
The house is easily accessible and located in the heart of Tr√©guier.
The interior is magnificent, especially Ernest Renan's study.
Beautiful garden.
Small but very cozy museum, I recommend not wasting too much time and visiting the medieval streets of the town

This museum, the house and garden of Mr. Ernest Renan, is a wonderful surprise.
The tour begins with a video, where you are seated to discover his life, his work, and his contemporaries.
An interesting, fascinating, and rich discovery. Throughout the video, you will discover his work and the impressive number of personalities he encountered throughout his life, most of whom you know.
A very warm welcome awaits you. A little extra: the museum created and made available a spiral-bound document in Braille and French simultaneously, and you can also discover in relief the details of the facades, decomposed elements, and other objects from his life.

We happily discovered the "small town of character" that is Tr√©guier and, sincerely, we loved it! It's really a pretty town: the houses blend in very well with each other and the cathedral is magnificent... One last piece of advice, if you can, go to Tr√©guier on a Wednesday: it's market day and it's extraordinary.

A great surprise, I didn't know the character yet very interesting, the visit of the house and the gardens were fabulous, the explanatory video at the beginning is very well explained arousing interest and taking us more into the visit! In addition we were very well received, a real pleasure, I recommend!

Beautiful cathedral of Chartres. They made beautiful renovations, everything is really clear and neat.

Even with clouds and no sunshine, the inside is bright enough to see through the painted glasses of the windows. They are marvelous piece of art.

If you have the chance to be in the area, you should take the time to walk there and look for yourself how gigantic and stunning it is.

What actually surprised me the most is how modern they are inside. They have contactless payment card machine for donation at each corner of the cathedral. So if you don't have coins like me, you can still use your card to pay to lit a candle or novena.

The hours of the priest are written on a card board inside.

The confessional is brightly litten and has a priest waiting inside for anyone who wants to confess theirs sins. This is unseen for me before today in France.

There is also a treasury room which you have to pay to access it.  Overall a great place to visit.

I advise to park your car at the parking lot of Cathedral. There almost non existant place to park there.

A Stunning Journey Through Time: My Review of Chartres Cathedral
Nestled in the charming town of Chartres, just southwest of Paris, France, the Chartres Cathedral (officially known as the Cathedral of Our Lady of Chartres) stands as an awe-inspiring testament to medieval ingenuity and faith. This Gothic masterpiece, a UNESCO World Heritage Site since 1979, draws visitors from around the world with its soaring spires, intricate sculptures, and unparalleled stained-glass windows that seem to glow with divine light. If you‚Äôre a history buff, architecture enthusiast, or simply someone seeking a profound cultural experience, this cathedral should top your list.
Construction began in the 12th century after a fire destroyed much of the previous Romanesque structure in 1194, with the current form largely completed by 1220‚Äîa remarkably swift timeline for such an ambitious project. Measuring about 130 meters long and with towers reaching up to 115 meters, it‚Äôs one of the best-preserved examples of High Gothic architecture. The facade alone is a storyteller‚Äôs dream, adorned with over 2,000 sculpted figures depicting biblical scenes, saints, and everyday medieval life. As you approach, the asymmetrical towers‚Äîone flamboyant and ornate, the other more restrained‚Äîcreate a sense of dynamic balance that pulls you in.
Stepping inside is like entering a kaleidoscope of color and light. The cathedral boasts 176 stained-glass windows, covering nearly 2,600 square meters, most dating back to the 13th century and miraculously surviving wars and revolutions. The famous ‚ÄúBlue Virgin‚Äù window, with its vibrant cobalt hues, is a highlight, symbolizing the cathedral‚Äôs deep Marian devotion. On a sunny day, the interior transforms into a symphony of reds, blues, and golds filtering through the glass, casting ethereal patterns on the stone floor. Don‚Äôt miss the labyrinth etched into the nave‚Äôs pavement‚Äîa 13th-century pilgrimage path that visitors can still walk today, especially on Fridays when the chairs are cleared.
From a visitor‚Äôs perspective, Chartres offers an immersive experience that‚Äôs both educational and spiritual. I recommend joining a guided tour, such as those led by experts like Malcolm Miller (or using his book as a companion), to decode the symbolism in the windows and portals‚Äîit‚Äôs like unlocking a medieval code. Many travelers rave about spending hours here, mesmerized by the details; one recent account described it as ‚Äúbreathtakingly beautiful‚Äù with ‚Äúmagnificent Gothic architecture‚Äù that leaves you in awe. Entry is free, though donations are appreciated, and climbing the north tower (for a small fee) rewards you with panoramic views of the surrounding countryside. It‚Äôs easily accessible by train from Paris (about an hour), making it a perfect day trip. Just note that restoration work, ongoing since the 2010s, might occasionally obscure parts, but it ensures this gem shines for future generations.
In a world of modern wonders, Chartres Cathedral reminds us of humanity‚Äôs capacity for beauty and endurance. Whether you‚Äôre there for the art, history, or quiet reflection, it delivers an unforgettable punch. I give it a solid 5 out of 5‚Äîabsolutely worth the pilgrimage!

If you are only in Chartres for a few hours spend them visiting the incredible and Architecturally astounding Cathedral. Being the first UNESCO awarded and supported further by the volume of original  stain glass. If able to stay for the evening the light show on and around this Cathedral and the surrounding Chartres centre is highly recommended.

An excellent holy place in the heart of Chartres, our lady of Chartres Cathedral is a must visit. You can visit during the day for prayer and tourism and during the night for an exquisite laser show.
Enjoy...
Unbelievably beautiful cathedral! Have seen quite a few in my lifetime but this one was special. Beautifully restored and not too busy. Loved the inside even more than the outside.

Jaw dropping piece of human history. 60,000 years of use, with amazing art work and living spaces that really give you an insight into how our ancient ancestors lived through the ice age.

The guide was very kind to summarize the key points in English (but I don't think there's any guarantee of that). They do however have some brochures you can read in English beforehand. Still, knowing some French will definitely help you get the most out of it.

Absolutely loved it!  Our guide for the day was fantastic.  Her knowledge and enthusiasm really made the experience top knotch.  Unlike some of the more well known caves in France such as Chauvet or Lascaux, you actually get to experience the real cave.

A small but interesting site to visit if you‚Äôre in the area. It‚Äôs close to Citadel de Blaye and makes a great diversion.
The caves themselves are small but fascinating. You can see real carvings of prehistoric animals (not just copies).
The staff were friendly and helpful. I had read that the guide only speaks French but our guide gave a very passionate and interesting overview of the caves and their history in English (there were also some leaflets in English to help bring the experience to life).
Well worth a visit.

A bit disappointing at first, when you see that the whole experience is basically one room. However, as the guide immerses you in the story and shows the multitude of engravings, you get a clear picture of what life was like, 32 000 years ago, even 60 000 years ago. Bonus points for the guide's enthusiasm!

Guided tours, in French, only. Our guide spoke a little English to help us understand the main points she was making. Some of the drawings are very difficult to see even with the guides laser pointer.

Built on a falaise overlooking the Ailette valley in the 13th century, the ch√¢teau de Coucy once boasted the largest keep in Europe, 55 metres high. It was renovated in the 19th century by the architect Eug√®ne Viollet-le-Duc.

Sadly, in March 1917, the retreating German army dynamited the keep and the towers in each corner of the castle. Today, the ch√¢teau de Coucy is nothing more than a ruin, but a magnificent ruin, well worth visiting.

Loved it! Very interesting history of construction & destruction, with lots of information written in French, German & English (and guide books available in many more languages). Great views, as well.
Didn't go inside, walked around the walls. Paths were ok, but difficult for someone with mobility issues.

Huge castle ruin, which you can explore. The remaining structures are well prepared, a lot of signs in french, german and english explain you the history of this castle! To explore the whole complex we needed 2 hours... It was very interesting!

Steeped in history, four towers blown up by the Germans in 1917 but enough to see still. Excellent guide boards showing what it looked like. Underground areas to explore. Great place to spend a couple of hours

One of my most exciting discoveries in the region. The ceiling of this small, 14th century monastery is decorates with small painted wooden elements showing scenes from everyday life, religion and imaginary beings. There is a short video played in of the side rooms that explains about these, I highly recommend to start with that as there is no other explanation given and might be hard to understand what you see there.
Also visit the church with 5th centiry baptistry!
It‚Äôs small but beautiful. Did not mind to pay 7 euro entrance fee

The cloister was very interesting, but considering the 6‚Ç¨ of ticket, the people working there could be more attentive... For example, saying than in a few minutes an included explanation would start... Our experience was seeing by ourselves the cloister and when we were interested in the baptistery, then the guy said to us "run because my colleague is about to finish her explanation there" and when we arrived, we were quite ignored. Curiously, she was the same to sell us the tickets.

Sincerely, you can go for free to the cathedral and see the baptistery from a glass door (paying or not). We understand that the cloister's gem needs maintenance and they make us pay a ticket, but I am not sure if that price is worthy.
This is an old monastery. For 6 euros you could wander around inside, but it is not too interesting.
Refusing entry to a 3 year old to use the bathroom. Incredibly bad

Once in a lifetime experience. Lots of walking as you would expect if you wish to reach the top. Cobblestoned streets wind up to the abbey. Many spots to stop along the way and plenty of photo opportunites. Hard to describe the layout as you walk down and the up then down again on parts. The terrace level has amazing views. Shops are expensive as you would expect in a tourist lication. Our tour from Paris gave us plenty of time to explore. Highly recommend!

I visited Mont-Saint-Michel Abbey alone, which I had long wanted to do.
It was truly wonderful and inspiring.

The biggest issue in my life is my own death and the death of a loved one, which I will experience someday.
I wanted to deepen my consideration about it, so I visited Mont-Saint-Michel Abbey and prayed silently.
As I walked around the Abbey, I thought about this issue.
Although I have not found an "answer" about this issue, the experience of praying at Mont-Saint-Michel Abbey gently enveloped me.

This experience is a treasure of my life.
I will never forget it.

May God bless all the people of the world!

Legendary & Iconic Cathedral
This is a must visit for all history & or Architectural fans. This place is very unique in the world and is a must see site. It is not so difficult to get too but of course you have to check the timing of the tides, etc.
Once you are here expect to climb a bit. Specially if you want to visit the church. This place is beautiful and is one of the highlight of your visit to France.
Try too the local food is is absolutely fabulous!

Even after finalising the itinerary, I always keep one or two days extra whenever I visit any place.
Because you may 'discover' something interesting later that you may want to visit üòé.
Mont Saint Michael was one such place that I 'discovered' when I was in Paris.
The visit to the Mont took the whole day (12 hours), but it was worth it. üòä
I had booked the day tour with the 'Paris City Vision' tour company.
And everything about this Fairytale Castle on a tidal, magical, holy island turned out to be awesome.....a perfect blend of natural and man made beauty.
From the car parking area, which was about 2.5 km from the walkway bridge to the Castle, shuttle buses were available, although you can walk all the way if you want.
Carrying an umbrella did help ‚òÇÔ∏è as it was hot and sunny.
During the French Revolution, the Castle was nationalized, and monks who had settled here as early as 966 CE were expelled.
The Castle also served as a prison for some time.
However, after the celebration of 1000 years of its foundation, some monks again moved in and started residing in the Castle.
So there does exist a very small French commune here; with a mayor, priest, postman, and police !
The bay of Mont Saint Michael, covering an area of about 500 square km, boasts of the highest tides in Europe, and those who want to experience the tides can plan their visits accordingly.
Be prepared to climb lots of stairs.
The steep winding street of the Castle is lined with many shops and restaurants, so don't forget to taste the classic Mere Poulard omelet here üòã.

Mont-Saint-Michel is a unique medieval island-town with narrow streets, covered galleries, fortified walls and an abbey at the top. You can walk through the cloister, step into the gardens, see the bay from different levels and watch how the low tide fully reveals the sandy seabed.
Tickets for the abbey can be taken in advance on the official website or bought at the entrance. Free shuttles run from the parking area to the island, and there is also a convenient pedestrian walkway along the causeway.
During the day you can clearly see the details of the old town and the vast bay; in the evening the abbey is beautifully illuminated ‚Äî a completely different impression. The climb to the top is quite steep, but absolutely worth it: the views are truly impressive.

This is an absolute MUST VISIT.

The house is a good visit but there is not tons to see. Worth going in if you want to see some beautiful rooms. There are also a few buildings in the grounds you can visit with the ticket.

The grounds are the stand out. Incredible views, walks, they are so well kept. You could spend hours wondering around, soaking up the sun, having a picnic, playing games etc.

You can also rent various things for decent prices. E.g rowing boats, bikes, tandem bikes, little carts etc

The grounds are free and are worth the trip from Paris or anywhere really. 10/10 recommend.
It‚Äôs a very beautiful and big castle with huge park. Went there with friends and family. You can rent the bikes and golf car to check the park.

Beautiful gardens to stroll all day long.  The guides showed exceptional ability in providing additional direction.  The chateau itself was beautiful but needed a little TLC.  Not as crowed as Versailles, which makes it more family friendly.  Had a great hot chocolate with whipped creme in this charming french town.

From the minute we walked into the park gardens and then saw the chateau we knew we had picked a good one.  The gardens were very tidy and quite large with a beautiful water feature surrounding.  The outside of the Chateau is very picture postcard and inside didnt disappoint either.  You only get access to the first floor and one room on the basement level.  There are some beautiful floors - tiles and parquet. l;ots of interesting informationon boards to read on your way round.  The local authority gave the owners some money to help with restoration but it now is in desperate need of a new roof.  Anything that is given is going towards that.  You can see the effects of some slight water damage on walls so I hope they manage to get this fixed before the damage becomes more extensive.
We walked up to the Dauphins Dairy a separate building built for Marie Antoinette.  It was OK.  Not a great deal to see inside.
Then we walked ujp  to the shell house which was amazing.  E verwhere on the walls and ceiling is covered entirely with shells of all different kinds.  I thought it must have taken ages to do but apparently it was all done within a year.
Would recommend a visit to this place if you are nearby.  Wished Id taken a picnic!!
Worth visiting. If you like Versailles then you most likely would appreciate this other ch√¢teau and its environs.
Definitely worth a visit. Good value. Beautiful gardens.

Lovely Ch√¢teau. Definitely worth a visit. It's free to walk round the gardens and moat. Also free to walk round the inner courtyard. Toilet facilities are available.

If you wish to view the Ch√¢teau internally there is a small fee to pay.

Parking is plentiful and free, as is most French areas in this region of France.

Wonderful spot to visit.
Surprisingly interesting, if you're around you should try to get to see it

This is a beautiful place to visit. The grounds are stunning. We went on a tour of the castle and information is provided in both French and English. This used to be a guided tour but now you can walk around at your leisure.

There is visible renovation being done to the roof and walls which makes the castle even more impressive.

Suitable for all ages, its a place I would return too.

This is a 'wow' Chateau !  We actually packed in the wonderful Parc next to it, but the Chateau does have a large carpark with no height barrier. Entrance into the Chateau is ‚Ç¨7, but the grounds/gardens, inside square, and a hunting rooms are free. The rooms are all furnished beautifully,  and each room has information in both French and English.  The guides are extremely helpful, and the elegance of the Chateau transports you through history to a time of wealth and servitude.  It was very much by chance we chose this particular Chateau to visit, and we're so pleased we did, well worth a couple of hours. Little gift shop. Toilets. No refreshments.

My wife and I stayed in Villefranche for a month. The woman who we rented the apartment from in the Old Town area of the city recommended we take a trip to see The Trophy of Augustus. There is so much history in this place, you can almost feel the generations over the eons brush past you as you tour the grounds. One of the coolest things we did was to take the steps up and actually stand on a number of observation spots to see just how grand and how massive this monument the the founder of Rome and the conqueror of the Apline people really was. It sits right above Monoco looking down into the harbor and out to sea. Truly spectacular vistas. On the way up you can also see Eze which is another spectacular place to visit, shop and eat. The Trophy also has a small museum, but it is well worth the time. Everything is in English and you can go through every small exhibit in about 30 minutes. It really helps put some perspective on how old this monument is, and what was entailed in restoring it partially. It is purposefully left partially exposed so you can see what was used to build it. We highly recommend you take the time to visit this out of the way experience. Stunning views are wrapped in history. A perfect combination for anyone who loves beauty and history.

Marvellous place, hidden Augustean gem in La Turbie. The museum is also very well structured, and the view is breathtaking. The woman working at the information point was gentle and very cultured. I felt emotional to come here, as an big fan of Ancient Rome.
I would‚Äôve loved to have visited this place, but all the doors seem to be closed.

An extraordinary place, well worth a visit. The panorama from there is breathtaking with views over the whole of Monaco. The monument itself is well presented and allows close inspection, you can even climb up to a high viewpoint.
Did not respect the opening hours displayed at the entrance. Anyway, not much to be seen inside as everything has been renovated and lost its authenticity.

A must see location if you are interested in Romain history and archaeology. Very frienly receptionist who spoke also english.  The informationsigns at the locations are in french, english and dutch.
The locations are quite impressive.  You realise the size of the buildings when you walk through te locations. There are lovely places where you can sit on a bench. We walked (and sat) almost 2 hours there. Cost are 6 euro for an adult.
A 5 star location!
The thermal area is well conserved, with the structure of the swimmingpools, the theather and the temple are very deteriorated. Maybe 1 hour is enough for the visit.
We went for the opera. It was just stunning. What an idyllic location for such a extravaganza
Historically interesting and well maintained
Very nice, beautiful location. Good explanations and well laid out

Not my first time in Paris, but I‚Äôm surprised I only discovered today that you can actually climb the Arc de Triomphe. Enter through the underground passage ‚Äî much safer than crossing the roundabout ‚Äî and today being Sunday, entrance was free, which was a great bonus.

It was raining on and off, but that didn‚Äôt take away from the experience at all. In fact, reaching the top was the highlight of the day. The 360¬∞ views of Paris are incredible, and seeing the Eiffel Tower from above feels completely different from seeing it at street level.

For anyone visiting ‚Äî even if you‚Äôve been to Paris multiple times ‚Äî going up the Arc is absolutely worth it. It offers a fresh perspective on the city and some of the best photo spots you‚Äôll find. Highly recommended.

„ÄêQuick Summary„ÄëA spectacular view of Paris at night! The illuminated Arc de Triomphe and the sparkling Eiffel Tower view from the top are absolutely breathtaking.

„ÄêPurpose of Visit„ÄëPerfect for an evening visit, especially for night view appreciation, right after checking in on your arrival day.

‚úÖ Experience (Highlights)
After a flight from Tokyo, we checked into the hotel around 4 PM and headed straight to the iconic Arc de Triomphe.

* ‚úÖ The View from the Arc: While the illuminated Arc de Triomphe itself is grand and full of charm, **the Eiffel Tower's sparkle illumination (Champagne Flash) seen clearly from the top of the Arc is truly unmissable.**
* By visiting during the transition from dusk to night, we enjoyed a complete panorama: the grandeur of the Arc, the lights along the Champs-√âlys√©es, and the dazzling sparkle of the Eiffel Tower.

* ‚úÖ Final Impression: I believe everyone who witnesses this view will fall in love with Paris. It was a magical moment‚Äîthe highlight of a perfect Parisian evening.

The Arc de Triomphe is absolutely worth going up. The climb is a bit of a workout, but the view at the top makes it more than worth it. Looking out over the Champs-√âlys√©es and the Eiffel Tower is astonishing, especially at sunset.

The atmosphere at the top is surprisingly calm compared to the busy traffic circle below. It also has a romantic feel to it, and it‚Äôs a great spot for a proposal or a special moment.

It's a dream come true being able to actually see and touch it in person. We visited Paris on Bastille Day, so there was a ceremony where flowers was lying down. I was able to climb the Arc de Triomphe where you can see Paris city's. You can also see Le Champ Elysee which is  a very popular street in Paris. Beautiful place

Visiting the Arc de Triomphe for the first time was truly amazing. Standing beneath this monumental arch, I could really feel the weight of history and the beauty of its design. Every carving and detail tells a story, and being there in person made me appreciate it so much more than just seeing it in pictures. Climbing the 284 steps to the top was a challenge, but absolutely worth it‚Äîthe view of Paris stretched out in every direction, with the Eiffel Tower standing tall and the Champs-√âlys√©es looking endless. The view was breathtaking and made the whole experience unforgettable. It‚Äôs one of those places that captures the magic of Paris in a single moment.

Beautiful gardens year round and free to walk around the entire property. Right in the heart of the city it can easily be made part of a day walking tour just visiting landmarks. Guided online tours let you download audio information that you can use as you're exploring.

Even in the metropolis of Paris, the Domaine National du Palais-Royal is a very mysterious place.

Especially when you visit the Domaine National du Palais-Royal at twilight, you feel as if a magical time is about to begin.
I feel as if historical figures and actors of the past are emerging from the pillars.

What a mysterious and poetic place!
Very unusual, have been to Paris loads of times and never knew it was there. 5-minute walk from the Louvre, beautiful gardens and very peaceful, nice for photos

The Palais-Royal is a historic palace walkable near the Louvre Museum. Besides the stunning view of the palace, it has perfectly maintained & peaceful gardens complete with water fountains.  The tree lined path is one of Paris‚Äôs most photographed iconic spots. Surrounding the garden, you'll find beautiful boutiques, cafes, and shops. In the courtyard of the former palace, they have these beautiful black & white striped columns which was installed by an artist. Very iconic & great for photos. Worth a visit to see the gardens, palace & art installations you don‚Äôt want to skip!
Love this place!  Located just behind the Louvre yiu need to stop and have a look. You won't be disappointed
Interesting house, furnished as of 19th century. It feels like to walk in a house where the owner stepped out for a couple of minutes.... Worth a visit if you are in the neighbourhood.
Original

These are Balzac's memories. When he was in debt, creditors would wait for him in front of this house, so he would lower his voice and blow out the candles. Victor Hugo would visit it, and it later became Gambetta's house. This man has a lot to do with our history. He lived and died in this house (I thank the manager who showed us around; she is very kind and friendly). This house is part of our history.

This house of illustrious people is worth a visit...and it's worth taking a guided tour...A dive into the life of Balzac and especially Gambetta....you are 2 steps from a pedestrian entrance to the Parc de St Cloud. Easy access by Transilien and/or bus....

The Maison des Jardies, or Maison des Illustres, is a residence located in S√®vres in the Hauts-de-Seine department. It was originally a winegrowers' house, then transformed into a country home for Parisians seeking a return to nature.
Balzac lived in a nearby chalet from 1838 to 1840. After being removed from power, Gambetta occupied it until 1878, when he died at the age of 44. This "secular saint" is the object of an annual pilgrimage by the government, as well as by many foreigners. A charming, comfortable little house with a lovely garden.
I recommend the guided tour. The guide is charming and friendly. He knows his stuff well.

Great Chateau
This is a great place to come and see where Voltaire lived and understand a bit more about this great writer & philosopher. The location itself is in a beautiful park and is really worth visiting. Highly recommended if you are in this region.

Definitely a hidden gem. We were staying close by and enjoyed the visit to Voltaire‚Äôs estate. The local lady (guide?) was very informative and provided interesting aspects of life in France during the 18th and 19th centuries. The lower/basement level is converted into a sort of small museum on the influence of mystique and fairies introduced in French society of the time
Interesting country house to visit on the outskirts of Geneva. The interior feels more like a museum than a house
Not much to see inside besides few sculptures of him. Great choice of excerpts of his writings that explains his revolutionary different philosophical views.

Very beautiful chateau! The manor is well maintained.

Booking via agency is much cheaper than booking on its website. Very reasonable price for each peaceful place and for 2 hours visit, no crowds on Saturday.

Staff are also super friendly! It would be nice if they have a terrace cafe in the future!

For exhibitions there are not too much interesting things to see but the organisation definitely makes an effort to entertain visitors.

What a unique church! First at church, then a monument to Napoleon, then a church again. The Corinthian columns and interior like nothing I‚Äôve ever seen in a Catholic Church before. Trust me, I‚Äôve been to a lot of Catholic churches.  I was so happy we finally made it to this Parisian landmark.

Oh boy!
We had no idea what this was, as we just saw it on our first walk through the city after arriving.
Such an impressive piece of architecture on the outside, it turned out to be the most beautiful church I've ever been inside of.
Unbelievable and well worth the 10 minute stroll around.

A very iconic church located right in the heart of Paris, standing as one of the city‚Äôs most spectacular landmarks. Its grand architecture and intricate details make it impossible to walk by without stopping to admire it.

The atmosphere around the church is peaceful yet powerful, with a sense of history and artistry in every corner. Whether you‚Äôre visiting for its religious significance, architectural beauty, or simply to take photos, this spot is undeniably captivating.

It‚Äôs one of those places where you can‚Äôt resist taking a picture ‚Äî the structure, lighting, and surroundings all combine to create a scene that perfectly captures the charm of Paris.

La Madeleine is imposing looking on the outside and serenely beautiful on the inside. This large Roman Catholic church houses a relic of Saint Mary Magdalene and is not to missed. No tickets or reservations needed, but be mindful it is an active place of worship. Highly recommended.

La Madeleine is truly one of the most impressive churches in Paris. Its grand architecture, inspired by a Roman temple, makes it stand out from anything else in the city. The interior is stunning ‚Äî peaceful, elegant, and filled with beautiful details that reflect both history and artistry. It‚Äôs a great place to take a quiet break from the busy streets around Op√©ra and Place de la Concorde.
Whether you‚Äôre visiting for its architecture, attending a concert, or simply passing by, it‚Äôs definitely worth a stop.

If you're into exploring the great (and lesser) cemeteries of Europe, you won't go wrong by adding this to your list. It's a lovely walk and the cemetery is filled with notable artists, authors and entertainers.  I had some trouble connecting the location of burial sites with the map located at the entrance but, if you have time, it shouldn't matter (they're not going anywhere :) )

A must do .  An insightful walk through French history . Many famous authors scientists politicians, have memorials here.   The architecture of the memorials is amazing , reflecting monumental art of that particular era.
It‚Äôs also peaceful and reflective . Above as the frantic city traffic races by, and people revel in the streets of Montmartre , here below people that once did those very same things rest eternally.
The contrast to Myself couldn‚Äôt be more poignant.

The Montmartre Cemetery left a deep impression on me. Walking among the resting places of so many renowned individuals, artists, writers, and thinkers was both humbling and thought provoking.

It reminded me that no matter how high we rise in life, we all eventually return to the same stillness. There‚Äôs something powerful about standing in the presence of history, where greatness now rests in quiet dignity.

The cemetery itself is peaceful, shaded by trees, and full of character. It‚Äôs not just a place of remembrance, but a quiet space for reflection on the impermanence of life and the legacy we leave behind.

Peaceful and quiet wandering among famous and less famous tombs. Quite amazing plot under a bridge. Do not miss the serene monument dedicated to two famous French singers Michel Berger and France Gall.
Interesting vibe, one of a kind place. It also features some known figures like Degas or Juliusz S≈Çowacki

I visited Place Vend√¥me during Christmas, and the atmosphere was absolutely magical. The holiday lights and decorations made the whole square feel festive and elegant. It‚Äôs surrounded by plenty of luxury boutiques, so it‚Äôs a great spot if you enjoy high-end shopping or simply want to stroll around and admire the beautiful window displays.

A stunning place to visit during the holidays ‚Äî refined, lively, and full of charm. Perfect for a Christmas walk in Paris!

Place Vend√¥me is a grand 17th-century square in Paris lined with elegant fa√ßades and luxury boutiques. Its central Vend√¥me Column, inspired by Trajan‚Äôs Column, beautifully commemorates Napoleon‚Äôs victory at Austerlitz. A compact but iconic spot blending history and prestige.
Jewelry stores galore and you can‚Äôt beat the classy Christmas decor in the square around Napoleons pillar.

Place Vendome is a gorgeous square in the heart of Paris that used to be known as the Place Louis-le-Grand and the Place International. It was started in 1698 as a monument to the armies of Louis the 14th.

The impressive Vendome Column sits in the centre of the square. It is a tall column with Napoleon standing on top depicted as a Roman Emperor. The column was built by Napoleon to honour the battle of Austerlitz and torn down during the Revolution. It was eventually rebuilt and still stands here today.

Our bus tour stopped here at night and I definitely recommend checking it out at night if you can. The quaint street lights and classic design are a sight to see. The legendary Hotel Ritz Paris surrounds the square and it is absolutely stunning when lit up. A gorgeous and historic spot to check out when in Paris.

This is an absolutely amazing square. All the buildings encircling the square as gorgeous and lavishly ornate. There is a column commissioned by Napoleon inspired by the Trajan Column at the centre. These days it is a centre of hi-end fashion brands.

Beautiful and magnificent. A little abused due to the age but worth the visit. Impressive confessionals, tableaus and architecture. The history is definitely recommended to be read. You may find homeless men sleeping around the outside of the building but with proper care and being vigilant this doesn't pose a threat.
This gothic church definitely warrants a visit when in the area, the small entrance opens up to a huge vaulted ceiling space, quite nice just walking around the pews taking it all in.

I happened to be staying nearby and decided to wander in. To my pleasant surprise, there was no admission fee or wait to get in. The main reason I‚Äôm leaving a review is that I was truly overwhelmed by the beauty of this church. Despite visiting many other churches including St. Chapelle and Notre Dame, this one really stood out to me. It was one of my most memorable experiences while visiting Paris. I highly recommend visiting here to see the amazing architecture and sculptures.

We accidentally stumbled upon this incredible church in Sept, so when I found myself back in Paris in Jan with my boys, I had to bring them here.  This is 1 of the most beautiful churches I've ever been into & I make it a point to go into every church I possibly can, wherever I visit.  It's right next to The Louvre, so if you find yourself in that area (& who doesn't when visiting Paris), then I absolutely recommend this gem.   It's truly spectacular & well worth the time.  In fact, every time I visit Paris, I will definitely visit here.  It's free to visit & you can purchase candles to light inside via cash, apple pay or Google wallet.  Even if you aren't spiritual,  there's something about being in these beautiful,  historical places that is just magical.

Saint Germain l'Auxerrois, Paris France
As per architecture design this is so beautiful church
Beautiful heritage church with elegant architecture and timeless design in the heart of Paris.

Clearly a church trying to create real community and serve the needs of church-goers and neighbors alike. It's a super-traditional service in some ways (old hymns) and a super-progressive one in others (strong themes of racial and social equity).
A very spiritual and loving church‚Äîblessed to have found it.

I visited while I was in for the month studying. I don't even have words for what a great experience I had. One of the best messages I've had the pleasure of being in for. If you're a student, this is absolutely worth the trek and worth your time.

It's also a beautiful building.
It's an amazing church with beautiful sermon and extra nice community. Also the band at the 2pm sermon is the best!

We did a wedding here and it was absolutely perfect! A grand and breathtaking church in the heart of Paris. Perfect for couples dreaming of a stunning French ceremony. Our bride really felt like a queen, stepping outside with the public cheering for her as they exited as newlyweds. She's not the queen - but she celebrated a real royal wedding in Paris. Vive les mari√©s!

Where Christopher wren was inspired to build st Paul's cathedral.  Over refurbished altar which though dramatic rather kitsch

This church attached to military hospital interesting building some good photographs. Worth a visit but you need official identification.

Interesting building for its history, the old "Cit√© Sainte" located on "Petit Bourbon" on the way to the old road to Saint Jacques de Compostelle. The chapel is inspired by St Peter in Roma. Some great paintings by De Champaigne are there too.
I wanted to provide photos here. I did not go in.

Good baroque church but the highlight for us was the military medical museum.  Fascinating variety of ww1 gas masks and stretchers as well as Napoleonic and present day exhibits.  NB you need you passport or an ID card to gain admittance.

This mosque was incredible and is a must visit for anyone that comes to Paris. It is well kept, the gardens are beautiful and there is a cafe adjoining, which is not to be missed.

There is a real sense of community by those who use this mosque, which was beautiful to see.

The mosques architecture is sublime, with influences from Morocco - you feel transported to another land.

a very nice place to relax, explore, and enjoy. this place reminds me of alhambra palace but with more color and more like a place to rest in the middle of busy paris! everything are so well-designed and well-preserved, other than praying one thing you need to do is taking lots of pictures here, ü©µ

If i have one word to describe the mosque, it is an oasis. A place where you can rest your soul and recharge your spirit after those long walks around Paris. The building itself felt old in a classic and good way. An arabic architecture that remind you of classic building of andalus you often see in the history book. Calm inner yard, immaculate garden and dark wood ornaments from the floor up to the dome. The main prayer room a bit small compare to the rest of the building, but it is still impressive and probably can hold up to 500 people. The mosque itself is just one part of the complex, there are a couple of institute and also a restaurant attached to its complex. The mosque is also open for non muslim visitor that want to absorb the tranquility of the building and its surrounding. It is such a treat to be able to pray in this mosque. Hopefully you'll be able to visit it too someday.

The Grand Mosque of Paris is a serene and culturally rich gem nestled in the heart of the French capital. Built in the 1920s as a gesture of gratitude to Muslim soldiers from French colonies who fought in World War I, this mosque is both a place of worship and a powerful symbol of interfaith respect and multicultural presence in Europe.

The architecture is inspired by Moorish styles, particularly those of North Africa and Andalusia, featuring stunning green-tiled minarets, carved wooden ceilings, graceful arches, and peaceful courtyards. The central courtyard, with its fountains and mosaics, offers a tranquil escape from the busy Parisian streets‚Äîa place where visitors can pause, reflect, or simply admire the craftsmanship and beauty.

Beyond its religious significance, the mosque also serves as a cultural center. It includes a traditional hammam (bathhouse), a beautiful tea room that serves mint tea and North African pastries, and a restaurant offering exquisite Algerian cuisine. These experiences provide a window into Islamic culture and hospitality.

The Grand Mosque of Paris stands not only as an architectural treasure but also as a beacon of coexistence, spirituality, and heritage in one of the world‚Äôs most diverse cities.

This mosque is truly a sight to behold. The architecture is stunning, and every detail feels thoughtfully designed. What makes it even more special is the serene garden surrounding it‚Äîlush, peaceful, and beautifully maintained. Walking through it feels almost unreal. It‚Äôs a place that leaves you in awe and brings a deep sense of calm. Absolutely unforgettable.
Place de la Bastille is full of life! The surrounding restaurants and especially the Sunday market bring a vibrant energy, in such a striking contrast with the historic events that took place here.

Place de la Bastille in Paris is a very versatile area. The monument itself is a beacon in the city with the tall column with the bright gold angelic figure on top with wings spread wide. The metro station is a major hub that can get you just about anywhere in the city. Lots of restaurants located all around the very large circle roadway along with the Opera.  Market on weekends is great too.

I was in Paris last week and it was a pleasure to visit Bastille and see this beautiful historic monument
A must see when your ever in Paris

My first time to visit a French market and the flea market on the next street.  We had a great time here. We came in at around lunch time and were able to get some food, fruits, vintage pendant, vintage broach and a cute top for my mom. Merchants are nice and be prepared to get out your google translator cause not all merchant can speak English.  Remember you are in their country so at least a little French and smile will come a long way.  I never had any issues with  anyone in France.

Ok, I wasn't expecting the whole construction was stand up, but there are a few stones (they were moved by the way) on a park, and the park is close because they are fixing or something... It took us thirty minutes on the metro to arrived there, it doesn't worth.

The Church of Saint-Roch is beautiful on the inside. We were fortunate to attend Mass here on Easter Sunday. The light through the stained glass windows creates a wonderful atmosphere and the acoustics of the organ are amazing. This is more of a neighborhood church than many of the others in Paris. It is easily overlooked packed in among the other local buildings.

As literally ‚Äúpassing‚Äù passage Saint Roch, my thought wondered around for the possible whereabouts for Rose Bertin‚Äôs ‚ÄúLe Grand Mogol‚Äù (it was supposed to be very close to the church). Getting used to the smell of sewage was very helpful in Paris, yet once I was allowed to enter, Oh the history speaks its own. Is it true YSL had his funeral here? Church of Saint-Roch is a must visit church if you have Jesus in your heart.
The build, architecture, ceiling, and pillars of this church are very unique. The altars arrangement was also quite intriguing. It's worth the visit and prayer.

The Church of Saint-Roch is a hidden gem in Paris, known for its beautiful Baroque architecture and serene atmosphere. Located on Rue Saint-Honor√©, this historic church features stunning altars, intricate sculptures, and impressive artwork. The grand interior, with its high vaulted ceilings and peaceful chapels, provides a tranquil retreat from the bustling city outside. Notably, the church has strong artistic and historical ties, having been frequented by artists and musicians throughout its history. Whether you're seeking a quiet moment of reflection or admiring the artistry, the Church of Saint-Roch is a lovely and lesser-known treasure in Paris.

A hidden gem in the middle of Paris. Despite being so unkept and badly maintained you can still enjoy the historical and magnificent art that draws you closer to our Lord. It‚Äôs sad to see it‚Äôs deterioration. However, it‚Äôs true beauty still comes across and forces you to imagine of what once was.

The Church of Saint-Sulpice, located in the fashionable 6th arrondissement of Paris, is one of the most significant and largest churches in the city, second only to Notre-Dame in size. Its construction took more than 130 years, from 1646 to 1780, and involved several architects, resulting in a distinctive blend of Baroque and Classical styles. The church was originally built on the site of an older 12th-century Romanesque church.
The building's facade remains unfinished, lacking one of its planned towers, giving it a unique, somewhat asymmetrical appearance. The interior is striking in its scale and austere elegance.
The main treasures inside are the frescoes by Eug√®ne Delacroix, located in the first chapel on the right.
Another unique artifact is the gnomon, an astronomical instrument created in the 18th century to accurately determine the date of Easter. It consists of a copper strip embedded in the floor of the nave and a system of holes in the windows that allow sunlight to fall on a white marble obelisk and a scale on its surface at noon, marking the spring equinox.

Beautiful cathedral, with free entry and offering historic art and peaceful place to sit and rest from the busy parisian street life.
Came during the week around noon, it was not busy at all and offered such a wonderful place to admire art and architectural of the time.
If you're nearby its worth a stop it.

Saint-Sulpice Church is a remarkable historic landmark with impressive architecture and art. I attended mass here, and the atmosphere highlighted the grandeur of the space. A significant place to experience both heritage and worship in Paris.
The church is spacious, historically significant, and less crowded than other Parisian monuments, making it easy to explore its details and artistry.
The largest church in Paris. Both the feeling is very intimate. Beautiful Delacroix paintings in the side chapel. First class relic of St Faustina. Peaceful and contemplative.

Not sure why but I was a little overwelhmed by the experience. It's impressive in size and architecture but there many cathedrals that compare. But there was something about the visit that was different in an emotional way for me on that day. Anyways, if you are nearby then take the opportunity. It's worth the time. It's free.  It's accessible.

I can see how these gardens are beautiful. Unfortunately we came in the rugby world championship and everything was torn apart. Aside from that there were parts that were very beautiful and sculptures placed in so you can be there to admire them. Definitely a place to relax in a big city!

During a walk of the area, consisting of the Arc de triumph and the the famous Champs √âlys√©es, this is the perfect place for us to stop for lunch, there is the bestest vegetation, tunnel, to shelter from the rain with seating, tourists seem to miss it.

Lovely castle worth visit. I recommend to buy audio guide too. Overcrowded however it's well organized at the entrance. It's good to buy a ticket online with a time slot in advance and then just go straight to the entrance skipping all that huge queue in front of ticket office.

Jardin des Champs-√âlys√©es is such a peaceful escape right in the heart of Paris! Beautifully landscaped with elegant fountains, sculptures, and tree-lined paths ‚Äî it's perfect for a relaxing stroll or a quiet moment away from the busy avenue.

The Arenas of Lutetia are one of the rare surviving traces of Roman antiquity in Paris: the amphitheater was built in the 1st and 2nd centuries AD, when the city was called Lutetia and was under the rule of the Roman Empire.
The arenas were created as a multifunctional space for gladiator fights, theatrical performances, and public gatherings, and they could accommodate up to fifteen thousand spectators.
The arenas of Lutetia were partially destroyed in the late 3rd century, around 275 AD, during the Germanic (Frankish and Alamanic) raids on Lutetia, and they were never rebuilt. They were subsequently abandoned and remained hidden beneath the city for a long time, until they were rediscovered during the construction of the Rue Monge in the 19th century, sparking a wave of interest among Parisian intellectuals, including Victor Hugo, who advocated for the preservation and restoration of the monument.
Today, the arenas are open to the public and serve as a peaceful urban space where you can see the remains of the ancient walls, the stage platform, and the spectator seats. However, much of the structure has been lost, and it would be great to restore it to experience the atmosphere of Roman Lutetia and the fascinating history of its disappearance and rebirth.
The overall impression is somewhat sad due to its neglect and unwelcoming nature. This place deserves proper attention....

Free to visit. The Roman theatre from the first century AD once hosted theatrical shows and gladiatorial contests and could seat 15,000 people. Much of the seating was destroyed and what you can see now is new. But you can still see the huge stage. It's now a city park and easily accessible.
I LOVE ruins! The arena is about 2000 years old and partially restored. It's ideal because it's free, easily accessible, and beautiful. The gardens around the arena are lovely and peaceful.
Hidden gem behind apartment buildings. Lively little ‚Äúplayground‚Äù for all ages. Men playing p√©tanque/boule, children playing, people relaxing on the former seats of the Roman arena
It looks so green and fresh! Amazing!

An urban forest? I'm very skeptical.

The very term "urban forest" is more of a public relations exercise than a tangible scientific reality. With only 470 trees planted in a limited area, this project objectively resembles a dense thicket or an inaccessible square more than a truly self-sustaining forest ecosystem. The term is considered misleading, even bordering on semantic fraud, by some observers in the field (Source: Batirama, "Paris and its urban forest craze," January 21, 2025).

The project's long-term biological viability raises legitimate technical skepticism due to the significant constraints of the subsoil. The presence of underground infrastructure such as the metro and parking garages drastically limits the available soil depth, transforming the area into a complex green roof where the long-term development of large trees remains uncertain (Source: Institut Paris R√©gion, "Urban Micro-forests: Ecological Functions to Evaluate," May 13, 2025).

From a functional standpoint, the change in the traffic pattern, from a roundabout to a horseshoe shape, has created problematic disruptions in traffic flow. The redesign has created discontinuities for cyclists and congestion points for motorists, complicating local transit instead of improving its flow (Source: Isabelle et le v√©lo, "Place de Catalogne: From a Racetrack to a Square for All," November 15, 2020).

Finally, the social utility of the space is questionable since the planted area is protected and closed to the public to safeguard the young saplings. This is an expensive green backdrop to be viewed from afar rather than a usable public park, a limitation of use highlighted during the consultation reports where the legibility of the project and its status as a "forest" were already called into question (Source: City of Paris, "Report of the information day Place de Catalogne", January 4, 2024).

A magnificent urban space recently transformed into a small forest, planted with ferns and various trees.
There is also grass, benches, and mist generators.
The plaza was previously a simple concrete disc, serving as the center of a roundabout that is now partially pedestrianized.
The trend toward eliminating cars from the urban landscape and encouraging pedestrians is welcome.
The "urban forest" is a bit of a stretch, but the trees are growing. The tree-lined center of Place de Catalogue is a pleasant spot for walkers and passersby.

It's a huge waste if it stays like this: the square is now very beautiful and pleasant with its greenery, but the surrounding restaurants and shops aren't keeping up (there's not much life there apart from a very noisy and smoky bar that attracts young people). A comprehensive development plan including all the surrounding shops and restaurants was needed to ensure everything was in sync and coherent. I was expecting pleasant restaurants with large terraces taking advantage of the view of the lovely green square. The lack of ambition, design, and communication is palpable, and it's clear that economic activity isn't taking hold around the square. It's a shame. Things can still change, though; I hope it improves, there's potential there (a local resident).

Incredible historic landmark and tomb! The history of this location is truly remarkable and worth listening to the audio guide you can use with the ticket. I used the free audio guide on my phone, it‚Äôs great. This is definitely worth the visit. The architecture is really amazing, you can‚Äôt help but take pictures. The cross with Jesus Christ is so powerful to witness. The angels of victory around Napoleon are so beautiful and cool. His statue made with marble and gold is so beautiful. This entire location is absolutely breathtaking and amazing to see. Rest in peace, Napoleon! Praise Jesus Christ our Lord and Savior! Be sure to book your ticket in advance online, they sell out fast, and online you can reserve a time slot.

Napoleon‚Äôs Tomb at Les Invalides in Paris is a remarkable tribute to one of history‚Äôs most influential figures. As you approach the magnificent dome, its golden exterior glistens in the sunlight, setting the stage for the grandeur that awaits inside.

Stepping into the tomb, you are greeted by the impressive sight of Napoleon‚Äôs sarcophagus, crafted from striking red quartzite, resting on a green marble pedestal. The surrounding circular crypt is adorned with intricate sculptures and reliefs that celebrate his military achievements, immersing you in the legacy of his reign.

The atmosphere is both solemn and reverent, encouraging contemplation of Napoleon‚Äôs complex life‚Äîhis brilliance as a military strategist and the controversies that surrounded his rule. The museum adjacent to the tomb further enriches the visit, showcasing artifacts and exhibits that delve into his life and the era he shaped.

Overall, Napoleon‚Äôs Tomb is a captivating blend of history, artistry, and reflection. It offers a unique opportunity to engage with the past and gain insight into the man who profoundly influenced France and Europe. A visit here is essential for anyone wanting to understand the intricacies of this iconic leader‚Äôs legacy.

A truly unforgettable experience. Standing before Napoleon‚Äôs Tomb was deeply moving and felt like stepping into history itself. The architecture, the atmosphere, and the sense of significance in this place are incredible. One of the highlights of my entire trip. Highly recommended.

The area in which the tomb is house is so striking, you can‚Äôt miss seeing it from afar and it makes you wonder what it is (if you don‚Äôt already know). The detailing on the dome is incredible and the gold so vibrant, especially when the sun is shining. We missed going in due to time limitations.

There's really no one place to start, as you could begin your tour anywhere in the museum buildings.  Bathrooms are co-ed and unfortunately seem rarely cleaned.

Well preserved relics of man‚Äôs inventiveness & craftsmanship.  Beautiful models of early factories & structures - all displayed in a uniform & considered manner.
Only bummer was the protective glass cases prevented taking good photos.  Had I known the Museum book (highly recommended) was only 18‚Ç¨ - i would have stopped trying!  This Museum may not be for everyone- but any science/technology/engineering nerd will love it.

a really cool place if you‚Äôre into inventions and science. It‚Äôs set inside an old church, which gives it a unique vibe. It‚Äôs well organized by theme, so you move from one topic to another easily. Honestly, it‚Äôs both fun and educational even if you‚Äôre not a total tech geek.

Votive Christian church to thank the Holy Virgin for protecting Paris in 1944. 2 churches brought together in May 1952 and in 1954: a high and a low. Erected following a vow in 1944, and which was to be replaced by an urban plan which was never made. Therefore closed from 1974 to 1988. Reopened with the inauguration of the Robert Debr√© Hospital. On the side: small round chapel which houses the baptistery, as in ancient times when baptisms were given outside; and which also serves as a confessional. Very refined. A disgrace.

I've been a very loyal customer for years, and I've even been making donations to you for every sale for years.

But today you've extremely disappointed and humiliated me in front of all the customers.

I was at the stand in the center and I did my little tour, then a volunteer gave me the receipt to pay.

I paid at the central checkout near the toys and, of course, I went to collect my items, except that the bag she gave me to hold the item was too small, so the item fell and made a noise, so I picked it up and put it back in my bag.

A super-unfriendly volunteer standing at the lighting stand approached me and yelled at me, "You didn't pay for your items." Shocked by this volunteer's comments, I looked at her, but of course, the lady I paid for was the one who billed me.

And then I went back up the stairs, and another gentleman came running to get me, telling me that the lady downstairs told me I hadn't paid.

Outraged, I showed him the paper with "pay" written on it.

And I replied, "It's a disgrace, sir. I paid and I have the ticket, and you continue to call me a thief even though I have proof."

Outraged, I saw him come back with my ticket, and he told me it was fine, and I didn't even look at it and headed for the exit.

I'll never give you another cent, and I'll never give you donations again.

Shame on you!!!

Watch out for those who actually steal instead of attacking the people who actually pay for their purchases.

I thank the parishioners for their welcome on the occasion of a celebration on June 4th.
I told them I was coming from the church across the street [Catholic] and I was welcomed by our Protestant friends; two women offered me something to eat [cherries, watermelons, and many other fruits] by handing me a plastic plate and a napkin. Having seen a little girl trying to give a cherry, I grabbed one from the table, not daring to take it from the little one. The ceremony was a blessing similar to baptism for a child and four adults who had confirmed the blessing they had received when they were children. No Baptist, I asked? No. Indeed, it is not yet baptism when the time comes to give a child a name. I was very happy to be welcomed and informed in this way and will keep very good memories of my visit.

√âglise Saint‚ÄëPhilippe‚Äëdu‚ÄëRoule
This church is located in the VIII district of Paris and has a rich and unusual history. It stands on the site of an old chapel. The construction of this church was carried out until 1784. The architecture is in the neoclassical style. The facade resembles an ancient Roman temple: a portico with four Doric columns, a triangular pediment with a bas-relief and the inscription "Deo Optimo Maximo sub invocatione Sancti Philippi Apostoli".
The interior originally consisted of a straight rectangular basilica with a nave of seven arches, side galleries, and a vault made of wooden coffers. Later, in the mid-19th century, the church was expanded with the addition of new chapels and stained glass windows. The main organ has over 1,500 pipes. Interestingly, this is one of the first Parisian churches designed in the neoclassical style, inspired by ancient temples, and it served as a model for other 19th-century church buildings
What a beautiful. This is just local church with a breathtaking interior design. Everything so clean and it's so quiet and calm. The atmosphere in the church is welcoming .

The art work which most struck me were the painting of Christ being removed from the cross which dominates the ceiling above the altar; and paintings of The Visitation and the Holy Family's flight to Egypt in the sanctuary. I had never thought of the Holy Family fleeing in a boat, which was a charming twist. Also of interest, the plaque commemorating a priest who was martyred during the revolution.

The Church of Saint-Pierre de Montrouge is a stunning neo-Romanesque church in the 14th arrondissement of Paris. √âglise Saint-Pierre-du-Gros-Caillou is a beautiful and peaceful church nestled in the 7th arrondissement, just a short walk from the Eiffel Tower. Its elegant yet simple architecture creates a serene atmosphere, perfect for prayer and reflection.

The interior is warm and welcoming, with stunning stained-glass windows that allow soft light to filter through, enhancing the sacred ambiance. The church is well-maintained, and the sense of tranquility makes it a wonderful place to step away from the busy streets of Paris.

Very bright neo-classical Catholic church in the 7th arrondissement. The main nave is high and wide, and the two parallel side naves are narrow and (I think) a bit lower.  There is also a modern, rather large chapel added on the backside of the main altar with its own eastern end altar. I am not exactly sure why this chapel was added. Aesthetically beautiful church!

The Church of Saint-Augustin (√âglise Saint-Augustin) is a unique architectural and historical monument. Built between 1860 and 1871 by architect Victor Baltar, it became the first major religious building in Paris to use a visible cast iron and steel metal frame combined with stone cladding. This innovative approach for its time made it possible to create an impressive interior space without traditional buttresses, giving the building an unusual appearance at the junction of industrial and eclectic styles. The church was conceived as part of Baron Haussmann's urban planning scheme for the transformation of Paris, and it was intended to serve as an architectural landmark at the intersection of the Boulevard Malherbe and the Boulevard Haussmann, completing the perspective from the direction of the Madeleine Church. With its 80-meter-high dome and 100-meter-long structure, Saint-Augustin is one of the largest churches in the city. The architectural style of Saint-Augustin is eclectic, combining elements of Romanesque, Byzantine, and Gothic architecture. The facade is adorned with an 8-meter-diameter stained-glass rose, reinforced with cast-iron armature. Inside, the gilded cast-iron columns, decorated with polychrome angels by Louis Schroeder, and the dome paintings by William Bouguereau, are noteworthy.
One of the unique features of the church is its layout: the building has a trapezoidal shape, where the chancel is wider than the facade, and the side chapels gradually expand as they approach the choir.
The church is also famous for its musical organs: the main organ, created by Charles Spackman Barker, was one of the first in the world to use electricity, and has 54 registers.
Napoleon III planned to make this church the burial place of the Bonaparte dynasty.

The Church of Saint Augustine was built in Paris between 1860 and 1871 by architect Victor Baltard, who combined Romanesque and Byzantine style.
It's considered a place of deep conversion and renewal.
Charles de Foucauld (french Explorer) rediscovered his faith in this exact Church.

I stepped inside just to take a quick look ‚Äî and ended up standing still, completely mesmerized. The light through the dome felt almost divine, the silence almost alive. For a few moments, time slowed down. One of those rare places in Paris that makes you feel something real.

The churches of France continue to blow my mind. I am no longer a practising catholic but I have found these church visits very emotional. This church is very dark and amazing. I was baptised in a church of the same name so the connection was special.

is a Roman Catholic church located in the 17th arrondissement of Paris, France. It is dedicated to Saint Odile, the patron saint of Alsace.

The church was built between 1935 and 1946 in the Art Deco style. It is a rare example of Art Deco architecture among the churches of Paris. The church's bell tower, at 72 meters high, is the tallest in Paris.

The church's interior is decorated with stained glass windows, mosaics, and sculptures. The stained glass windows are particularly notable for their use of Art Deco motifs.

The church is a popular tourist attraction and is a must-see for any visitor to the 17th arrondissement.

Additional details:

The church is located at 2, avenue St√©phane-Mallarm√©.
It is open from 8am to 7pm.
The entrance is free.
The church is wheelchair accessible.
Here are some of the things you can see and do at √âglise Sainte-Odile:

Take a tour of the church and learn about its history and architecture.
See the stained glass windows, mosaics, and sculptures.
Attend a Mass or other religious service.
Visit the church's gift shop.
√âglise Sainte-Odile is a beautiful and historic church that is a must-see for any visitor to Paris. It is a great place to experience the city's rich religious heritage and to learn about the life of Saint Odile.

A lovely church. Though it looks heavy and imposing in the outside once inside it is light filled and airy. The barrel vaulted ceiling is lovely with beautiful decorations. There is a large chapel behind the alter and smaller ones along the sides.

The Masses here are reverent and well-organized, with inspiring homilies that uplift the spirit. The community is welcoming, and the church‚Äôs location near Les Invalides makes it a convenient stop for both locals and visitors.

Whether you‚Äôre attending a service or simply admiring its beauty, this church is a must-visit for anyone seeking a moment of peace in the heart of Paris.
