Very beautiful church amongst one of the busy streets of Paris. In a way proofs you the fact that you should never leave the camera in your pockey while you are in Paris.

Lovely church with a slightly more "Catholic" feel to it than most French churches which I generally feel are cold and almost Protestant. As someone who lives in Brazil I was pleased to attend mass in Portuguese as well.
Very unique church with beautiful colors

Being next to a larger church put this one kinda into the shadow. Instantly could tell this one is older, has a history and could tell more stories. Glad I stopped in! Saint-Pierre de Montmartre (French pronunciation: [s…õÃÉ pj…õ Å d…ô m…îÃÉma Åt Å]) is the second oldest surviving church in Paris, after the Abbey of Saint-Germain-des-Pres. It is one of the two main churches on Montmartre, the other being the more famous 19th-century Sacr√©-C≈ìur Basilica, just above it. Saint-Pierre de Montmartre, begun in 1133, was the church of the prestigious Montmartre Abbey, destroyed in the French Revolution.[1]

Considering the age of this Church, it is in a remarkable condition. The internal achitecture and statues are immaculate and well preserved. A delight to visit as it is so quiet and modest compared to the larger and much more famous neighbour around the corner. The entrance door in itself is a masterpiece of carving at such a time, given the basic tools available to the carpenters.

Tucked away beside the bustling Place du Tertre, the √âglise Saint-Pierre de Montmartre is a peaceful and historic retreat in the heart of one of Paris‚Äôs most vibrant neighborhoods. Often overshadowed by the grandeur of the nearby Sacr√©-C≈ìur Basilica, this small but enchanting church offers a quieter, more reflective experience that complements any visit to Montmartre.

As one of the oldest churches in Paris, founded in 1133 and consecrated in 1147, its history is truly remarkable. Built on the site of an ancient Roman temple dedicated to Mars, the church preserves columns and capitals from the Merovingian period, dating back to the 6th and 7th centuries. Its Romanesque and early Gothic architecture blends beautifully with its serene atmosphere, making it a treasure for history and architecture enthusiasts.

Inside, you‚Äôll find a sense of timelessness. The nave and choir, with their elegant ribbed vaults, are particularly captivating. The bronze doors, added in the 20th century, bring a modern artistic touch that contrasts harmoniously with the church‚Äôs ancient elements.

If you‚Äôre planning a Montmartre itinerary, √âglise Saint-Pierre is perfectly located to visit before or after the Sacr√©-C≈ìur. Its proximity to Place du Tertre, with its lively artists and cafes, makes it a delightful stop for a mix of quiet reflection and Parisian charm.

While not as monumental as other Parisian landmarks, the √âglise Saint-Pierre de Montmartre exudes a subtle beauty and profound history that leaves a lasting impression.

This second oldest (12th century) church in all of Paris is worth visiting, especially if you are taking a tour of Montmartre. It is basically right behind the more popular basilique Sacre-Coeur de Montmartre, and lot less crowded.

You cannot miss but notice the beautiful art and detail on the bronze central doorway. The church displays a statue of our lady of Montmartre. It was nice and peaceful inside and we could take our time appreciating the beauty of the art and history of this place.

Chapel situated in Montmartre near Sacre Coeur and village square. It is known to be the second oldest surviving church in Paris.
Very simple and tranquil inside.
Free to enter.
Very nice and quiet Catholic church. It was empty on a weekday when I visited. Good for photography or just to rest for a bit from Paris walks.
Beautiful church, free to enter

√âglise Saint-Denys du Saint-Sacrement is a beautiful, peaceful spot tucked away from the busy streets of Paris. It‚Äôs small and intimate, with elegant architecture and a calming atmosphere that makes it perfect for a quiet moment of reflection. The artwork and details inside are stunning, especially if you enjoy historic churches without the overwhelming crowds.

If you‚Äôre exploring the Marais and want to step into a serene, authentic Parisian church, this is definitely worth a visit.

We visited this beautiful Catholic Church April 2019 for Easter Mass. As a Altar Boy from the 60's I found this to be a great example of what you'd expect to see in a Catholic Church from this period.

Very friendly congregation. An elderly lady greeted everyone at the end of each pew with the famous French Cheek Kiss. What a surprise to my wife and I who had traveled here from Texas.

Beautiful music with pipe organ from the balcony above and behind us. If you want a great experience visit this Church during a service even if you are not Catholic. The Church exudes history. It's a must see while in Paris.

I tried to attend the 9 Mass on a weekday.  That is the time posted out front and on the website.  I couldn‚Äôt figure out how to enter.  All gates and doors locked.  I tried a what seems like a rear entrance but the parents present were not sure how to enter the church.
Such a peaceful and beautiful Church, full of  history and faith.

It was his last project, the Saint Jean-Baptiste church in Belleville was the most accomplished work of¬†Jean-Baptiste Antoine Lassus, one of the first French architects of the Neo-Gothic style in the middle of the 19th century. Lassus determined the structure, set the iconographic program, and designed the church furniture of Belleville. The sculpted decorations are the work of Aim√©-Napol√©on Perrey. The windows were made by Auguste de Martel, based on cartoons by¬†Louis Steinheil. The hinges of the gate and all the side doors were forged by the artistic ironworker¬†Pierre Fran√ßois Marie Boulanger.
Beautiful historical church right in front of metro Jourdain. Excellent acoustic and beautiful architecture.
It is one of the first churches built in the Gothic revival architecture in Paris.It was constructed in 1859.

Old gothic style Catholic Church in Paris. Far from the great circuit, this Church gives clear signs of tiredness, such as faded paintings and damp marks. In any case its architecture is very beautiful and its atmosphere is peaceful, due to the friendly people who frequent it.
It is easy to reach by public transport using the subway or bus.
üòçBeautiful church with a warm, tranquil feeling. A delightful visit...üòç

Heard the Good Friday Mass here. Very Solemn amidst the cacophony of businesses along Rue de Commerce, a very busy commercial strip where you can find Mediterranean, Chinese, Japanese, Korean mini restaurants. A lot of pastries shops too!
When you stand along Rue de Commerce, you can never miss the church as it gloriously stands straight on.  A reminder that in the conduct of your daily life, Christ is there looking after you. Another beautiful church to visit when in Paris.
St Charbel üíå I love this church
Local and special place to pray!

Beautiful and serenity in itself.
The art and work is just beautiful.
During the summer the beautiful windows illuminates the interiors with an mesmerising experience.
Stoped by here a few weeks ago as I always do if I'm in this area. I really like this church as its peaceful and well kept.
Nice XIX Century catholic church. Great services.
This is an old Catholic Church near our hotel.
Beautifully maintained church with parts from the earliest European settlers. This is definitely worth a visit to have a different perspective on the history of the area
This church is featured in the film, "The Legend of the Holy Drinker" starring the late Rutger Hauer. It is arguably his finest role and deserves more attention.
went to the swedish christmas market in the church. It was small but lovely, really good hot wine and deserts. Can't wait to go again next year
Best Childhood memories. Go to Santa Lucia for Christmas even if you re not religious. It's beautiful
Santa Lucia should not be missed, beautiful and puts you in the right mood for Christmas.
We had a nice violin concert with some nice refreshments
Very nice visited Effile Tower üóº Amazing experience
Beautiful church in s random neighborhood in Paris.  If you want to see the real medieval France, visit the random churches.  So much history and beautiful art all in one.

It‚Äôs quiet and elegant, perfect for a short break from the busy streets.
‚Ä¢	The church shows a different side of Paris ‚Äî calm, spiritual, and artistic.
‚Ä¢	It‚Äôs very close to the Mus√©e Gustave Moreau and Rue des Martyrs, a street full of food, flowers, and small shops.
Gorgeous church with lots of lovely details on the walls. Especially the herbal mural on the anterior arch is something not found in many churches.

A beautiful and tranquil place to sit and reflect. The entire building is a wonder and a fine example of stonemasonry, carpentry, and fine artwork. The only disappointment was a woman taking advantage of visitors who are likely to be charitable Christians. She was a middle aged respectable looking lady approaching all who were in the church asking for money because she had an unwell grandchild. I was not convinced of her genuine plight. It lowered the tone of what the building represents.
Surprised how nice it is, currently under renovation and the entrance door is difficult to find

A beautiful garden with gorgeous arbors, olive and fruit trees, a vegetable garden, and a play area for children. We spent many mornings here having our breakfast from The French Bastards (see our review- excellent!).

It‚Äôs an incredibly peaceful spot in St. Germain. Stop and enjoy. And don‚Äôt forget to smell the roses!

If you are in jardin de Luxembourg and you don't find a space to sit and relax in the sunlight , please come here.  It's much more calm and peaceful with less crowd.
Careful if you have pets as they are not allowed inside

Best public park in the 7th, selon moi. As others have said, it is a lovely oasis, walled off from the streets without feeling closed in. And shockingly, not only are jeux de ballons NOT strictement interdits, there is a lawn R√âSERV√âE aux jeux de ballons des jeunes enfants!! Delightful

A beautiful tiny park, dogs not allowed so very clean and perfect for picnics and read and get. Not very far from le bonne marche. Middays could be loud because children love to come in groups and play. Facilities and drink water fountain are available.
What a lovely place to spend some quiet fun time with little ones. Absolutely fabulous park, complete with toilets.

A square located on the west side of the 13th arrondissement of Paris and the "Maison Blanche" metro station, north of the "Pot√®ne des Peupliers" tram stop, a few minutes' walk away; with bars and restaurants on the north and east sides, as well as a park on the northeast side, other businesses on the west side, a residential building on the southwest side, and a daycare center on the southeast side.

It can be accessed from many of the surrounding streets, with sidewalks suitable for walking and strollers, but not necessarily in a wheelchair, but be careful if you have crutches.

There is a green island in the middle, but you must be careful of traffic if you want to access it. It's best to stick to the small park between the restaurants on the east side.
Beautiful, typical Parisian place. The cafe "13" is a good example.

Unforgettable art works. √úber beautiful building, and very nice staff, from ticket office to caf√© and shop. My only complaint is that there were way too many school groups and sometimes you cannot even approach the works because the kids are seated on the whole floor. Maybe you should reserve the museum for students at specific times and days?
The Mus√©e Picasso, housed in a magnificent Marais mansion, showcases the immense artistic range of Pablo Picasso, from paintings and sculptures to ceramics. It's an essential  you visit.

I learned so much about Picasso I didn‚Äôt know. For instance, he worked in a variety of mediums. Much of the exhibit came from Picasso‚Äôs own collection‚Äîworks he kept with him throughout his life. Very well done!

I really enjoyed visiting the Mus√©e National Picasso-Paris (part of Paris Museum Pass). It‚Äôs a beautiful museum in a historic building (starting from the antique statue at the corner of the entrance), and it has one of the best collections of Pablo Picasso‚Äôs art. You can see his paintings, drawings, and sculptures. The museum is well organized, and you can follow Picasso‚Äôs journey through different stages of his life and work.

One thing to know before you go: you must leave your bag in the cloakroom, which is downstairs. It‚Äôs free and safe, but it‚Äôs better to travel light if you can.

There‚Äôs also a small garden behind the museum. It‚Äôs a nice quiet place to sit and relax. The entrance to the garden is inside the museum too. It‚Äôs worth finding though.

Picasso was a master of traditional art, but he chose to be creative and free, "like a child". You can really see that in the artworks on display.

The museum is not too big, so you can enjoy it in one visit. The staff are helpful, and the signs are in English and French. I highly recommend it to anyone visiting Paris.
Really one of the best museums of my Paris trip! I really was able to appreciate those artworks. So many good works of Picasso in many varieties. Good reflection of how diverse his works are.

Guimet museum showcases the greatness of Sanaatan Dharm, and its impact on the Asian culture. At the main entrance, you are welcomed by the giant four-faced moorti of Bhagwaan Brahma. There are numerous beautiful moortis of Bhagwaan Vishnu, Bhagwaan Shiv, and Bhagwaan Buddh from various parts of Asia - India, Japan, Korea, china etc - on all the floors. The most mesmerizing moorti is on the ground floor, which shows Bhagwaan Vishnu resting on Anant Sheshnaag.

You also get a lovely view of the Eiffel tower while having lunch at the terrace. Great museum, 10/10, would visit again.
A fascinating museum showcasing rich stories from across Asia. The exhibitions are thoughtfully curated, well-organized, and provide a meaningful space for cultural exchange.

I visited the Mus√©e Guimet in Paris a few days ago and was truly impressed. The collection of Asian art is extensive and deeply atmospheric‚Äîmany of the pieces felt like they carried a spiritual energy. I‚Äôm not usually superstitious, but there was something powerful and even a little eerie about the experience that stayed with me.

The highlight at the end? The terrace on the top floor has an amazing view of the Eiffel Tower. Totally worth the visit‚Äîfor both the art and the unexpected moments.
The museum itself was brilliant, my kids really enjoyed it. What takes it down a bit, was the rooftop cafe. ‚Ç¨17 for a cup of instant noodles, is a ripoff. ‚Ç¨121 for four people, food and drinks.

Mus√©e Guimet is a treasure chest of civilizational memory and as I come from the very soil where those deities were once sculpted, worshipped, and philosophized over, it felt more than just awe. I've seen Vishnu not as a concept but as carved permanence. I stood before Bodhisattvas whose eyes seem to have watched over centuries of seekers.

What I experienced isn‚Äôt just art, it‚Äôs an ancestral pulse. Terracotta figures from the Indus Valley, the tantric grace of Cham sculptures, gilded Tibetan mandalas, Chola bronzes radiating devotion. It's the cosmos of my land, mirrored and preserved across oceans and empires.

Incompetent and arrogant!

No one anwers your mails in regard  to retrieve your purchased objetcs after you pay the invoice. They let you  wait for weeks and you have to mail endless mails and call.

Unbelievable!

Never again  No fun to spent your money there..

come here for the exhibition of famous fashion houses (admission is free).  Luxury space.  Because I have only experienced the space on the ground floor, it is quite small.  Anyway, it was a good experience.

A catastrophic experience with Artcurial‚Äôs shipping department  and one person in particular.

I have worked with galleries, auction houses, and shipping contacts across the US, UK, and EU  and never in my life have I encountered someone as unprofessional, slow, and utterly useless as Marine Viet, the so-called ‚ÄúDirector of Shipping and Customs.‚Äù

Due to her negligence, lack of basic follow-through, and inability to coordinate even the simplest international art shipment, I was left with a high-value painting stuck in limbo. Zero urgency, zero responsibility, zero awareness. A stray dog in a New Jersey warehouse has more logistical competence than this person.

This is not just about poor communication, it's about institutional rot. Artcurial looks like a high-end French auction house on the outside, but inside it‚Äôs a bureaucratic corpse choking on its own arrogance and inefficiency.
Emails go unanswered for weeks. Questions are dodged. No timeline, no clarity, no leadership.

Avoid Artcurial at all costs  especially if you're an international consignor. You‚Äôll be on your own, with no help, no accountability, and no professionalism.
I deeply regret ever trusting them with my work.
One of the most famous auction Riom in Paris located in the heart of the Champs-Elys√©es
How people can even think to place something here. That's dumb place.

As others have commented, we were expecting more of HCB‚Äôs works to be featured in the exhibitions. In hindsight, ten euros for two average-sized rooms were not really worth the price.
Your experience will depend on the temporary exhibitions they host. When we visited Sibylle Bergemann‚Äôs ‚ÄòMonument‚Äô exhibition was on and that was admittedly a very good one.
Amazing building well worth a visit, especially during a great exhibition, such as David Hockney!

Small yet exquisite space for photography that stirs the soul

We went to see Avedon‚Äôs ‚ÄúIn the American West‚Äù and it made us think and feel in new ways!

I love that it is a tucked away gem in the Marais and a must visit if you‚Äôre in this area!
Caught Richard Avedon‚Äôs American West portraits.  Incredible to see the work prints and some of the letters etc.
Currently exhibiting Richard Avedon‚Äôs ‚ÄúWest‚Äù, very convincingly placed. Just two big rooms but worth it at ten Euros. Lots of small bistros and a park nearby

Probably the most overlooked major museum in Paris. The Medieval collections are wonderful and well worth seeing, but it should be noted that its a museum focused on Medieval art rather than giving a more rounded picture of the period and society.

The Roman baths within the museum complex are incredible and very important archaeologically but have no interpretation and sadly become little more than a nice backdrop to one gallery, which is a massive missed opportunity. The outdoor elements of the baths were also inexplicably closed off. It feels as if the museum didn't want to dilute its Medieval theme by highlighting them too much.

The staff at the entrance were stunningly unfriendly but those in the galleries were nicer

If you are a fan of the middle ages or if you just like museums, this is a great place to visit. It is so big and you can see so many medieval remains. The lady and the unicorn tapestry alone is worth visiting at least once. It is also.situated right next to the 2000 year old roman bath remains.

I love medieval art, so naturally really enjoyed my visit to the Cluny museum. It's full of medieval sculptures, reliefs, artwork, jewellery, armour, and TAPESTRIES - these are simply stunning! A darkened room with huge tapestries of Lady and the unicorn, from floor to ceiling, you can explore the details close too. There are other tapestries as well, which are also amazing. I highly recommend visiting this beautiful museum!

Not a very large overwhelming museum but a petite and well kept wonderful museum. Great tapestries in 19,20,21 and very good collection of Christian relics. The courtyard is fantastic.  Time spent 2hrs.

This is the best museum in Paris. It is so well laid out and the timeline about medieval art is priceless. Don‚Äôt miss the beheaded statues that were originally on a portal at Notre Dame and allow yourself an hour at least with the Lady and the Unicorn.

Undeniably one of the most impressive museums in Paris. Absolutely awe inspiring, giant rooms with high ceilings filled with millennium old pieces of history, entire chunks of churches and cathedrals, and there's a lot to visit and look at. Also, a little glimpse at the Eiffel tower in the distance. Quite marvelous.

My second time visiting this museum. Other than the wonderful to-scale casts and structures of ancient architecture from France, there‚Äôs a fascinating exhibition of modern architecture including some of Le Corbusier‚Äôs seminal works. This one has place has lovely views onto the Eiffel Tower.

One of my favorite museums in Paris. We just saw the delightful exhibition on the Grand Magasin of Paris.
The castings and reproduction of architecture are great, the recreated murals (especially the dome) are beautiful and the architectural models are fascinating. And the full scale build of the Corbusier apartment is fascinating.
Never too busy and with great views if the Eiffel tower.

This site is absolutely stunning ‚Äì full of history and beauty. A must-visit.

unfortunately, the experience is spoiled right at the entrance by Mr. Tenan, Alpha chief of the Korporate agency, who barks at visitors for no reason. I‚Äôve met street aggressors with better manners.

In a cultural landmark of this standing, basic courtesy should be a given. How can such behaviour still be tolerated?
Great museum for those who are fascinated by architecture, art or design. The vast collection include reproduction of cathedral portals, stained glass windows, and mural paintings.

Saint Sava Serbian Orthodox Church in Paris is exceptionally beautifully painted, with astonishingly well-conceived fresco compositions.

The church is not only a spiritual center for the Serbian people in Paris but also one of its cultural hubs. The extraordinary chanting of the church choir 'Saint Simeon the Myrrh-Streaming' is a balm for the soul.

The church holds immeasurable significance in preserving and nurturing the identity of Serbian expatriates in Paris. Bishop Justin and the outstanding clergy selflessly contribute to this mission‚Äîa model to be followed throughout the Serbian diaspora.
Really beautiful and magnificent orthodox church with nice souvenir shop. Holy atmosphere making u forget the area around. Highly recommended!
One of the most beautiful cathedrals I have ever seen. The atmosphere is peaceful and you can see the fervor of the Serbs for Orthodoxy
Serbian Ortodox chrurch qute little place.
Beautiful orthodox church
Please allow for window openings to allow air to circulate in the room, as with more than 30 people, there is a lack of air in the room. Thank you in advance.
Beautiful and pleasant place... and very well organized.
Perfect venue for public events. Not wheelchair accessible.

Superb venue: neither too big nor too small. Beautiful stained-glass windows, equipment (tables and chairs) provided and in good condition.
I loved it.

Very nice room, large and well modernized with the work done recently. The only dilemma is the old-style windows which are fixed and do not open, meaning that we breathe the same air for the entire time we are there, which means there is no ventilation.

Visited the Chapel of Our Lady of the Miraculous Medal in Paris, such a beautiful and peaceful place. The moment you step inside, you can really feel the calm and sacred atmosphere. It‚Äôs simple yet very meaningful, and seeing where the Miraculous Medal originated makes the experience even more special. The church itself is modest but filled with a quiet sense of reverence. The small garden and area outside are also peaceful, perfect for a short reflection or prayer. Definitely worth a visit if you‚Äôre in Paris, even if you‚Äôre not deeply religious it‚Äôs one of those places that just fills you with peace. The location around the area is also a nice place to stroll

My visit to the Chapel of the Miraculous Medal on Rue du Bac in Paris was an experience I remember mainly because of how the history of the place connects with the physical presence of the bodies of the saints. I already knew about the apparitions of 1830 and that Sister Catherine Labour√© had encounters with the Virgin Mary there, but entering the chapel made me realise how close one can actually get to the events described in the accounts.

When I walked inside, I immediately noticed the area connected to the apparitions, including the spot Sister Catherine identified as central to what happened. This made the story, which I had previously known only from descriptions, feel much more concrete. On the right side of the chapel, I saw the body of St. Catherine Labour√©. Seeing her incorrupt body made me aware that the person whose experiences influenced the spirituality of so many people really lived there, prayed there, and carried out her work in that environment. On the left side lies the body of St. Louise de Marillac, the co-founder of the Daughters of Charity, whose work had a major impact on the development of charitable care. In a separate part of the chapel, the heart of St. Vincent de Paul is preserved. Seeing these relics made a strong impression on me because they offered a direct connection to people who shaped the history of the Church and its charitable mission.

The interior of the chapel is modest but well maintained. I did not feel any pressure to behave like a tourist. The atmosphere was calm, and the people inside kept silence and respect. This allowed me to focus on what I was seeing and to look at the place not only as a historical site but also as a space that has attracted visitors from around the world for almost two centuries. I felt that the history and the presence of the saints were not just elements on display but an active part of the place.

Leaving the chapel, I had the sense that I had seen a piece of history presented in a direct and tangible way. It is a place that may interest both believers and visitors who want to understand an important element of religious and social life in France.

I went there a Friday by noon for the morning prayer which ended by 12:30 and I came back 3:30pm for for the worshipping and purchasing of some medals üèÖ. It was a good time and I've learnt so many new things. It was primarily a beautiful üòç day with a nice weather and the service whether the security guards or the priests or the church sisters were very great, advising and had a good listening ear to our misunderstandings and really had the right words to lead the tourists üòá I loved being there üôè‚ô•Ô∏è

I visited the Chapel of Our Lady the Miraculous Medal in Paris ‚Äî magnificent, beautiful, and deeply spiritual! You can truly feel the peace and the presence of Divine grace. I have no words to describe this experience. üôè

On November 27, the Feast of Our Lady of the Miraculous Medal is celebrated. At the entrance of the Chapel of the Miraculous Medal in Paris, next to the Door of Mercy, stands the statue of Saint Vincent de Paul, reminding visitors of the mission of service and charity that inspires this place. Nearby, the figure of the Archangel Saint Michael offers a sign of protection. Very close by, the image of Saint Catherine Labour√©, witness of the apparitions of 1830, connects us with the origin of the Miraculous Medal.

The medal shows on its front the Virgin Mary standing upon the world, with rays of light representing her graces; and on its reverse, the M and the cross, the Sacred Heart of Jesus, the Immaculate Heart of Mary, and twelve stars.

We found this church accidentally while strolling in the area. It has beautiful architecture, both exterior and interior. The church has a quiet ambiance, and we spent a while there to take a break and recharge our energy before continuing our adventure in the beautiful city of Paris.
Wonderful church with a quiet square outside.

We were Lucky because we had our apartment right next to the Basilika Ste-Clotilde. The Basilika is a really nice and very big church in Paris next to Square Samuel Rousseau. The church has a lot of small but very nice windows and sculptures and looks very good day and night.

Beautiful basilica! Quiet, peaceful, and filled with interesting history. Decapitations, relics, frescos, statues, and chapels. Everything a believer can ask for! A great place to pray, meditate and lose one self in the details, symbolisms, and significance of this house of God.
Gothic style church with remarkable details and beautiful interior.

One of my favorite churches to photograph inside and outside when in Paris. I visit often and never fail to go back. Has a very big organ. Once I went and there was an organ concert (I believe it was a Sunday). It was crowded, but it was worth it.

The church stands as a testament to architectural splendour, capturing admiration both inside and out. Its design allows for an abundance of natural light to fill the space, creating an inviting and uplifting atmosphere.
Sunlight pours through the stained-glass windows, casting vibrant patches of colour across the interior. This interplay of light and colour enhances the experience of prayer, enveloping visitors in a serene and contemplative mood.
Among the church‚Äôs many features, the organ holds a special place. Its presence and sound are particular favourites, offering a memorable highlight for those who visit or worship within these walls.

Every time we come to Paris, we think of Notre-Dame ‚Äî but this church took my breath away. It may not have the same fame, yet it radiates such beauty and peace that it instantly becomes unforgettable. A true hidden gem in the City of Lights‚Ä¶ and believe it or not, it‚Äôs completely free to visit!

It's the 2nd church i visited in Paris. It has many unique paintings and statues. It wasn't crowded so you can take your time and even sit down to admire its beauty. The colored windows were so beautiful. It's still being renovated from the inside so it has a strong smell of paint.

What a wonderful church that I had the pleasure of singing Sunday Mass in the other week. The light from the stained glass windows was absolutely stunning when mixed with the insence of the mass, and the organ is just wonderful. Regular mass occurs here as well as frequent organ recitals which really show off the impressive instrument. Would highly recommend on a visit!
Great quality but the prices are still not great value. Huge range though!

The after-sales service on the 4th floor is fantastic üòç
A big thank you to Mr. Dally for his kindness, professionalism, and smile. Also, thank you to Ms. Karine.

We came today, September 12th at 6 p.m. for a bag repair service, after speaking to an advisor on the phone who explained that we could come at that time. The receptionist was disgusting, unpleasant, and haughty. She absolutely does not represent the brand's image.

I was on the 4th floor for after-sales service.
Very well received, well organized, and their customer service is excellent!
Warm welcome

What an amazing Church. Like almost all the churches in France, always amazed at the high arches of these Gothic style of churches. The stained glass windows and the awesome inspiring high ceilings . A must visit From wiki "Saint-Nicolas du Chardonnet¬†(French pronunciation:¬†[s…õÃÉ¬†ni.k…î.l…ë¬†dy¬† Éa Å.d…î.n…õ]) is a¬†Catholic¬†church in the centre of¬†Paris,¬†France, in the¬†5th arrondissement.[1]¬†It was constructed between 1656 and 1763. The facade was designed in the classical style by¬†Charles Le Brun. It contains many notable art works from the 19th century, including a rare religious painting by¬†Jean-Baptiste Corot."

We find it really hard to be impressed with churches in France as there are so many spectacular ones. We stopped in at Saint-Nicolas du Chardonnet during Mass and were really impressed. The building is beautiful and they have a mission which feeds the homeless. A lovely church.

Like most of religious places in Paris is a unique historical place, I saw a stone carving from 1625 on one of the side doors. There are a lot of beautiful antiques inside despite of spiritual vibe. Nobody ask for a ticket. Parking place and bathroom not available or very hard to find. Check the pictures please.

Beautiful church which offers the mass of all ages.

As to those who complain on the dress code, people are simply following Catholic modesty. Shorts in the middle of the summer is no excuse, as we in the Philippines wear pants, collared and long-sleeved shirts. Just imagine; if we are to appear before the highest official in France in person, are we expected to wear a casual t-shirt with shorts? Absolutely not! A Catholic church dedicated to Saint Francis of Assisi, consecrated in 2005 based on a design by architects Jean-Marie Duthilleul and Corinne Cailles, it stands on the site of a Capuchin chapel built in 1941.
The translucent white marble exterior is aligned with the street facade and features two recesses, one corresponding to the monumental wooden entrance doors and one to accommodate a black granite sculpture by Alain Courtaigne. On the corner near the statue is the tall bell tower, barely visible from the street.
The layout is nearly square, with a white marble altar at its center. It is set on a central axis connecting the street side at both ends with the opposite glass side overlooking a private garden. The windows are slightly frosted to reduce light. The interior features light wood furnishings, as is the ceiling. The atmosphere exudes a sense of peace and serenity. The most interesting element in my opinion is the view onto the garden, in front of which stands the large golden cross.

A refined church where you can observe nature behind the altar!

The Palmier Fountain, also known as the Ch√¢telet Fountain, is a column located on the Place du Ch√¢telet in Paris. It was built in the early 19th century by order of Napoleon to commemorate his victories. At the top of the column is a statue of Nike, the goddess of victory. At the base are four other female figures, symbolizing vigilance, justice, strength, and prudence. The fountain was also intended to provide drinking water to the people of Paris.

A moving and unexpected moment at Alma‚Äôs Bridge

I happened to be in Paris on the Sunday of the Tour de France, and certain roads were closed to traffic. I found myself near Alma‚Äôs Bridge and realized it was the tunnel where Princess Diana‚Äôs accident happened.

Even though no one else seemed to be going down there, I decided to walk into the tunnel. It was quiet, and I was able to see the spot where it happened and a portrait of Diana. I stopped and had a moment of silence. It was honestly quite emotional.

I wasn‚Äôt expecting to feel so moved, but being there in person made it a memorable moment.

Pont de l‚ÄôAlma in Paris blends history and elegance beautifully, originally built in 1856 to honor the Battle of Alma, it now graces the Seine with clean lines and the famous Zouave statue still standing guard. Iconic views of the Eiffel Tower add to its quiet, emotional power.

The square in front of the Church of Saint-Medard is a place with a unique history. It is located in the Latin Quarter, on the site of a former church cemetery.
The history of this place is associated with Jansenism, a movement within Catholicism. In the 18th century, the cemetery was the burial site of Fran√ßois de Paris, a revered Jansenist deacon, and his grave became a place of mass pilgrimage. The followers experienced religious ecstasy accompanied by convulsions, earning them the nickname "convulsions." The place became an arena of incredible events: crowds gathered here, some seeking miraculous healing, while others came to gawk at the unusual spectacle.
The unrest became so widespread that in 1732, King Louis XV ordered the cemetery to be closed. The next day, a famous sarcastic inscription appeared on the gates: "De par le Roy, d√©fense √† Dieu de faire miracle en ce lieu" - "In the name of the King, God is forbidden to perform miracles in this place."
In 1875, the cemetery was finally closed, and in its place, the park that exists today was created.
Today, it is a quiet and peaceful park with a fountain and beautiful flowers.

I reviewed the Rotisserie Segar chicken here in this little square. I was having a nice time eating this bird as the rain began to fall.

Just as we were wrapping up filming, the biggest rat I‚Äôve ever seen in my life scurried out right next to us. I‚Äôve lived in New York for the past 3 years, and this was easily the biggest rat I‚Äôve ever seen. My girlfriend legit thought it was a fox. It gives me the chills even thinking about it.

Other than that, it‚Äôs a nice place to chill.

Site of Fashion Week for designer show Sept 2025.  Historic site:

Historical significance:
A center of royal life: The palace was a significant royal residence for centuries, hosting grand parties and being the birthplace of royalty.
A hotbed of revolution: In the 18th century, the gardens became a meeting place for revolutionaries. The rallying cry that led to the storming of the Bastille was famously given here by Camille Desmoulins in 1789.

Modern attractions
Tranquil gardens: The elegant gardens provide a peaceful escape from the city, ideal for a leisurely stroll or a quiet picnic.
Chic shopping: The arcades surrounding the garden are home to upscale designer boutiques, vintage shops, and art galleries.
Modern art: The inner courtyard features the striking black-and-white striped columns of Daniel Buren's "Colonnes de Buren" art installation.
La Com√©die-Fran√ßaise: The historic French national theatre is located in one wing of the Palais Royal.
Legendary dining: It houses historic restaurants like the famous Le Grand V√©four, which has hosted famous figures for centuries.

The Palais Royal Garden is one of Paris‚Äôs most charming and Instagrammable spots! Surrounded by elegant architecture and beautiful greenery, it‚Äôs the perfect place to take stunning photos, enjoy a peaceful stroll, or simply relax and soak up the Parisian atmosphere.

What makes it even better is that it‚Äôs free to visit ‚Äî a quiet escape right in the heart of the city. Between the famous black-and-white Colonnes de Buren and the perfectly manicured gardens, every corner feels picture-perfect.

A must-visit for anyone who loves art, beauty, and a touch of Parisian magic! üá´üá∑

This is a historic garden located in the 1st arrondissement, opposite the northern wing of the Louvre. It is part of the architectural ensemble of the Palais-Royal, which includes a palace, a square, and a park.
The garden was established in 1633 and covers an area of 20,850 m¬≤. Originally built for Cardinal Richelieu and known as the Cardinal's Palace, it became the royal residence after his death and was renamed the Palais-Royal. Today, the garden is open to the public and is open daily from 8:00 a.m. to 10:30 p.m. It is surrounded by galleries with boutiques and cafes, and is also known for its modern installations, such as the Buren Columns and the Paul Bury Fountain.
The garden features magnolias planted in 1992, which bloom every spring, creating a picturesque sight.
There is also a small bronze cannon that was used as a sundial in the 18th century, firing every day at noon.
The Palais-Royal Garden is an oasis of tranquility and beauty in the middle of a very noisy city.
Interestingly, there are many cafes and restaurants serving Asian cuisine, especially Japanese and Korean, near the garden.

Went in September on a cloudy chilly day and it was still so magical. First, it‚Äôs free public space so no entry fee.

There are a few benches and seating surrounding the fountain. It could be a lovely spot for a picnic, to relax and read a book, or for a stroll. Definitely ideal for photo shoots just under the lime and chestnut trees.

You can find the Louvre and the city‚Äôs oldest restaurant nearby plus shopping in the surrounding arcade.

Definitely a quintessential place to visit and linger awhile. Coming back again and again.

The Jardin du Palais-Royal is a peaceful oasis right in the heart of Paris, just north of the Louvre. Despite its central location, it‚Äôs surprisingly calm and never too crowded.
On one side, you‚Äôll find charming caf√©s and restaurants; on the other, the quiet and elegant Rick Owens boutique. The modern art installations add a creative touch to the classic Parisian atmosphere.
A perfect spot to relax, reflect, and enjoy a quieter side of Paris.

Re: James Douglas Morrison (Poet)
Jim was a very complex and gifted individual. He consciously created a revolutionary public persona. But he lived long enough to regret it. He was both handsome and intelligent. In private, he was rather quiet and introverted in contrast to his rock star image. Jim subsequently became an alcoholic. But it permitted him to perform on stage, without being self-conscious. Jim used to walk on edges of buildings. But he had a bad fall prior to his departure to Paris, since he was coughing up blood. As for his death, he apparently purchased heroin in the Rock 'N' Roll Circus Club where he passed away as a consequence due to the combination of alcohol with heroin, which resulted in heart failure. Strange because he was strongly opposed to it since Pamela was using it on occasion.  As for "The Lizard King" for the younger admirers, it's tongue-in-cheek. Jim in countless ways was an actor.  Ironically, the idolatry that followed him right to his grave greatly contributed to his death. Jim and Pam are the Romeo and Juliet of pop music. They will remain forever young. (How many rock stars today read Camus, Hegel, Heidegger, Hume,  Kierkegaard, Montaigne, Nietzsche, Plato, Rousseau, Sartre, Schopenhauer and Voltaire?)

The Pont de la Tournelle is a simple, old looking bridge that blends in well with the architecture of the area (which is beautiful by the way). The bridge has literary and cultural significance and has been featured in the writings of Victor Hugo, and Ernest Hemingway. They were both talking about different bridges at the same location. There has been a bridge at this location since the 1600s, but this one was built in 1928 (previous bridges having been washed away or demolished).

The bridge has been described as 'intentionally lacking symmetry', not sure exactly what this refers to. Maybe the fact that the small northern arch spans part of the river, while the southern arch spans a walkway - albeit quite likely the walkway is a more recent addition.

Great looking bridge. Of note, there's a statue of St. Genevieve on the south side, she being the patron saint of Paris after having driven Attila's huns away from the city with the power of prayer.

Located at the top of luxembourg gardens, is this stunning stretch of greenery, that is no way as busy as the palace garden, it is so nice to walk along the shade of the many tress enjoying the peace and tranquility whilst admiring the many monuments and statues along the way.

As I entered the garden, I was greeted by the serene atmosphere and meticulously landscaped paths. The lush greenery and vibrant flowerbeds provided a picturesque setting, perfect for a leisurely stroll.

I wandered along the tree-lined avenues, taking in the sights and sounds of nature intertwined with the city's charm. The centerpiece, the stunning fountain, sparkled under the sunlight, creating a peaceful ambiance. Benches scattered throughout the park offered ideal spots to pause and soak in the surroundings.

As I continued my walk, the sculptures and statues of famous explorers added a touch of historical intrigue. The gentle rustling of leaves and the distant chatter of fellow walkers created a symphony of tranquility.

My walk through Jardin des Grands-Explorateurs was a refreshing escape from the hustle and bustle, a perfect blend of natural beauty and cultural richness.

This is part of the extended green space along with Esplanade Gaston Monnerville and the Luxembourg Gardens in the 6th arrondissement. It is situated just south of the Esplanade between Rue Michelet (north) and Ave. de l'Observatoire (south).

The Garden created in 1867 and is dedicated to world explorers Marco Polo (1254-1324) and Ren√©-Robert Cavelier de La Salle (1643-87). It is similar in shape and scale to the Esplanade to the north and features a couple of the sister monuments that pair with those in the Esplanade, flowerbeds, side walking paths, rows of trees on both sides and park benches.

However, the most striking feature is the Fountain of the Four Parts of the World at the southern end. This fountain monument was designed by Gabriel Davioud and completed between 1867-74 and is well worth spending a few minutes to enjoy during time spent at the Garden of the Grand Explorers.

This park was very nice. There was a pond with a fountain in the middle and people put toy boats into the water to sail around. In the park there is also a lot of statues and a beautiful view to the Luxemburg building. There is also a playground for kids and a workout spot for adults,  and on the grass there is a great place door yoga and just doing your daily fitness routine.

It's a nice place to relax. Though it's not huge but you can definitely have some quite time there. On one side, there's a pretty small playground for the kids in the pattern of a ship. Children aged 2 to 8 can enjoy there.

A lovely garden ü™¥ featuring tall trees üå≤ and a children's playground.
This public garden offers relaxation and play areas surrounded by greenery, some shaded by large trees boasting beautiful colors in spring and fall: ornamental apple trees, maples, hazelnut trees, a chestnut tree in the center, and a particularly remarkable cedar.

This public garden is exceptionally well-maintained by the fantastic gardeners of Paris, and the play and relaxation areas are designed for a natural and very pleasant experience. The Carr√© de Baudouin building, accessible from the garden, houses exhibitions. It's located just off Rue de M√©nilmontant, behind a wall decorated by graffiti artists, with designs that are regularly updated.
Very quiet, sunny, on the side of the road but you can barely hear it. The only problem is that there are very few games for children.

This garden is deteriorating year after year...
It's a shame, it has everything it needs to be a charming place.

Pont Saint-Louis is more than just a bridge‚Äîit‚Äôs a serene passage between two of Paris‚Äôs most historic islands, √éle de la Cit√© and √éle Saint-Louis. Just steps from Notre-Dame, it offers a peaceful spot to pause, take in the views, and enjoy the quiet beauty of the Seine.

The bridge is pedestrian-only, which makes it feel relaxed and welcoming. It‚Äôs a great place to stop for photos of Notre-Dame from a different angle or to watch the boats glide by. Street performers often set up here, adding to the lively, artistic vibe without overwhelming the space.
This small bridge links the tow islands of Ile de Cite and Ile de saint-Louis, very handy for us walking types.

I didn‚Äôt know there is a bridge between two island because it doesn‚Äôt look existing on the Google Maps. It‚Äôs pedestrian only bridge but wide enough for the car traffic.
There were some old people enjoying roller skating slalom! üòÜ
Amazing bridge connecting the two islands in paris. On nice days you can find many a street artist here and it's fun to just sit down and enjoy some time here.

Sweet little bridge connecting I'le de la Cit√© and I'le Saint Louis. We walked it all times of day and night and never tired of the views. Cafes nearby on both side and a great view of the Seine and Notre Dame. Even though it was winter we had street museums on Sat morning. It was even nice in the rain.

Big space on an abandoned warehouse where they hold expositions and events. When we passed by there was so e sort of flea market, that was kinda overwhelming for my taste. Would like to pass by and check out something art related.
Walked past this space on a Friday morning, wow transformed into a 2nd hand market.
Super

A legendary venue for artistic events in Paris!

Here's a magnificent pocket-sized exhibition by Aksel Varichon, a tiny summary of his immense talent!

Fantastic weekend at the Feminist Liberated Fair!

This space is large, clean, and perfectly suited to this type of event!
The temporary exhibition about the time was really great. Meaningful, fun, clear orientation. The AC here is super good for a very hot summer. No need to book in advance. Very quiet here.

It is a very nice museum to know about the history of La Poste ( Postal Service of France). You can see all the stamps produced by France till now since the last 2 centuries. The museum was really fascinating and interesting and the ticket is also really less so a person must visit this place. You can see a lot of older technology as well.
Love this little museum! such a pleasant surprise. And I have returned a few times to the gift shop to buy quirky gifts for people that you wouldn‚Äôt find anywhere else.

I love everything post office so this museum is really perfect!! I love stamps and here are stamps. Letters and uniforms - mailboxes (yes, I have a fascination with yellow so I like it even more!).
The staff are lovely and especially the lady at the souvenir counter, never met anyone cuter than her!

Fabulous museum! Quiet, well organized, fascinating history of The Post.... For patrons who are Deaf, there are video descriptions of several of the exhibits in French Sign Language- it's wonderful!üá®üáµüíôüá®üáµü§©ü§ü

Eglise Note-Dame de Grace de Passy „Ä∞Ô∏è„Ä∞Ô∏è
I am here as an American, to let you live through
me, the experience of visiting this church. First,
this is not a tourist monument, and it would be
more simple if a local friend took you and found     a parking space on the street. Once that is done,
you will enter an experience that you never knew.
You will enter another world. The quiet creaking
of the old wooden floor. The filtered light coming
through the stained glass windows. The small
wicker chairs that hold you so upright. And also something that I will never forget, a prominent
smell of a combo of candles, many flowers, and burning insense, which fills the whole church.
An organ plays, and a young woman sings with
a voice from heaven. As you later leave, you will ask yourself, "What is this world on the street,
with a bakery, a fish restaurant, a shoe shop??
I don't know if you are in the mood, but a
combination to this would be the Passy Cemetery which is less than a mile away.
There rests many famous persons, such as
the artist Manet, musicians Faure, Messager,
and Ibert, and Givenchy and Guerlain (perfume)
Let this remind you, as you go away from the big attractions, there is so much history in Paris‚ùó
Jack Roach -- Florida & France  Sept.6 2023
Beautiful church ‚õ™Ô∏è
Secluded little church square just off busy shopping street.
Perfect place to pray
amen

Make sure to buy tickets online in advance, as they get sold out fast, then it is a wonderful museum showcasing evolution and scientific discoveries over the ages. There is a staggering amount of skeletons and fossils on display, as well as a vast collection of prepared organs and other specimens. It's a museum that triggers curiosity and a great way to discover natural history and our origins. Absolutely loved our visit, couldn't recommend it more !

Went on the first Sunday of the month for free, you can get tickets for free on the website but it‚Äôs not the easiest to navigate if you don‚Äôt speak French. Very cool museum with amazing selection of different samples. It‚Äôs so gorgeous. I only wish some more of the signage was in English.

Apparently you can enter for free (first Sunday of the month). Otherwise book tickets online. You cannot buy tickets at the gallery.
Really liked the gallery! Very well maintained and the collection is extensive. Wonderful place for nerds or people interested in this. Since my French is basic, I couldn't read/understand most of the labels and specifics of the pieces. It would have been great if some of it were in English. You may try Google Lens > Translate, but this might be tedious. No WiFi available either.
The shop outside has cool merchandise but unfortunately it was shit when I visited.

A very interesting museum in a such an old, architecturally beautiful  setting. My two kids, aged 7 and 12, were over the moon as there were so many interesting things to see. The sable tiger, the mammoth, the whales and the T-Rex skull were the highlights of their visit.

Of course the content is all a bit macabre but we all loved it. However, it's mostly only in French and I would have loved to at least have the names of the animals/content in English. That being said, I would recommend this museum to anyone interested in biology and evolution.

Very impressive collection of skeletons. I wish I had visited while still at college studying comparative anatomy. Can't recommend enough. If you're interested in evolution/anatomy or skeletal structure it's well worth a visit. You could spend hours there.
Calm and nice

Charity sales are regularly organized there. (clothes, shoes, trinkets, books...You can eat well there for cheap, and buy delicious jams prepared by a good soul, the benefits of these meetings help feed the most deprived in the neighborhood. Thank you to all the volunteers

text:
Notre-Dame totally amazing place to visit
I highly recommended 100%
1000 year old local church. I love it
Peace & tranquillity in the centre of Paris, with exquisite stain glass windows and a wonderful architectural design provides a remarkable serenity amid the bustle of city dwellers.....
I have visited this place this month. Yes i am satisfied and happy .

Anyone be careful when crossing the streets and take care of your purse. If necessary get into the M√©tropolitain stations to check your position on the plans inside or ask an Agent wearing a RATP Staff uniform for advice. It's so easy to get lost here and there‚Äôs lot of traffic.

Quite known area in Paris. Good for people who look for moderate accommodation who come for exhibitions at Porte de Versailles.
It‚Äôs a good place to discover Paris with good connection to metro tram and trains not far from the metro Porte d‚ÄôOrl√©ans. Very good selection of restaurants around the area as well
Lively neighborhood..lots of tourist class hotels.  Good subway connections to rest of Paris
Nicest place to stay in Paris. Good restaurants.

The fountain itself is beautiful ‚Äî calm, historic, elegant. The issue? There are a few too many "innocents" hanging around, eyeing your pockets like it‚Äôs a sport. It‚Äôs a cool little spot, but the sketchy surroundings dull the charm a bit. Worth a photo stop, just keep your bag close and your wits closer.
A beautiful fountain with lots of interesting history. Nice place to sit and watch the world go by. Just watch out for pickpockets and scammers.
A pleasant place where you can rest after a day of walking in beautiful Paris.

Many years ago during our first visit to paris many years ago, this monumental fountain and area, was in a sad state, however, in recent times, it has been restored to its former glory with water actually cascading down its steps, the area, feels like it has stepped up as well, being very popular with locals and tourists alike.

A nice little fountain that has been restored,  it invites one to sit relax and contemplate life's little mysteries. A few nearby benches to sit and eat and relax from the bustling city. This small fountain dates back to 1550 and was designed by Pierre Lescot by request of King Henry IV. Many nearby caf√©s and restaurants. Downside is the undesirables close by to scam or pickpocket from you.

The Church of Saint Th√©r√®se of the Child Jesus in Elizabethville (Yvelines).

It was built from 1927 to 1928 under the direction of architect Paul Tournon and is inspired by the Saint-Chapelle de Paris. The sculptures are by Carlo Sarrabezolles. If it's not strictly neogothic, it's safe to say it's neogothic with art deco sauce.
The first sanctuary in honor of Sainte Th√©r√®se of Lisieux consecrated in 1930. Gothic in style. Very pure in lines and of small dimensions. Beautiful place to visit, see and pray.
Thanks to Fr Simplisand Fr Calvin for your warmly welcome. Mbarikiwe sana

This unusual-looking church, Saint-Ferdinand-de-Ternes, was built on the site of an older church. Construction of the new building began in 1937. It was not completed until 1957.
The architecture of the church is an example of the architectural eclecticism that was popular in Europe at the time. The church features massive, often cubic structures, large domes, and centralized compositions. It is described as having a neo-Byzantine style.
The facade is decorated with three rather strange and slightly frightening sculptures depicting Saint Ferdinand, Christ, and Saint Teresa.
The church also has a lower temple, or crypt.
One of the most wonderful moments was hearing beautiful singing, which was soulful and harmonious.
This was such a beautiful church! I wish that I was able to take more views from the inside, but I was being respectful and mass was about to begin.
A beautiful  place of worship. Around the corner from where I am staying.  Enjoy hearing the bells chime on the half hour.
Such a beautiful church. Exploring the neighborhood I was staying in, I found this beautiful church and enjoyed the beautiful setvice.
Love this church! We got married here and the parish was easy to communicate with for all of the details and information.

Visted the Hotel in December 2025. Wonderful place to see. All those marble chambers and the Napoleon resting place and statute. I loved the entertaining projection on the walls and statues. It is also close tothe Eifel tower.
Musee de l'armee is also there which really interesting.

The whole place was beautiful with history everywhere. We definitely did not end up giving it the time it deserved due to a scheduling conflict. I also would highly recommend taking a picture of the map because the grounds can be difficult to navigate.

A great museum, describing the long and rich history of the French Army. Originally designed by Napoleon to be an hospital for injured soldiers, it was lately turned into a museum at the end of 1.800. The main dome is the mausoleum of some of the greatest characters of French Battles, like Napoleon.

If you like military history then this is a must see in Paris. From the historical suits of armor to the vintage muskets, cannon. and swords.
Napoleon's tomb is a bonus.

It's large enough that we never made it to the 20th century military equipment.

I visited H√¥tel des Invalides on the 6th of October, and it was a truly memorable experience. The architecture alone is breathtaking, especially the golden dome that crowns the complex. Inside, I explored the military museum and Napoleon‚Äôs tomb‚Äîboth deeply impressive and rich with history. I highly recommend going, but make sure to buy your ticket online in advance. Mine cost 17 euros, and it saved me time at the entrance. Overall, it was a smooth and enriching visit.
Lovely bridge in Paris. Lots of good restaurant nearby.
Simply beautiful!! Loved everything about this place.
A beauty bridge to see skating performers on Sundays and view the Seine river.
A wonderful place for views of the islands of St. Louis and the Cit√©, near the institute of the Arab world and pedestrian promenades on the left bank of the Seine.

The Pont de Sully, known for its picturesque views of the Seine River and iconic architecture, is a must-visit spot for anyone traveling to the city of love.

Upon arrival, I was greeted by friendly staff who were more than happy to answer any questions I had about the area. The ambiance was relaxed and serene, making it the perfect place to take a stroll or enjoy a picnic with loved ones. The view of the river was breathtaking and left me feeling refreshed and rejuvenated.

What sets the Pont de Sully apart from other locations is its unique architecture and design. The bridge boasts intricate details that are a testament to the rich history and culture of Paris.

Although my experience at Pont de Sully was mostly positive, I did notice that some areas could use a bit of maintenance. For example, some of the walkways were uneven and could pose a safety hazard. I would suggest that the owners pay closer attention to the upkeep of the facilities to ensure the safety and comfort of their visitors.

Overall, I would highly recommend a visit to Pont de Sully. It's a stunning location with a rich history and culture that everyone should experience at least once. The staff were friendly, the views were breathtaking, and the atmosphere was serene. I would definitely consider returning to this location in the future.

This impressive building, with its ornate facade and historical significance, is a true architectural gem. The square is a vibrant public space that often hosts events and exhibitions. I enjoyed the lively atmosphere and beautiful surroundings. The mix of historical and modern elements in the area adds to its charm, making it a delightful place to explore.
Beautiful place during Christams .
You can get really cool photos here!:)
A large space full of historical sculptures and excellent architecture
Love this place ‚ù§Ô∏è
When we visited, the Basilica was still under construction from the fire it had. So we just admired the facade and the surrounding areas. Which was still a wonderful experience!

Despite its modest exterior, the interior is warm, spiritual, and intimate a place where art, history, and devotion come together quietly yet profoundly. A must-visit for anyone seeking a peaceful, beautifully decorated sanctuary off the beaten path.

üìç Basilica of Notre-Dame des Victoires

7 Pl. des Petits P√®res, 75002 Paris, France üá´üá∑

Tucked away in the 2nd arrondissement of Paris, the Basilica of Notre-Dame des Victoires is a peaceful and lesser-known spiritual gem with a rich and fascinating history.

The church was originally built in the 17th century by Louis XIII, who vowed to construct it after a military victory over the Protestants at La Rochelle in 1628 ‚Äî hence the name ‚ÄúOur Lady of Victories.‚Äù Construction began in 1629 and continued over several decades, finally being completed in the 18th century. Over time, the church became a site of deep Marian devotion, attracting the faithful from around the world.

What makes this basilica unique is its collection of over 37,000 ex-voto plaques, letters, and tokens of thanks left by worshippers whose prayers were answered. These offerings, covering nearly every inch of the interior, create a powerful visual testament to centuries of faith and gratitude. It was also here that St. Th√©r√®se of Lisieux experienced a profound spiritual moment ‚Äî an important stop in her spiritual journey.

In 1927, Pope Pius XI elevated the church to the status of minor basilica, recognizing its religious significance. Today, it remains a quiet refuge in the middle of Paris, a place where history, art, and devotion all come together ‚Äî often missed by tourists but cherished by those who discover it.

This church has a great architecture inside.
Peaceful and quiet environment.
I have seen some unique statues
I felt really a good holiness inside the church
Must visit church in Paris

A nice 17th century basilique tucked away in the second arrondissement of Paris, with an interesting history. It has a few chapels and quite a bit of beautiful art and decoration.

We stumbled into this church on our visit to the covered galleries, the entrance of one is just right across the street from the basilica. It sure is worth a visit, especially if you are in the area. It was so quiet and tranquil.
Kinda dirty and a lot of tags are on the bridge but the view is really nice to see, maybe some trash can could help resolve the garbage issue. I had no problem crossing it.
A nice bridge crossing the river Seine and overlooking a beautiful neighborhood.
A very unique and beautiful bridge!

Despite this bridge not being as famous as some of the others, this bridge still gives some beautiful panoramic views of the city of Paris along the Seine and still offers a really nice walk. It‚Äôs open all the time and is really beautiful at any time of the day, especially during sunrise or sunset when the sun reflects against the Paris skyline or at night when the skyline is all lit up. Since it‚Äôs close to many of the attractions of the city, it‚Äôs a great location for those wanting to spend time in the city. And since it‚Äôs not as popular as the other bridges, it is not that packed with tourists, making it more enjoyable of a stroll to some. The architectural work of the bridge is also absolutely stunning, and is a great opportunity for photos.

The Pont Charles-de-Gaulle bridge straddling the river Seine in the eastern part of Paris neer the place in Gare De Lyon area where we were staying. Fun to watch the boats go by, and lot of places to take great photos.
A quirky part of the 10th, definitely worth visiting, especially during the autumn flea markets, (vide grenier), translate clearing the attic, it was so much fun mingling with the local.
A lovely corner to share with friends.

Small, very quiet square in the heart of the Belleville district. Very pleasant in the summer thanks to the terraces. Typical of Parisian life, you can enjoy a quiet drink on the terrace and then after dinner in the famous restaurant recently opened by one of the participants of Top Chef. Accessible on foot from the Belleville metro station because it is impossible to park on the street
I really like this square in the 10th arrondissement, very lively, with beautiful cafes and pretty old passages.
Deserted alley with many dilapidated buildings, maybe cozy on the weekend, but not when we were there.
Nice quiet spot to enjoy the shade or the sun!
Super crowded but well designed with areas for every age
Super

Simple place. Lot of children.

A charming and elegant bridge with stunning views of the Seine! Pont de la Concorde connects some of Paris‚Äôs most iconic landmarks, with the Eiffel Tower, Assembl√©e Nationale, and Place de la Concorde all nearby. It‚Äôs a peaceful spot for a walk, especially at sunset when the city glows at night or in the evening

A beautiful bridge that spans the Seine River, connecting the Quai des Tuileries at the Place de la Concorde with the Quai d'Orsay. It offers stunning views of various Parisian landmarks, including the Eiffel Tower. The bridge itself is an architectural gem with ornate details. The area around Pont de la Concorde is known for its historical significance, and it's a popular location for both locals and tourists to enjoy a pleasant walk along the Seine or to take in the iconic sights of Paris.

A beautiful bridge that is parallel with he Seine River, connecting jardin des Tuileries at the Place de la Concorde with the Quai d'Orsay.
It offers stunning views of various Parisian landmarks, it‚Äôs walking distance almost to everything you want to visit including the Eiffel Tower.
The bridge itself is an architectural gem with ornate details.
It can be reached by metro Concord

This place is a must-visit pitspot üöè on your next trip to Paris! üá´üá∑ Pont de la Concorde is an iconic historical bridge üåâ in the heart ‚ù§Ô∏è of Paris with breathtaking views ü™ü of the city üèôÔ∏è and the Eiffel Tower!üóº Arrive just before sunset üåá and bring your best camera üì∑ for some Instagram-worthy ü§≥ photos! üì∏ I wish I could come here more often!

No nonsense bridge spanning the river Seine. Helps with the traffic flow and gives access to Place de la Concorde on the North Bank. Wide pedestian walkway provides for many photographic oportunities of the local landmarks.

This week was my fifth visit to this beautiful Louis Vuitton foundation.
The exhibitions I've seen here include the Morozov brothers' art collection, Simon Hanta√Ø (+fugues in color), Basquiat √ó Warhol, David Hokney, and now Gerhard Richter. (I regret not being there when there was a Mark Rothko exhibition.)
The building itself, designed by Frank Gehry, is a work of art itself. I recommend everyone to visit this museum when there's an exhibition, as they've never disappointed me. I'm studying conservation and restoration, and I have to admit that the exhibitions they put on here are incredibly impressive. They feature artworks from all over the world, a compelling narrative with clear explanations, and a very comprehensive selection of art from the artist(s)/collection currently on display.

I recommend buying a ticket online in advance, as it is simply convenient.

The art and the building itself are wonderful to see! The place is huge ‚Äî much bigger than I imagined ‚Äî and it‚Äôs such an enjoyable space to walk around. I spent about two hours exploring and still didn‚Äôt manage to see all the paintings. I wore heels, which I quickly realized wasn‚Äôt the best idea ‚Äî I‚Äôd definitely recommend wearing something more comfortable next time since the venue is quite large!

It is an art museum and cultural center designed by architect Frank Gehry and opened in October 2014. The initiator of its creation was Bernard Arnault, the head of the LVMH group, who, after visiting the Guggenheim Museum in Bilbao in 2001, suggested that Gehry build a chic Art Nouveau center. The project was officially announced in 2006, and construction was carried out from 2008 to 2014 on the territory of the Bois de Boulogne, on a site leased from the city of Paris for 55 years. The building is made in the deconstructivist style and consists of two main elements: the so-called "iceberg", formed by blocks of white ultra-strong concrete, and twelve giant glass "sails" with a total area of 13,500 m2, which seem to wrap around it. To implement this complex project, advanced 3D modeling technologies were used at that time, and each of the 3,600 glass and 19,000 concrete panels had to be manufactured individually. The 7,000 m2 building houses 11 exhibition galleries, 350-seat classrooms, a restaurant and multi-level terraces with views of the Eiffel Tower and La Defense Towers.
The Foundation promotes contemporary art by presenting works from its own collection by Bernard Arnault and LVMH, as well as organizing large temporary exhibitions.

The building is so pretty and modern! They also have a dedicated bus to take visitors there making easy to go, entrance was fast, there is plenty to see. If I may suggest some  things to improve is to expose a bigger variety of artists, and keep the cafe open until the place closes.

Highly recommended for architecture enthusiasts‚Äîthis is one of Frank Gehry‚Äôs most iconic works. The building itself is a masterpiece, blending bold design with natural light and sweeping curves. Booking tickets online is a smart move to avoid long queues

You do not need to buy tickets or reservations in advance.  I know there are tours you can sign up for,  but I did not do that.   I just showed up and stood in the line for those with no reservations.  It took maybe 25 minutes of waiting,  and once inside you are welcome to explore the church,  or sit and pray.  Lots to see inside, so beautiful.
This is a very special place.  Our Lady of the Fields is the patron saint of Glenmary Home Missioners.  We were able to add this stop in Paris to our pilgrimage

This is a church designed by Gustave Eiffel some 20 years prior to his work on the Eiffel Tower. We enjoyed a brief look around when passing by recently.

The exterior is imposing but modest, fronted with portal and rose window and backed by a bell tower.

The interior has good lighting and space. There are nice things to see including murals upon the walls of the nave and impressive stained-glass windows.

Worth a look around if you enjoy seeing old churches during your travels.
I stopped off here a few weeks ago while out walking and it's such a beautiful well kept church. It was also very peaceful inside even though there were alot of tourists but people were respectful.
Fav church, right on my street!

I did not know  there is such a big protestant church in the center of Paris, but once noticed, this gothic style church has its own beauty while it sure is solemn. Unfortunately I had no time to participate in Mass, but next time when I have a chance, I will.
Beautiful gothic style Eglise that you can visit along the way when you are strolling around Musee du Luvre or Jardin des Tuileries.
Beautiful architecture, impressive organ

The Oratoire du Louvre was originally a royal chapel, located extremely close to the Louvre.   It was given to the protestants by Napoleon.
It is one of the few domed churches in Paris.   You can also get into the "boxes" to see how the richer people worshipped.  There is a small yard and monumental sculpture along the Rue de Rivoli.   There is also an upstairs room that is round and has quite dramatic architectural features.

Come to pay a respect to Sainte Rita as she responded to my wish. Will definitely come back when I visit Paris.
Very cute

A beautiful wooden statue (I think) of Saint Rita and a contemporary chapel, a place of silence and contemplation. A charming little shop sells images with prayers. I love stopping by before heading up to Montmartre via Rue Lepic.
Magnificent, refined chapel with a magnificent statue of Saint Rita, the dearest saint of desperate causes!! Very simple, very sober, very clear, peaceful!!
Wonderful acoustics for great performances!

Definitely my favorite place for some divine silence and the sun just hits so beautifully at the entrance which is so inviting. I love the organs when they play and it just engulfs the whole ambience of the place !

Beautifully located and very meaningful. Dalida is Montmartre. Her personality is visible in many places,  while wandering around. I suggest to stop by the Buste de Dalida, take a rest and then walk down to the Cementary of Montmartre to pay a tribute to the place of eternal rest of Dalida.

Tucked into one of Montmartre‚Äôs quieter corners, Place Dalida and the Buste de Dalida felt like a small reward at the end of our uphill wandering. My wife and I had just taken a break at Square Suzanne Buisson, and from there we continued along Rue Simon Dereure, a lovely residential street lined with typical Parisian fa√ßades and small balconies filled with plants. The further we walked, the fewer tourists we saw, and Montmartre slowly shifted from busy postcard to lived-in neighbourhood.

At the end of Rue Simon Dereure a short staircase leads down to a narrow passageway. It‚Äôs not difficult, but it‚Äôs worth noting for anyone with mobility issues that there are steps and some uneven surfaces, so good shoes are definitely recommended. The alley itself feels almost secret, framed by stone walls and houses, and soon opens onto Place Dalida ‚Äì a small, cobbled square surrounded by trees and classic Montmartre buildings.

In the middle stands the Buste de Dalida, a bronze sculpture of the beloved singer set on a granite plinth. Dalida, who lived in Montmartre and became a true icon of French music from the 1950s onwards, is honoured here with a monument inaugurated in the late 1990s, sculpted by Aslan as a tribute from the city and her fans. The atmosphere is gentle and slightly nostalgic, as if the square were holding its breath for her. From this spot you also get a beautiful view of the dome of Sacr√©-C≈ìur in the distance, perfectly aligned with the sloping street and the lampposts ‚Äì a scene that begs to be photographed. We took our time capturing a few shots of us together with the basilica discreetly watching over the hill behind us.

Of course, we also joined in the little local tradition: gently touching the statue for good luck. It feels a bit playful and cheeky, but it‚Äôs part of the charm ‚Äì one of those small rituals that connect you, briefly, with all the other travellers who have passed through this tiny square.

There are no facilities directly on Place Dalida: no public toilets, caf√©s or shops on the square itself, which helps preserve the quiet atmosphere. The closest restrooms are back at Square Suzanne Buisson, so it‚Äôs good to plan a quick stop there if needed before continuing your walk. If you need to grab a coffee or a snack, you‚Äôll find plenty of options a short walk away on the busier streets of Montmartre ‚Äì especially toward Lamarck-Caulaincourt or Abbesses, both of which also have Metro stations that make the area easy to reach. Just be ready for slopes and stairs; Montmartre is beautiful but not the flattest part of Paris.

For us, this stop was less about ticking off a famous landmark and more about enjoying a small, intimate corner of the district. Standing there, with Dalida‚Äôs monument in front of us and Sacr√©-C≈ìur in the background, we had a few quiet minutes to breathe, smile, and simply enjoy being together in Montmartre.

If you‚Äôre already exploring the area, I would definitely recommend adding Place Dalida and the Buste de Dalida to your walking route. It‚Äôs a short detour that offers a mix of history, a touch of superstition, and one of those quietly romantic views that make Paris so memorable.

On a walking tour and we found this beautiful church in Paris, France. Below is the description from Wikipedia.

The¬†√âglise Saint-Paul-Saint-Louis¬†(French pronunciation:¬†[e…°liz¬†s…õÃÉ¬†p…îl¬†s…õÃÉ¬†lwi]) is a church on rue Saint-Antoine in the¬†Marais¬†quarter of¬†Paris. The present building was constructed from 1627 to 1641 by the¬†Jesuit¬†architects¬†√âtienne¬†and¬†Fran√ßois Derand, on the orders of¬†Louis XIII of France. It was the first church in Paris to break away entirely from the Gothic style and to use the new¬†Baroque style¬†of the Jesuits, and it had an important influence on Parisian religious architecture. It gives its name to¬†Place Saint-Paul¬†and its nearest Metro station,¬†Saint-Paul. Next door to the church is the¬†Lyc√©e Charlemagne, also founded by the Jesuits.

The Church of Saint-Paul in France is a place I thoroughly enjoyed visiting. This historic church in the heart of Le Marais and exudes a timeless and ancient spirit, making it unique. The serene atmosphere amazed me the moment I stepped in. The church's architecture, with its grand arches, intricate carvings, and stunning stained glass windows, reflects centuries of history and devotion.
What I found most enchanting about Saint-Paul Church was its quiet reverence. Despite being in a bustling city, it feels like a tranquil haven where you can reflect and connect with the past. The aged walls and soft light filtering through the windows create a calming and awe-inspiring environment.
Saint-Paul Church in Paris is a hidden gem for anyone interested in history and architecture. I enjoyed the sensation of stepping back in time and feeling the deep, ancient soul of this beautiful place.

Saint-Paul-Saint-Louis was built at 1600s. Its style marks a break in Paris from Gothic forms toward Baroque design, with an imposing fa√ßade of Corinthian and composite orders, a dome above the transept, and richly decorated sculptural ornamentation.
