Edit: The 12th arrondissement newspaper's statement "3000m2 returned to pedestrians" is laughable, whether you're for or against the works ü§£ If it were a square that had once been pedestrianized, maybe, but no pedestrian alive in 2025 will have known this square as a pedestrian zone ü§£

The 3-star rating is more of a weighted average of the old square and the new one taking shape üòÖ
The new square will surely have its advantages (greenery, more space for pedestrians) but its share of disadvantages in terms of traffic (if it doesn't improve) because the space for the four lanes (Boulevard de Reuilly, Avenue Daumesnil, Rue de Reuilly, etc.) is tiny...
One can question the relevance of massive works to redesign a square if the result falls somewhere between [rather worse; barely better].

The advantages I mentioned are quite relative considering the neighborhood, which is one of the richest in green spaces (Bois de Vincennes, Coul√©e Verte, Pelouse de Reuilly), very wide sidewalks (Avenue Daumesnil, etc.), in short, a pleasant neighborhood to live in, already well-spaced in terms of layout with smooth traffic flow.

PS: Photo taken upstream on Boulevard de Reuilly with a traffic jam that rivals that of Saint-Lazare.

Whether you're on foot, in a car, or on a bicycle, avoid this area if you can. The entire space is under construction, and work is at a standstill, particularly on the sidewalks, which are impassable. At the traffic lights, only two or three cars pass per bicycle. Buses are stuck. And it's no better for cyclists, since the only place pedestrians can get through is on the bike path.

A nightmare for everyone! Whether you're a driver, pedestrian, bus, or cyclist!

It used to work, it was great, and now it's unbearable, stressful, and inefficient! What's the point? I wonder!

It now takes 20 minutes to get through, whereas before it wasn't even an issue.

A beautiful square.
Construction is currently underway, which is causing noise and making it even more difficult to get around (pedestrians and public transport).
Once the work is completed, this square will regain all its charm.
Many shops are located in this area (restaurants, banks, supermarkets, bakeries, bookstores, stationery stores, opticians, etc.)

The new traffic pattern is dangerous and, above all, it blocks all traffic!
The entire neighborhood has seen its road network change in just a few months. The result? More traffic, more parking spaces‚Ä¶ how are we, the residents, supposed to live a normal daily life now? How are the local businesses going to operate, pay their bills and rent?! I wonder!

This decision doesn't just affect individuals with their cars, but also all delivery drivers, tradespeople, and even bus drivers! Whether I take the bus or my car, the journey has become impossible‚Äîa loss of at least 15 minutes compared to before!

The cathedral was opened in 1861. The architectural design was inspired by the Hagia Sophia in Constantinople, as well as the features of 17th-century Novgorod and Moscow architecture. The cathedral features a five-domed structure, with the five domes symbolizing Jesus Christ and the four evangelists, and the central dome reaching a height of 48 meters.
The interior of the cathedral, typical of Orthodox churches, is characterized by its abundance of gilding, frescoes, and ornate iconostasis.
The iconostasis for the lower Trinity Church was carved from oak and was moved from the former embassy church.
The cathedral is known for its rich history: Pablo Picasso and Olga Khokhlova were married here in 1918, and Ivan Bunin and Vera Muromtseva were married here in 1922.

"For over 130 years, this majestic church has stood as a silent witness to Parisian history, its walls echoing centuries of faith, art, and transformation. Located just steps from the iconic Champs-√âlys√©es and directly behind the Louis Vuitton flagship store, the √âglise Saint-Paul-Saint-Louis is a masterpiece of Jesuit Baroque architecture. Commissioned by King Louis XIII and built between 1627 and 1641, it marked a dramatic shift from Gothic to Baroque style in Paris. [Eglise Sai...ch), Paris]
The church‚Äôs fa√ßade, inspired by the Church of the Ges√π in Rome, features Corinthian columns and a striking bell tower. Inside, its lavish decoration was designed to contrast Protestant austerity, with a soaring 195-foot dome, stained glass windows, and a white marble altar that includes fragments from Napoleon‚Äôs tomb. Victor Hugo himself donated clam-shell holy water vessels in memory of his daughter. [Eglise Sai...ch), Paris]
Throughout its history, the church has endured revolution, repurposing, and restoration. It was once transformed into a 'Temple of Reason' during the French Revolution before being reinstated as a place of worship in 1802. Today, it remains a cultural and spiritual landmark, with some of its artworks‚Äîlike a Delacroix painting‚Äîoccasionally loaned to museums around the world. [Eglise Sai...ch), Paris]
A must-visit for anyone touring Paris, this architectural gem offers a profound glimpse into the city's layered past, nestled in the heart of Le Marais, just behind the glamour of modern luxury

Spanning 3,687 m¬≤, this square features a fountain built for the International Colonial Exhibition held at the Porte Dor√©e in 1931. Its name refers to the French colonial officer and administrator, Joost van Vollenhoven (1877-1918), who opposed the additional recruitment of indigenous troops during the Great War and died on the field of honor in 1917.

The Church of Saint-S√©verin in Paris, or √âglise Saint-S√©verin, is located in the heart of the Latin Quarter and is one of the oldest surviving parish churches on the left bank of the Seine.
Its history dates back to the early Middle Ages, when a small chapel was built on this site in honor of Saint S√©verin, a hermit who lived here in the 6th century. Since then, the first church has been established here. The current building primarily dates back to the 15th and 16th centuries and is an outstanding example of Gothic architecture in the Parisian school. The church was repeatedly rebuilt after fires and destruction, especially in the 12th and 15th centuries, resulting in a combination of early Gothic and late Gothic elements. One of the most impressive architectural features is the exquisite column in the choral area, which resembles a twisted trunk and symbolizes the Tree of Life. The church also features elegant stained glass windows, including both medieval and modern designs from the 20th century.
The church is famous not only for its architecture, but also for its spiritual atmosphere: for centuries, students and scholars from the Latin Quarter have prayed here, and the organ of √âglise Saint-S√©verin is considered one of the best in Paris and is regularly used for concerts.
The church has well-preserved authentic features of Gothic Paris, almost untouched by time. It's like traveling back in time - walking under the vaults, seeing the darkened columns, especially when evening falls and you find yourself stepping out of the bustling pace of city life.

An impressive looking church both inside and out! Fancy stonework litters the building as well as numerous pieces of art integrated within. The building is also physically quite large and the backrooms are accessible and numerous!

The interior of the church is of the hall type, with a length of almost 70 meters and a width of about 30 meters.
The most notable feature of the interior is the ambo, or rud-screen, which is a transverse hanging gallery with a delicate balustrade and two elegant spiral staircases on either side. This masterpiece, created in the 1520s, is the last surviving ambo in Paris.

Our quiet morning visit to this remarkable church became one of the most magical moments of our trip. Arriving early while it was still peacefully empty allowed us to fully absorb the sacred atmosphere - an experience nothing short of spiritual awakening.

Every detail, from the shimmering stained glass to the echoing silence, felt like a carefully preserved secret. This isn't just a church - it's a little gem that radiates timeless beauty in the heart of the district.

For those seeking a moment of tranquility away from the crowds, this sanctuary offers pure magic in its most unassuming form.

First building we found coming out of the subway. Unassuming but totally beautiful inside! Situated at the foot of Montmartre, it was built from 1894 to 1904. It is notable for its innovative use of reinforced concrete, a pioneering technique championed by architect Anatole de Baudot. The church blends Art Nouveau aesthetics, characterized by organic forms and decorative ceramic tilework, with Gothic structural elements such as pointed arches. Its iron frame and fa√ßade distinguish it from traditional Parisian churches, reflecting early 20th-century architectural experimentation.[1][2]

The totality of the church was classified as a historic monument on 9 September 2014.[3]

A stunning example of Parisian architecture, Pont d'Austerlitz is a must-visit for anyone visiting the City of Lights. This iconic bridge offers breathtaking views of the Seine River and the surrounding cityscape. The ambiance is peaceful and romantic, making it an ideal spot for a leisurely stroll or a picnic with loved ones.

The bridge's design is a perfect blend of historical and modern elements, making it an architectural masterpiece. The service provided by the staff is excellent, and they go out of their way to make visitors feel welcome. The bridge is well-maintained, and the quality of the experience offered is exceptional.

What sets Pont d'Austerlitz apart from other bridges in Paris is its unique history and location. It was constructed in the early 1800s, making it one of the oldest bridges in the city. It connects the 5th and 12th arrondissements and provides a crucial transportation link between the two.

There are no complaints or criticisms about this beautiful bridge, making it worthy of a perfect 5-star rating. However, it would be even better if more seating areas were added for visitors to relax and enjoy the views.

Overall, I would highly recommend Pont d'Austerlitz to anyone looking for a quintessential Parisian experience. This bridge is a true gem in the heart of the city, and I will undoubtedly return in the future. Thank you to the owners and staff for maintaining such a beautiful landmark.
There are so many historic bridges in Paris. This one was fun to wall over. Every bridge has its own story and views.

What a beautiful church. On Rue Saint-Denis it was one of the churches that was part of the pilgrimage to Saint Denis. Built on the site of a 1120 Abbey. Multilingual information about the church's history and art are available.

Saint-Leu-Saint-Gilles de Paris is a Roman Catholic parish church in the 1st arrondissement of Paris. It has housed the relics of Empress Saint Helena, mother of Emperor Constantine, for 200 years. Helena was an important person and there are still many visitors to the church precisely because of her. In 1915, the French Ministry of Culture classified it as a monument of historical value.

This is a Roman Catholic parish church on Rue Saint Denis in the 1st District of Paris. It is not far north of Pompidou and can be conveniently viewed when sightseeing in the area.

Originally constructed in the 13th-century, numerous enlargements and modifications took place up until 1780, providing the bulk of the present church you see today. Recent church history is also much associated with the relics of Saint Helena, mother of early 4th-century ruler Emperor Constantine, which were transferred to the church in the late 19th century.

Due to the narrow street in front of the church, it is a bit challenging to appreciate the facade and immediate exterior of Eglise Saint-Leu-Saint-Gilles. However, you can enjoy a simple Gothic facade with side turrets on both sides of the entrance.

We further found the interior to be quite dark throughout. You can walk through the nave, viewing a fine alter with surrounding decoratively carved columns and a nicely carved pulpit. However, it was rather difficult taking pictures due to poor light conditions on the day.

There are nice stained-glass windows to see. However, quite a few within the upper level of the church were missing, at present being replaced with temporary clear glass panes. Would be nice to see the interior with replacements window panes at some point in the future.

In the end, we liked Eglise Saint-Leu-Saint-Gilles but found it more difficult to enjoy given the dark conditions on the day we visited. Will have to give her another visit in the future so that we can better view and appreciate the church.

This former railway bridge, nearly 190 meters long, rests on five masonry arches, where two superb "N"s are carved into the white stone.

One might think this letter refers to the word "National," but it does not.

It echoes the former name of this imperial structure, built in 1853 by Baron Haussmann to connect the old Thiers fortifications located on either side of the river, which have since disappeared.

Inaugurated as the "Pont Napol√©on III," it retained this name until 1870, when, following the defeat against Prussia, it was renamed "Pont National" in memory of the 1848 Revolution. The bridge still bears the remains of the old railway line known as the "Petite Couronne," which once connected the Batignolles station (now Pont-Cardinet) and the Austerlitz station (formerly Orl√©ans).

Built in 1853 under Napoleon III, the Pont National is one of the longest bridges in Paris. It connects the 12th and 13th arrondissements and is part of the inner ring road. It was widened to accommodate the T3 tramway. Its massive, functional architecture reflects its purely utilitarian purpose.

Pont National...we must erase the history of this bridge. The magnificent N engraved in the white stone is perhaps too reminiscent of its founders: Baron Haussmann and Emperor Napoleon III. Such is history and political correctness. Visit it day or night.

A Hidden Gothic Gem in the Heart of Paris

Located just a few steps from the famous Centre Pompidou, √âglise Saint-Merri is one of the oldest and most beautiful Gothic churches in Paris. It was built between 1515 and 1612 and named after Saint Mederic (Saint Merri), a 7th-century priest who lived and was buried here.

The church is known for its stunning Gothic architecture, stone carvings, and colorful stained-glass windows. Inside, visitors can enjoy peaceful prayer, organ concerts, and a glimpse of Paris‚Äôs medieval spirit.

Unfortunately, like many historical monuments, it faces restoration challenges, but it still remains a beloved spiritual and cultural spot for locals and tourists alike.

üïç Address: 76 Rue de la Verrerie, 75004 Paris, France
üöá Nearest Metro:

H√¥tel de Ville (Lines 1 and 11) ‚Äì 3 minutes walk

Ch√¢telet (Lines 1, 4, 7, 11, 14 & RER A, B, D) ‚Äì 5 minutes walk

üöå Nearby Bus Stops:

Lines 67, 69, 70, 74, 75, 76, 96 all stop near H√¥tel de Ville.

üìÖ Best time to visit: Morning or late afternoon for soft sunlight and fewer crowds.
üé∂ Tip: Try to visit during an organ concert‚Äîit‚Äôs truly magical!

If you ever find yourself wandering around Montmartre in Paris, there‚Äôs a really cool spot you shouldn‚Äôt miss - the Wall of ‚ÄúI Love You‚Äù (Le Mur des Je t‚Äôaime). It‚Äôs basically a huge wall covered with the phrase ‚ÄúI love you‚Äù written in over 300 different languages. Yeah, it‚Äôs pretty much a love explosion! The wall was created by two artists, Fr√©d√©ric Baron and Claire Kito, who wanted to create a place celebrating love in all its forms and languages. It‚Äôs located in a small square called Jehan Rictus Square, tucked away near the famous Sacr√©-C≈ìur Basilica.

The wall itself is made of blue tiles with the words painted in white and red, and it‚Äôs about 40 square meters in size. What‚Äôs really special about it is that it‚Äôs not just for couples, it‚Äôs for everyone who believes in love, whether that‚Äôs romantic love, friendship, or just a general good vibe. Visitors often stop by to take selfies, leave notes, or just soak in the positive energy. It‚Äôs a perfect spot for a chill moment during a busy day of sightseeing.

So, if you‚Äôre in Montmartre, make sure to swing by the Wall of ‚ÄúI Love You.‚Äù It‚Äôs a simple, sweet reminder that love is universal, and it‚Äôs found in every language around the world.

1 - View from the Rue Dieu swing bridge.
2 - View of the Rue Dieu swing bridge, which, following a deliberation by the Paris Council in early October 2024, became the Bernadette Lafont Bridge, named after the late famous French actress.

Bernadette Lafont Bridge - (since 25/09/2024 - formerly the Rue Dieu swing bridge)

It crosses the basin of the Canal Saint-Martin, near the Allibert footbridge.

HISTORY OF THE CANAL SAINT-MARTIN:
4.5 km long, including more than 2 km underground, the canal connects the Bassin de la Villette to the Seine with a drop of 25 meters.
Inaugurated in 1825, it has 9 locks, two swing bridges, and a lift bridge. It is open to navigation 365 days a year. All locks are manned.

Construction of the 4.5-km-long Canal Saint-Martin began in 1805 at both ends, but was not completed until 1825 due to the difficulty of fitting such a structure into an already heavily urbanized site.

During the Second Empire, Prefect Haussmann, wishing to create the Boulevard du Prince-Eug√®ne (Boulevard Voltaire), encountered difficulties with the canal's presence, which would have required a movable bridge, an unacceptable feat for a major road intended to carry heavy traffic.
Engineer Belgrand solved the problem by moving the Bastille locks approximately two kilometers upstream, which lowered the canal between the Bastille and Rue du Faubourg-du-Temple by approximately five meters, thus allowing for the construction of a fixed bridge to cross the new boulevard. Deepening the canal created a trench and eliminated all ports.

Prefect Haussmann therefore decided to complete the project by covering the canal with an arch between the Bastille and Avenue de la R√©publique, thus creating Boulevard Richard-Lenoir. The entire project was completed between 1860 and 1862.
In 1906, work on covering the Canal Saint-Martin resumed. A new arch, the Temple Arch, was built as an extension of the Richard-Lenoir Arch. Thus, Boulevard Jules-Ferry was born.
The section that remained open to the sky was rebuilt in 1890 and redeveloped in 1999 and 2002.

Two swing bridges (Bernadette-Lafont Bridge - formerly the Rue Dieu Swing Bridge and Maria Pac√¥me Bridge - formerly the Grange aux Belles Bridge) and a lifting bridge (the Crim√©e Bridge) replaced the old wooden structures towards the end of the 19th century.

The famous footbridges date from the second half of the nineteenth century.
Note that the Arsenal Basin connects the Canal Saint-Martin to the Seine, between the Quai de la Rap√©e and the Place de la Bastille.
It was once a cargo port; today, it is a marina.

CINEMA:
It is on this famous canal and in this neighborhood that Marcel Carn√©'s famous 1938 film, "H√¥tel du Nord," and its famous line between Arletty and Louis Jouvet, "Atmosphere, atmosphere, do I have an atmospheric face...", are supposed to have taken place.

The film was shot entirely in the studios and the reconstructed hotel. All by Alexandre Trauner, one of the most famous production designers in world cinema.

PERSONAL ANECDOTES:

I lived not far away many years ago, on the other side of Place de la R√©publique, on the edge of the Marais.

The fl√¢neurs are disrespectful of the place and the community.

I'd dreamed of seeing a Shakespeare play at this theater for twelve years. For various reasons, I hadn't yet had the opportunity. Last weekend, I was finally able to realize this dream with my husband. The venue is absolutely magnificent, magical, and the cast far exceeded my expectations. The welcome at the refreshment bar was also very warm.

I would first like to thank the team for this wonderful experience. However, I would like to share a small criticism that, unfortunately, somewhat tarnished the experience.

This summer's sun was particularly intense, and I suffered greatly from the heat during the performance, despite the charming little straw hats provided by the theater. I am undergoing medical treatment that increases my sensitivity to the sun, and I have a disability that makes it difficult for me to sit on the floor. A few minutes before the end of the show, having no water and feeling very uncomfortable, I sat in a shaded corner of the stage with a beer (purchased at the refreshment bar, where I had been told it was permitted to drink during the play).

At the end of the performance, I wanted to sincerely thank one of the actors for the quality of the performance. Unfortunately, this moment turned into a public reprimand, as the actor criticized me for my disrespect by sitting in an area visible from the stage. I want to point out that no one on the staff had indicated to me that my presence in that area was a problem. If this was perceived as a lack of consideration, I deeply apologize. My gesture was not intentional; it was simply a reaction to genuine physical discomfort.

Perhaps in the future, in such weather conditions, it would be possible to provide a few additional shaded areas for the audience. This would help avoid this type of misunderstanding and preserve the magic of this wonderful experience.

Once again, thank you to the entire team, and my sincere apologies to the cast.

Having made it my goal to pray in all the churches in Paris, yesterday I decided to go to this church to thank the Lord at Our Lady of the Hostages for the release of the hostages in the Middle East.
Our Lady of the Hostages is located on a random street in the 20th arrondissement, and you have to go there intentionally OR because God is calling you there, because honestly, you hardly see it. I live in the suburbs, not really nearby. The church is quite small, and the interior is simple, with pretty stained-glass windows and little corners that you don't see, but they are the most wonderful. I'm glad I went there because I love Jesus, who sacrificed himself to save us, and there's only one person in this church. One is already a lot, but honestly, I was overwhelmed because I felt like I was being abandoned. So bring it to life and go there! Go there. The Lord is waiting for you there too.

A church that I really enjoyed visiting, due to its austere, simple but radiant architecture. The guided tour offered by the Art, Culture and Faith association allows us to connect the history of this church to that of Paris (during the period of the Paris Commune, with the bloody riots), and allows us to understand all the symbolism hidden within this building. Many thanks to the priest who gave us the tour, and then allowed us to enter the parish property, in order to admire the remains of this period, presented during the visit. I have very good memories of it.

Numerous successive chapels have been built since 1894 on land belonging to the Jesuits, commemorating the memory of the 52 hostages executed on May 26, 1871, on this site during Bloody Week during the Paris Commune. In 1932, Jesuit Father Henri Diffin√© proposed building a church, which was quickly completed in 1938 in the Art Deco style based on plans by architect Julien Barbier. It was inaugurated the same year by Cardinal Verdier.
This church was established as a parish in 1961 and was not consecrated by the Auxiliary Bishop of Paris, √âric de Moulins-Beaufort, until 2009.

A vast, beautifully landscaped garden with play areas and quiet spaces.
The extension of the garden and the creation of the Marthe Condat pedestrian path in 2024 now connect the Debergue and Arnold Netter neighborhoods. A shaded, curved path leads to the heart of the garden, which consists of a vast lawn and a green enclosure. Circular economy and heritage are combined with the reuse of stone benches and mascarons from the Pont-Neuf. The composition of different environments, wet and dry, offers varied landscaped atmospheres and promotes the development of biodiversity.
This garden, formerly Debergue - Rendez-Vous, was renamed in 2024 after Solange Falad√© (1925-2004), a Franco-Beninese physician, anthropologist, and psychoanalyst.

First visit for my uncle's funeral. Difficult. I appreciated the beauty of the newly renovated place, the quality of the welcome, and the attentiveness of the priest who celebrated the ceremony. Thank you.

A remnant of the 18th-century Wall of the Farmers General, the North Toll Gate of the Barri√®re du Tr√¥ne, with the identical South Toll Gate opposite it, is one of four monuments of this Wall of the Farmers General remaining in Paris. The interweaving of the superimposed geometric volumes is striking, the arches are majestic. Grand style for common buildings. This is the style of the brilliant, visionary architect of the late 18th century, Claude-Nicolas Ledoux, a precursor of modern architecture, the author, among other things, of unrealized projects of great creative audacity.
The golden age of interregional agricultural customs!!!

Mosqu√©e Omar Ibn Al Khattab in Paris offers a serene and welcoming environment for prayer and reflection. Its clean facilities and dedicated staff create a peaceful atmosphere for worshippers. A valuable community hub for spiritual growth and connection.
Welcoming! We are from the US. My son asked if could see a mosque. Here it was. We respectfully enter and it was an amazing positive experience.
Very convenient and clean mosque but on Friday every jumma prayer there are multiple Jamat because of the high demand.

This round square, dating from the early 20th century, is located in the 12th arrondissement at the intersection of an avenue, a boulevard, and a street; right next to the Picpus metro station (line 6).
It features a fountain in its center (its origin is unknown) surrounded by benches and vegetation.
This square is a reminder that Georges Moineaux, alias Courteline, whose bust stands on a column just opposite, lived from 1907 until his death in 1929 in a nearby building. A commemorative plaque commemorates this.
This square includes a central fountain, eight surrounding benches, and trees.

But it's at the end of the year that the fountain truly captures the eye and attention, when it dons its most beautiful finery for the holidays!

It's truly enchanting. It attracts people who, in the evening, will enjoy the illumination and admire the pearls of light that drip like pearls of water!
Not necessarily very quiet since it is located in the middle of a large avenue but very pretty
Very nice at the "change" of seasons when not too busy...
Not much of interest. Very small and right in the middle of the road.
I like this very nice place

Located near Bercy Seine station and Seine River, this library offers an impressive view, and the building itself is quite striking. The access to the library is easy and well-organized.

They host interesting events and exhibitions from time to time, which adds to the cultural experience. The collection is vast, providing great access to a variety of books, manuscripts, and historical documents. However, if you want to access specific manuscripts, you‚Äôll need to prove you‚Äôre actively working or researching on a particular topic, which ensures serious academic use. Highly recommended for both casual visits and research purposes.

What‚Äôs the point of calling yourself a library when you can‚Äôt even borrow books and the books aren‚Äôt always accessible to the public‚Ä¶

For the biggest library in Paris it‚Äôs a really stupid state to have it full of high security when you can‚Äôt even access anything on a Monday‚Ä¶ the place leaves much to be Desired looks run down in certain areas and the toilets are not clean. I find really shocking that they can just close areas of books and without warning and force everyone to work in the hallways and entryways‚Ä¶
Would not recommend.

It's heartbreaking to give such a low rating to one of my favorite places, but it's a shame that visitors are so badly informed about the normal functioning of the library.

What makes me rate it a two, though, is the despicable security at the top entrance. Sorry, it makes me feel better to say it, but even knowing that those guards have a difficult job, one just yelled at everyone asking for info (Info! Are you kidding!?), shouting, "Go to the line like everyone!" (He even yelled this at those who went to the MK2 cinema... "Go to the line!! Oh... okay, you can go... but watch out! I see you!").

Many of us are occasional visitors with specific research to do, and at the lower entrance, a few of us were misinformed, being told it opened at 13:00. An error is human, and this lady was nice! But then the upper guard shouted for "everyone up!". When we asked about the time, his first reflex was to yell, "Go to the line!" before finally explaining that it opened at 14:00.

He didn't tell us, though, that only the administrative area was open and that no books were accessible. That was one hour and a half lost, not counting the other hour and a half to get there. (My fault, I should have looked at the website, but some clear information while we waited would have saved a lot of time for many people!)

This is a really interesting national library‚ÄîI highly recommend taking the time to explore different parts of it inside. The architecture of the outside is fantastic, and it is really interesting to look at from the outside and from the observatory area inside. It is a good place to study; I often sat near the caf√©.

The library has interesting exhibitions and a cute gift shop with post cards that feature works of art in the library's archives; unfortunately, a tote bag I bought from the gift shop broke after only two days of use.

Great place to achieve knowledge in a very calm way.Having a garden in the middle of the library.Huge space for working as a person or in a group.Variety collections of books made it magnificent places to visit or work purpose.Having a lovely terrace inside wow!I love that view from terrace.Before entry you gonna get a glimpse touch of architecture around wow magical place.Beside this one part of BNF has a wonderful view covering Seine.Had a session there was less in time but worthy.Recommended if you somehow manage to pass by you should have a look in Biblioth√®que National Franceüá´üá∑

The Invalides Bridge (Pont des Invalides) in Paris is a beautiful and historic spot that offers stunning views of the Seine and the Eiffel Tower. It‚Äôs less crowded than some of the other bridges, making it a peaceful place to walk or take photos. The architecture is impressive, and it's especially lovely at sunset when the whole area glows with golden light. It's a great place for a leisurely stroll, and you can easily connect to nearby attractions like Les Invalides and the Champs-√âlys√©es. Definitely worth a visit!

This bridge over the Seine is quite an oddity in that it does not relate to a person or location. It is close to Les Invalides but does not lead to it. Either side has large decorative figurines sticking out from the pillars.
Much less crowded than nearby bridges.
Pont des Invalides is the lowest bridge over the River Seine.

The worst behavior that happened to me yesterday was during the entire day in this church by the person in charge of selling concert tickets! The moment the ticket was in my hands, my credit card declared the transaction failed. The moment he realized this, he snatched the ticket from my hands with such haste and anger that he almost cut the edges of the paper off my hand. As if I was going to run away without paying! And when I told him why he was behaving like this and now I'm going to pay again, he simply replied:
"That's how it is!!!"

It's very shameful for a church to place such people in charge!

On Avenue Mozart stands the private mansion that Guimard had built in 1909 for himself and his wife, Adeline Oppenheim, an American painter. He established their home, his architectural practice, and his wife's studio there.
A remarkable building that surprises with its random distribution of windows and balconies, positioned differently depending on the floor or facade. It was one of his finest creations, as he approached his fifties and Art Nouveau was beginning to fade.
The Villa Flore, to the right of the mansion, is also a work by Guimard and marks a conversion of the architect, who experimented with Art Deco.
Honest, down-to-earth, gospel centred congregation. Felt welcomed and good to be in the presence of brothers and sisters in Christ.  Thanks!

A church firmly focused on the Word of God, multicultural and socially active.
Bible discovery tours are available. Sunday services at 10:30 a.m. feature a time of worship with songs and a time of biblical meditation. The reception team will be available to assist you every Sunday starting at 10:30 a.m.

Simply put, the Word of our Lord applies here.

A warm welcome for all, including non-believers.

Very underrated museum. So much to see here from tombs and crypts of famous people, to museums about france's army and WW2.

Beautiful Cathedral in Paris. It is a separate entrance from Napoleons Tomb, but you can see some of the church through the glass. The church is focused on the French Military and was built in the 1600‚Äôs. Amazing statues, art work, and structure. I really enjoyed the architecture. It has a veterans chapel and the graves of many officers from the French Military. We really enjoyed the visit. A must see in Paris if you enjoy history.

This beautiful cathedral is located inside Les Invalides. It is also known as the soldiers church. There are banners of many of the defeated armies hanging. The back wall behind the altar is glass and you can see through to Napoleon‚Äôs Tomb which backs on to it.
Yet another great piece of French architecture, and you don‚Äôt need to buy tickets for the cathedral, which houses Napoleon‚Äôs tomb.

It was very challenging to find the entry points. Once you do, you have to go through security checks. Once you pass the security checks, you can choose where to go because there are other attractions like the army museum and so on. We wanted to go to the Cathedral because it was free and other attractions were not. The Cathedral resembles a pro war atmosphere perhaps because it is for the military. The architecture is remarkable. The art and information provided is great. The places are clearly marked. The Rotonde de la Villette is a historic building located in the 19th arrondissement of Paris, France. It is situated in the Parc de la Villette, a large public park in the northeastern part of the city.

The Rotonde de la Villette was originally built in the 1780s as a toll gate for the entrance to the city of Paris. It served as one of the gateways to the city, collecting taxes from merchants and travelers entering through the Villette neighborhood. The building was designed by Claude-Nicolas Ledoux, a prominent architect of the time known for his neoclassical style.

Today, the Rotonde de la Villette serves as a cultural and artistic venue within the Parc de la Villette. The building has been restored and transformed into a multipurpose space that hosts various events, exhibitions, and performances throughout the year. It is managed by the Parc de la Villette and is a popular destination for both locals and tourists.

The Rotonde de la Villette is characterized by its circular shape and impressive architectural features. It has a neoclassical design, with columns, pilasters, and a prominent dome. The building is made of stone and stands out amidst the greenery of the park.

Within the Rotonde de la Villette, you can find a caf√© and restaurant, which provide a pleasant place to relax and enjoy a meal or a drink. The venue also houses a theater, where you can catch performances ranging from theater plays to concerts and dance shows.

The Parc de la Villette itself is a vibrant cultural and recreational hub in Paris. It offers a wide range of activities, including gardens, playgrounds, outdoor cinema screenings, music festivals, and interactive exhibitions. The park is also home to several other notable architectural structures, such as the Cit√© des Sciences et de l'Industrie (Science and Industry Museum) and the Philharmonie de Paris (a concert hall).

The Rotonde de la Villette, with its historical significance and cultural offerings, is a must-visit attraction in Paris. Whether you're interested in history, art, or simply enjoying the beauty of the park, the Rotonde de la Villette offers a unique and enriching experience.
Very pretty, a bit scary at night

Excellent exhibition of Willy Ronis's work on show here till end of September 2018. The printing of the images is outstanding and are also beautifully presented . A must see et it's free.
Good experience but I strongly suggest not hanging pictures/exhibits on the stairs‚Äô walls as it can make difficult for people to go up/down and focus on the artwork at he same time.
Amazing spot right next to Grand Palais and Petite Palais. Great place to go for a walk!

Located within Place Clemenceau, next to the Champs √âlys√©es, stands this statue of the great french General, depicting him walking down the the famous boulevard, after the liberation of Paris, on the 26th of august 1944.
Very just tribute to a man who had the relevant role for the end of the WWII and for the final victory over the nazi forces. The french people recognizes such honor for whom deserves.
Monument dedicated to French president Charles de Gaulle.
Here near the palace in the garden is a statue of Churchill and close by is this magnificent statue of General Charles de Gaulle. A masterpiece.

Our collaboration with Alvine, which lasted 18 months, with the wedding in July 2021, was very positive.
Despite abandoning our choice of venue just before the lockdown, Alvine was able to find us another venue that met our criteria during the restrictions.
Overall, her responsiveness, her choice of vendors, her availability, and her advice throughout the planning process made it possible to create a wedding that perfectly matched our wishes.
Her presence behind the scenes on the big day was efficient and allowed us to fully enjoy the event.
In addition to being professional, Alvine is very pleasant and was able to guide us with good humor during this very important event in a couple's life.

My wedding was organized by the Moments d'√©motion agency in May.

Alvine was extremely helpful and available throughout the planning of the big day!!!
All our expectations were met; the decor was superb, exactly as we had imagined.
I highly recommend the services of this agency, which knows how to adapt to everyone's tastes ;)

Our wedding was a truly wonderful and emotional experience, with Alvine handling everything and listening to our every wish.

From the initial planning stages to the big day itself, she made it her mission to meet our needs and even exceed them.

Although our budget wasn't large, we clearly had a fairytale wedding, and that's all thanks to Alvine.

The service was so exceptional that our guests also requested her services. This was the best possible showcase of her expertise!

I highly recommend her and will continue to recommend her to anyone who wants to make their wedding a truly unique and emotional experience.

Nicolas

As a photographer, I have participated in many weddings and observed their organization. I must admit that I was delighted to meet Alvine and his team and discover their work as wedding planners, from the choice of the castle, to the decoration, catering, music and most importantly... the atmosphere of good humor and joy. Bravo and thank you again for this beautiful day Alvine!

We called on Alvine to organize:
- The decorations
- The day-of coordination
Several negative elements emerged:
We met Alvine three weeks before the wedding to hand over all the decorations we had purchased.
We spent a fortune buying decorations (including 80 lanterns). These were supposed to be displayed in the hall, but despite Alvine's visits to the wedding venue, she realized at the last minute that it was impossible to put them up high and hadn't anticipated this. So at 11 p.m., she started putting them up in the grounds in front of the guests...
We had ordered a canvas that was to be at the entrance to our reception venue, but there was no sign of the canvas.
We had planned to display about ten signs; none were displayed at the wedding venue.
During the installation of the secular ceremony, one of our guests helped her set up some equipment. (Even though everything was supposed to be ready before the guests arrived)
Our friends and family told us that Alvine had been extremely aggressive and disorganized during the telephone preparation of the surprises.
And so on!!!
Alvine justified herself by email after the wedding, telling us that she had planned additional decorative elements, and that we should thank her for that, and that it was the Domaine's fault if everything wasn't ready because the Domaine was obviously late on many things... we later received confirmation from the Domaine that the on-site managers were indeed on time and that it was indeed Alvine who was late.
In short, we are extremely disappointed with this service provider and we definitely do not recommend them.

Go quickly before they're all gone; they're on sale this weekend, November 15, 2025. A little pricey‚Äî‚Ç¨2.50 each, after all‚Äîthat's the only downside, but oh well‚Ä¶ it's for a good cause.

Having always visited churches only for their architectural value, at 70 I embarked on a journey to draw closer to God. The choice of church was therefore very important! I could easily have felt out of place and gone back to where I came from.
Father Alexandre, Sister Myriam, and the entire team of catechists welcomed me so warmly that I now attend Mass with great joy and visit this lovely chapel whenever I can. Many events are offered there outside of services (lunch, dinner, gatherings in the gardens during the warmer months, and the sale of delicious spring rolls made by the sisters themselves), so you have the wonderful feeling of belonging to a caring and peaceful group, and that makes all the difference!
Thank you to the priests and the Little Sisters for surrounding us with such kindness.

Dear Hospital Urgency Team,

We want to express our heartfelt gratitude for the outstanding care my son received during our emergency visit to Paris. Your team's kindness, expertise, and patience were truly remarkable, especially given our language barrier. We're so thankful to have been in such capable hands. Thank you to each doctor, nurse, and staff member who contributed to his care. Your compassion and professionalism made a difficult situation much more manageable. We're forever grateful.

We came with a 6 week old with  bad chest. After doing tests including an invasive eurethra cord to take a urine sample (which we hadn't agreed to) then we were bundled in a room at around midnight and told to wait a while for the rest results.

We asked at 5 am how long we should expect to wait. We were told the doctor would come in at 9:30am or so.

Complete joke. We were standing in a room with the baby. Eventually after 5:30 they decided to bring chairs. - this was after I had said it was completely unacceptable to not have given us notice of how long the results would take.

Staff kept dropping stuff and were very busy playing candy crush

My five year old son broke his arm while we were on vacation in Paris. We went to urgent care here and they were all so kind, so helpful, and it was all as quick and efficient as possible, given the circumstances. They even spoke English pretty well. The icing on the cake- two older women (volunteers maybe?) came to the waiting room with toys and a play table and entertained my 3 other young children for as long as we needed to take care of our boy. They literally babysat for us, it was wild. So grateful!

The garden is surrounded by office buildings housing innovative biotechnology companies. Called Biopark, this complex gives its name to the garden, structured by a network of 32 Chinese soap trees. Climbing plants scale the railings located on the building's facades.

Although the idea of sitting quietly may seem appealing, in reality, true silence does not linger for long.
The presence of water adds a gentle, soothing quality to the surroundings, enhancing the sense of calm.
The park offers a clear, unbroken view that stretches across its entire expanse, inviting contemplation and relaxation.

Probably the most vigorous water spouting fountain in Paris. Nice little stop after the big park visit. From wiki"The¬†Fontaine de l'Observatoire¬†is a monumental fountain located in the Jardin Marco Polo, south of the¬†Jardin du Luxembourg¬†in the¬†6th arrondissement¬†of Paris, with sculpture by¬†Jean-Baptiste Carpeaux. It was dedicated in 1874. It is also known as the¬†Fontaine des Quatre-Parties-du-Monde, for the¬†four parts of the world¬†embodied by its female figures, or simply the¬†Fontaine Carpeaux."

Walking into the entrance of the Jardin des Grands-Explorateurs, (grand explorers garden), our breath was literally taken away with the sight of this stunning fountain, that is dedicated to the four corners of the earth, definitely a must see when in the area.

This is the fountain monument situated at the southern end of the Garden of the Grand Explorers. It was designed by Gabriel Davioud and features striking sculptural work by Jean-Baptiste Carpeaux and colleagues. The fountain was unveiled in 1874.

What you see is a bronze sphere being held by four females representing (Europe, Asia, Africa and America). They each twist and contort themselves while holding the sphere upward. From below horses rise from the basin. Water spouts from dolphins and turtles evenly spaced within the basin.

It is a nice fountain monument well worth spending a few minutes to enjoy if planning to pass by the  Garden of the Grand Explorers.
Beautiful fountain leading to the magnificent Luxembourg garden. Must visit while in Paris
Bhaskar.. very well doing.. superb.. excellent..parlour also ...nice..loved..it..

A square located in the center of a group of residential buildings. It features beautiful playgrounds.
In conjunction with the rehabilitation of the surrounding buildings, Salamandre Square has been undergoing a complete redevelopment since late 2020. The heart of the square will open in the summer of 2021, and the access roads and in-ground planters at the foot of the buildings will be completed in the fall of 2021. Playgrounds, ball games, apparatus, and a table football table adjoin accessible lawns with benches, designed for relaxation. Trees‚ÄîJapanese privet, hawthorn, mountain ash, flowering ash, and Napoleon pine‚Äîprovide gentle shade. Shrubs and perennials provide gentle partitioning between the different parts of the garden.

Amazing art, and several interesting new exhibits were on display. I was very thrilled to find the works of Pablo Picasso. I wish I could have spent more time there, I'd definitely go back asap and dedicate 3-5 hours in order to get the full experience.
Beautiful museum with amazing displays and art work. Very kind staff and not too busy compared to the other more famous ones. I would 100% recommend visiting.
Every gallery in the museum was open and filled with gorgeous art. The special exhibition of Georges Condo was phenomenal.

The Mus√©e d‚ÄôArt Moderne de Paris is one of my top three modern art museums in Europe.

The collection is rich and varied: from masters such as Picasso, Utrillo, Matisse and Fernand L√©ger, to lesser-known artists whose works are equally remarkable.

Personally, as a Japanese visitor, I was delighted to find that the museum also holds a piece by L√©onard Foujita (Tsuguharu Fujita).
Free admission. Friendly staff. Beautiful layout. Very cool ouvr√©s!! Highly recommend! They also have free lockers for your stuff if you don't want to carry it around whilst enjoying the museum.
A lovely garden area, located near the canal, with its plenty of seating perfect place to rest before venturing to the chaos of Marche Joinville.
Playground, lots of benches, small library (adults books usually). Beautiful flowers, canopy, church.
Great place to relax in the 19th arrondissement of Paris

What an utterly splendid experience. The guided tour was nothing short of a theatrical performance, riveting from start to finish. The young lady conducting the tour delivered over an hour of engaging and impassioned narration. To call it a ‚Äúguide‚Äù would be an injustice; it was, in essence, a masterclass in performance art.

Though the commentary was primarily in French, I was able to glean roughly half the content through real-time translation. Alas, my grasp of French is limited, but even so, the quality and charisma of her delivery were unmistakable, far superior to any written English guide.

This lady possessed a captivating charm, commanding the room with a magnetic presence not unlike a leading actress in a period film. Her energy transported us into the whimsical world of the vintage amusement park with such vivacity that one felt entirely immersed.

Within the grounds, one finds a treasure trove of antique delights: a beautifully restored carousel, a mechanical horse-racing game, and a rotating bicycle contraption, all singular and enchanting experiences one seldom encounters elsewhere.

A veritable jewel of a museum. Highly recommended for those with an appreciation for charm, artistry, and a touch of nostalgia.

What a magical experience.  You'll see - and ride! - a one-of-a-kind pedal-powered carousel and see other antique carousels and historic amusement delights you've only seen in movies or perhaps in some slightly scary (but fun) dreams.  The tour  (we went on an English language tour) was geared a bit to the children in the group, but that was fine. Our guide was upbeat and fun and allowed us a number of hands-on experiences. Marvelous artifacts and magical buildings and environs.

For a long time I have been wanting to visit Les Pavillons de Bercy... and it finally happened!  This is a one of a kind place which takes you back in time when life was simpler.  The owner has quite the collection all beautifully curated. I was in awe of all it's beauty.  I felt like Alice in Wonderland.  The tour was in French, but that did not bother me one bit.  I feel honored to have experienced such an incredible collection.  I highly recommend people visiting.  This should be a national treasure!

A true gold nugget hidden from mass tourism. The mandatory reservation makes sense because you truly need to be touring with a guide and discuss the history of every game and ride. It is not made to just walk around but to be experienced
It is so fun for grown ups and kids to try the rides! We had a blast and our guide Libere was so personable and funny. Loved this museum. I

The most fun museum I‚Äôve ever been to. After visiting it, everyone will be back to a 12-year-old kid I promise. Our guide Manon is super knowledgeable with great humour so the whole visit was just pure joy. She explained all the classic objects in the venu and answered everyone‚Äôs question patiently. The English tour is much less frequent than French one so be sure to book in advance (I think you can only visit this place in guided tour). Highly recommend!! Again, thank you Manon for making this tour so memorable :)
Nice garden. With games and a maze for children. Too bad there's only one swing out of four.
Lovely, well-maintained garden ü™¥, even though it's located on the edge of the ring road. It has children's play areas.
If there is an Asian hornet nest, for the safety of children it would be a good idea to destroy it quickly.

This kindergarten needs to be completely reworked.
Safety: e.g., why build red brick outlines in a play area?
Cleanliness: why find glass beer bottles and metal caps, not to mention cigarette butts on the ground?
Children's facilities: no one plays ping pong, why not dedicate this space for our little ones learning to play soccer or basketball? They play in the middle of the park on concrete... and no one plays ping pong.
Why aren't there water points or even toilets in a public kindergarten?
Vegetation-wise, everything needs to be reworked. The trees are planted... and they aren't maintained.
... In short, it's a shame because this garden has great potential.
The benches are sometimes dirty because of pigeons, and a swing seat is often broken. There's no water point, but overall it's quite nice.

The Danish church is welcoming. It's not an architectural masterpiece, but every December it hosts a Christmas sale with many Scandinavian items: household goods, food, and a buffet.
I highly recommend the change of scenery this unique venue provides.

The Danish Church in Paris is a wonderful place to hold a church service. The lunches are also good, so if you plan to eat, book in advance. It is always sold out! The priest is also very friendly, and so is the congregation. Danish tour groups are more than welcome!

Superb space!

I rented one of the spaces for an event, and it was just perfect. What a wonderful surprise! Go for it.

If you're into exploring the great (and lesser) cemeteries of Europe, you won't go wrong by adding this to your list. It's a lovely walk and the cemetery is filled with notable artists, authors and entertainers.  I had some trouble connecting the location of burial sites with the map located at the entrance but, if you have time, it shouldn't matter (they're not going anywhere :) )

A must do .  An insightful walk through French history . Many famous authors scientists politicians, have memorials here.   The architecture of the memorials is amazing , reflecting monumental art of that particular era.
It‚Äôs also peaceful and reflective . Above as the frantic city traffic races by, and people revel in the streets of Montmartre , here below people that once did those very same things rest eternally.
The contrast to Myself couldn‚Äôt be more poignant.

The Montmartre Cemetery left a deep impression on me. Walking among the resting places of so many renowned individuals, artists, writers, and thinkers was both humbling and thought provoking.

It reminded me that no matter how high we rise in life, we all eventually return to the same stillness. There‚Äôs something powerful about standing in the presence of history, where greatness now rests in quiet dignity.

The cemetery itself is peaceful, shaded by trees, and full of character. It‚Äôs not just a place of remembrance, but a quiet space for reflection on the impermanence of life and the legacy we leave behind.

Peaceful and quiet wandering among famous and less famous tombs. Quite amazing plot under a bridge. Do not miss the serene monument dedicated to two famous French singers Michel Berger and France Gall.
Interesting vibe, one of a kind place. It also features some known figures like Degas or Juliusz S≈Çowacki

It was a surprise for me to find a Church run by the Blessed Sacrament fathers here. The church is small but the ambience is conducive for prayers and meditation as it is quiet and less frequented by visitors. We left the church happy with our wishes and prayers offered before an contemporarily designed altar.
Attended mass in French (I am American and speak very little) but the parish was very welcoming and kind.

An interesting chapel, especially thanks to the explanations of the priest, a volunteer with the Art, Culture and Faith association, which offers free guided tours. Despite its richly decorated stained-glass windows, I found it basic and rather empty compared to other buildings I've visited. However, the organ is magnificent and breathtaking.

The Church of Saint-Medard in Paris, located in the 5th arrondissement, is one of the oldest religious buildings in the city. Its history dates back to the 9th century, when it was a small chapel dedicated to Saint Medard, the patron saint of winemakers.
The current structure was built between the 15th and 16th centuries in the Flamboyant Gothic style, which was characteristic of the late Middle Ages. The main facade of the church features a tall pointed arch over the portal. The interior retains its original elements, including the carved wooden choir benches and 16th-century stained glass windows.
Lovely church open to passersby. The interior is quiet and austere.
I visited this beautiful church because it's mentioned in p.520 Victor Hugo's Les Miserables book. What an experience...
The milestone of the Mouffetard area. For infoor spirituality and meditation or outdoor festive vibes, musicians, dances, delicacies and pastries all around
A quiet place with outstanding food and drink. Very clean and well designed. It's a regular on my Paris vacations.

The Poterne des Peupliers garden is part of the Petite Ceinture railway line in the 13th arrondissement (PC 13).

With a little imagination, you might be able to picture the landscape that once unfolded here. The Bi√®vre River, which still flows through Paris beneath our feet, used to flow here. It was filled in, a victim of human excesses, with all sorts of waste being dumped there, particularly from the tanneries. It had been transformed into an open-air landfill.

Today, this garden promenade is home to trees with poetic names like blue cedars and ginkgo biloba. Floral displays mingle with numerous perennial plants.

The garden is long and not very wide, to say the least, sloping towards the back and muddy. Not really a place to have fun with friends. Apart from two benches for our owners, it is nonetheless well enclosed, but at a low height, the more athletic could jump the gates. So stay vigilant, it's always sad to discover places in Paris that are so poorly suited to our four-legged friends.

Finally, a dog park. In Paris, we have a real problem with green spaces, many of which are forbidden to dogs. This park, on the other hand, may not be as large as the Bois de Vincennes or the Parc Montsouris, but if you want to socialize your four-legged friend, it's the ideal place.
Just one caveat: avoid going on rainy days and those immediately after. Or dress accordingly.
Good garden to stay with a few friends. This park is not Montsouris but it is great. There is no criticism because the garden is made for relaxing and not necessarily having fun.

A pretty and surprising garden, all sloping downhill, leading to a long promenade with pleasant benches for relaxing and enjoying a break from the traffic.
Greenery and common trees give a wild feel to this long, sloping garden.

Really big place to pray. There is inside and outside. Really well maintained. You enter and you go straith to find Women place. They have also inside and outside. Blue carpets, Really clean. An extremely interesting historical place with thumbs of famous French. It worths to go down to the thumbs, to learn about those politicians, philosophers, authors, scientists, but I liked the large space and pieces of history on the ground floor. Beautiful, amazing, original.

Beautiful building. Not crowded. The crypt is amazing with notable historical figures (Victor Hugo) to current historical figures.  The ambience was definitely church-like and quiet, respectful. Not my first time in Paris, but I‚Äôm surprised I only discovered today that you can actually climb the Arc de Triomphe. Enter through the underground passage ‚Äî much safer than crossing the roundabout ‚Äî and today being Sunday, entrance was free, which was a great bonus.

It was raining on and off, but that didn‚Äôt take away from the experience at all. In fact, reaching the top was the highlight of the day. The 360¬∞ views of Paris are incredible, and seeing the Eiffel Tower from above feels completely different from seeing it at street level.

For anyone visiting ‚Äî even if you‚Äôve been to Paris multiple times ‚Äî going up the Arc is absolutely worth it. It offers a fresh perspective on the city and some of the best photo spots you‚Äôll find. Highly recommended.

„ÄêQuick Summary„ÄëA spectacular view of Paris at night! The illuminated Arc de Triomphe and the sparkling Eiffel Tower view from the top are absolutely breathtaking.

„ÄêPurpose of Visit„ÄëPerfect for an evening visit, especially for night view appreciation, right after checking in on your arrival day.

‚úÖ Experience (Highlights)
After a flight from Tokyo, we checked into the hotel around 4 PM and headed straight to the iconic Arc de Triomphe.

* ‚úÖ The View from the Arc: While the illuminated Arc de Triomphe itself is grand and full of charm, **the Eiffel Tower's sparkle illumination (Champagne Flash) seen clearly from the top of the Arc is truly unmissable.**
* By visiting during the transition from dusk to night, we enjoyed a complete panorama: the grandeur of the Arc, the lights along the Champs-√âlys√©es, and the dazzling sparkle of the Eiffel Tower.

* ‚úÖ Final Impression: I believe everyone who witnesses this view will fall in love with Paris. It was a magical moment‚Äîthe highlight of a perfect Parisian evening.

The Arc de Triomphe is absolutely worth going up. The climb is a bit of a workout, but the view at the top makes it more than worth it. Looking out over the Champs-√âlys√©es and the Eiffel Tower is astonishing, especially at sunset.

The atmosphere at the top is surprisingly calm compared to the busy traffic circle below. It also has a romantic feel to it, and it‚Äôs a great spot for a proposal or a special moment.

It's a dream come true being able to actually see and touch it in person. We visited Paris on Bastille Day, so there was a ceremony where flowers was lying down. I was able to climb the Arc de Triomphe where you can see Paris city's. You can also see Le Champ Elysee which is  a very popular street in Paris. Beautiful place

Visiting the Arc de Triomphe for the first time was truly amazing. Standing beneath this monumental arch, I could really feel the weight of history and the beauty of its design. Every carving and detail tells a story, and being there in person made me appreciate it so much more than just seeing it in pictures. Climbing the 284 steps to the top was a challenge, but absolutely worth it‚Äîthe view of Paris stretched out in every direction, with the Eiffel Tower standing tall and the Champs-√âlys√©es looking endless. The view was breathtaking and made the whole experience unforgettable. It‚Äôs one of those places that captures the magic of Paris in a single moment.

The church is inspired by Florentine Romanesque art, vast, spacious, and understated. The interior features works such as the wooden Our Lady of the Nations and a statue of Our Lady of the Rosary giving the Rosary to Saint Dominic and Saint Catherine, inspired by the painting in the Chapel of Saint Catherine, Basilica of Santa Sabina, Rome, Italy.

Outside, a remarkable bell tower is adorned with the statue of Our Lady of the Rosary.
